Like our page on Facebook and share information about our Lucky 13th Season campaign!
Come out and support TOOP by being an audience member of our 13th season shows! More information can be found on the TOOP Facebook page, or the TOOP website (both links are below).
If you own a business or know of a business that would be interested in supporting TOOP, please send a message to Kathryn Loveless, our Development Coordinator, and she will be in touch with more information.

If you have any questions about TOOP, our 13th Season campaign, or anything else, please don't hesitate to contact us at the addresses below!

Thank you for your time and support!

story:
About CONTEUR

Conteur is an established Canadian professional dance company, founded in 2011 in Toronto, ON that incorporates modern contemporary movement to express ideas and commentaries on the human condition.

Pushing the limits creatively, Conteur’s efforts to enlighten, inspire and entertain by exposing audiences to the beauty and intricacy of contemporary dance is the ultimate vision.

  • Conteur’s inaugural season and presentation of “State of Mind”, was presented to a sold out audience in Toronto, ON. "State of Mind" raised almost $20,000.00 for the charity – THREE TO BE; in support of research, therapies and initiatives for children with neurological disorders.

  • Conteur is dancing for those that are unable to dance, we are moving for the children; inspiring others to be a part of this change.

  • Sponsoring the show will aid in offsetting the costs of various productions expenses including, theatre, lighting design and parts, costuming, studio rental costs, artist salaries, and printing costs.

  • Without your help, Conteur is unable to successfully create a show of this caliber, which will achieve both entertainment value and make a difference in the community.

re(ACT) in Support of THREE TO BE

On November 22nd to 24th 2013 at the Fleck Dance Theatre, in Toronto, Conteur will be hitting the stage for its 2nd season premiering new works, researched and choreographed by Eryn Waltman in a show called – re(ACT). 

Re(ACT) is a contemporary dance performance which chronicles the physical, mental and spiritual development of one woman throughout the cycle of life. Rather than depicting the woman on a life course with a fixed beginning and end, re(ACT) explores the spectrum of life as a full circle, where the individual exists in purest form in the primary stages of life. In time, one harnesses the power to hold absolute awareness, absolute understanding and acceptance of time, of space and of the self. In succeeding to gain a strong sense of stability, balance and purpose, the individual arrives at a place of self-actualization − the return to the purist form of the self.

Conteur with the presentation of re(ACT) is especially proud and pleased to be partnering up with THREE TO BE for its second season, to bring awareness and support for the organization working with The Hospital for Sick Children and Holland Bloorview Kids Rehabilitation Hospital to support research initiatives that further the development of innovative treatments and therapies for children with neurological disorders. There are presently no foundations or agencies in Canada aimed at funding research and therapy for this broad spectrum of disorders, which range from Cerebral Palsy to Epilepsy to Autism. THREE TO BE stands ready to fill that gap. They are passionate about developing the organization to advance these fields of research and to make a difference in the lives of many children living with neurological disorders.

HOW YOU CAN HELP:


The Budget for this show is about $65000.00! Your support will help cover costs for our dancers, theatre expenses, production expenses, lighting, marketing, publicity, and more more! We have company members who have flown up from LA  (So You Think You Can Dance USA), Montreal, and various other places around Canada, all of which believe in this as much as we do! With YOUR HELP, we can make it happen!!!

We will offer you various tickets to the show, Conteur Merchandise, sneak peeks at the creative process, postcards, autographed Conteur materials, Private classes and interviews with dancers and the Artistic Director and much more!!

When supporting re(ACT), you will also be supporting our initiative to donate to this very worthwhile organization, THREE TO BE. Your support is needed and any size financial contribution is encouraged and appreciated!!!

Thank you from the bottom of our hearts!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute with a monetary donation, please help spread the word by sharing this link with everyone you know!

With YOUR HELP, we can make it happen!!!We will offer you various tickets to the show, Conteur Merchandise, sneak peeks at the creative process, postcards, autographed Conteur materials, Private classes and interviews with dancers and the Artistic Director and much more!!When supporting re(ACT), you will also be supporting our initiative to donate to this very worthwhile
organization, THREE TO BE. Your
support is needed and any size financial contribution is encouraged and
appreciated!!! 

Thank you from the bottom of our hearts! 


Other Ways You Can HelpIf you cannot contribute with a monetary donation, please help spread the word by sharing this link with everyone you know!

story:
Hey Everyone!

My name is Rebecca Green.  I am a dancer, choreographer and movement artist.  I currently attend California Institute of the Arts and am in my third year of the dance program there.  Each year, two qualified and hardworking third year dance majors are chosen to study abroad and travel to London for the Fall semester of their fourth year. After much persistence, writing a proposal and conferencing personally with the dance faculty, I found out:  I'VE BEEN SELECTED!  This is an absolutely once in a life time opportunity for me to study with educators and fellow dancers that I would never have met other wise, and I am so excited!   
London Contemporary Dance School is the UK's premier center for Contemporary Dance.  The program I will be a part of while attending is the 3 year BFA program. Some things this program will explore are strengthening and learning new techniques, teaching, choreography and collaboration across art forms.   
"As they continue the programme, our students deepen and extend their technical base, interpreting new work, and tackling more complex choreographic and improvisation tasks. They explore how to reflect on their developing interests in relation the artistic, professional and social contexts that shape contemporary dance today. - See more at: http://www.lcds.ac.uk/undergraduate#sthash.e3xvORWu.dpuf"

What I Need

Traveling and Living In London for 5 months is going to be an exhilarating and unique experience.  Unfortunately, it is also going to be very expensive!  In addition to paying my tuition for CalArts, which runs approximately 50,000, I will be paying to reside in London while I am attending the London Contemporary Dance School.  In order to do this, I need your help! 
Here is a breakdown of my budget, estimated by the International student and exchange coordinator here at CalArts. 


Airfare  $1400

Local Transport  $700

Accommodations  $5000

Utilities $250

Food and Household Goods  $1500

Insurance $500

Miscellaneous $1200

TOTAL $10,550


$10,550 is a pretty terrifying number for a college student who is up to her ears in student loans (me), but I am more than confident I will achieve my goal with the help of this campaign!  

If I do not reach my goal, all of the funds earned will go towards my living expenses during my time at LCDS.  

 

Why Donate? 

This program will open up many doors to further my artistry and my career. Traveling to LCDS is a chance for me to make personal connections, network, learn new skills and enrich my education so that I can put into practice and share the knowledge that they have to offer.  
On a larger scale, traveling and exchange of this kind is what allows the art community to communicate and share new information with one another.  I will not only be making connections with people in London for myself but also for the benefit of many other artists within my personal network.  I will be helping to bridge the gap internationally between artists in hopes of fueling the ever growing and developing global art community.     

Can't Donate?
Don't worry!  There are lots of ways to help.  You can start by sharing this campaign with your friends and family.  Help spread the word!  

Thanks for taking the time to view this campaign page and have a wonderful day!

Sincerely,
Rebecca Green

story:
Hi Everyone, my name is Ivan Jermyn. I am sixteen years old and I live in  Montpelier Vermont. This year in the summer, I have been chosen to go on tour with Circus Smirkus. This 10 week summer of touring will be so amazing and life changing and I will love every minute of it.

One problem, I need to raise $6,250 before going on tour.

Please donate as much as you want to and help spread the word to all of your friends and relatives to help me train and perform.

Thank you so much.

For more information about what i'll be doing this summer, feel free to check out this video.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5_CRNdD6BpQ

story:
Cecilia Borasino is an independent coreographer  from Lima Peru since 2001. Her creations are the results of a multidisciplinary artistic team formed  by: Dancers, actors, musicians, photographers, video makers and costume disigners.

Cecilia and her team have been invited to present two of her most important works in theater YUYACHKANI for a series of presentations from may 29 to june 8. This retrospective is an opportunity to present for a very large and varied public the creations from 2008 ANONIMOS and 2010 EJERCICIOS PARA EVITAR EL SUEÑO which are still significant.

This presentations will promote the growth and recognition of contemporary dance in Peru opening new opportunities for a new public and artists to come in contact with an art form that does not have many followers in Peru, but as you know, deeply touches the soul and makes people reflect on the emotions of human existence

WHAT WE NEED: 

To cover all the expenses in salaries and material resources required to present both plays for 10 days we need US 4800.00 $.

This Money will be used to pay for the rehearsal facilities, printing the programs and the rest of the publicity required; It also includes costumes maintenance; video projectors, artists, producer, press agent, theater rent, and technical personal.

We will gladly compensate your support by putting your name and logo in all our advertising material, you will receive invitations to the shows, autographed cards, invitations to the party with the artists and our infinite gratitute for ever and ever!

We hope that with your help we will reach our financing needs and be able to cover the expenses required. And that this presentations will help the spiritual growth of a large audience.

story:
The Company and the Project

Beyond the Round is a theatre and film production company founded by Rachel Dottermann and Kalina Hada-Lemon, a team with ten years of combined experience in "show biz." After working together in London for several years as actors, designers and producers, we decided to move to the big city and bring our art with us! This summer, we are extremely excited to be producing High Life, a work by Canadian playwright Lee MacDougall. This has been a passion project for quite a while and the opportunity to share it with the city of Toronto is irresistible. We place heavy importance on producing and distributing the works of local artists, to support Toronto's "entertainment economy." High Life is a delightfully Canadian and ironically light perspective on what is typically considered the darker way of life - the life of a junkie. Not only are the dialogue, vocabulary and style familiar, but the characters and story are also accessible, allowing the audience to connect with them on a human level. If you contribute to this campaign, not only will you be allowing a complete team of artists to achieve an amazing feat, but you will also open up a different perspective on theatre for new and veteran audiences.


You Spot Us, We'll Spot You

We have an amazing artistic and productive team, a stellar cast, and phenomenal script, but unfortunately our money tree burnt down. Maybe yours is still fruitful? We are looking for contributions to put towards the production aspects of our show, and we can't do it without your help!

Our fundraising goal for High Life is $4000, which covers the cost of:

  • theatre rental (Scotiabank Studio Theatre @ Pia Bouman School) 
  • advertising (posters, press, etc.)
  • programmes (cast and crew bios, advertisements, special thanks, etc.)
  • rights to the play (playwright's royalty)
  • lighting/sound (set-up and usage)
  • set (apartment interior, car interior)
  • rehearsal rental insurance (3 months)

Your donations are invaluable to this production! Any amount possible puts us one step closer to attaining our goal, and we are more than grateful. And of course, we won't leave you jonesin' - check out our awesome perks to see what your generosity gets you! From thank you's to an Executive Producer credit, there's something available for anyone to enjoy...cause we owe ya one!

Any funds left over from production budget, or gained after the run of the show will be distributed amongst the cast and crew of the project. We are big believers in art for the love of it, but our team definitely deserves a reward for all their time, effort and commitment. 


You'll Get Addicted

High Life is a brilliantly written script by Kirkland Lake native, Lee MacDougall. It is a dark, hilarious and addictive dialogue with characters so endearing that you'll always be on their side. Dick, a plotter by nature, pitches a plan to his newly-released fellow ex-con and "raving morphadite," Bug. With two other junkies on board, one a clean-cut ladies man and the other a neurotic invalid, he takes charge of a "failsafe" plan to rob a bank for nothing other than an unlimited, lifetime supply of morphine. But what happens when you cram four murderous, jonesin' addicts in a car together for hours on end? Well, that's why you have to come see the show...

Beyond the Round is dedicated to producing engaging theatre for a new generation of audiences. We believe that over the years theatre has become less accessible to its attendees, with there being gaps in generational style, dialogue and subject matter. It has become our goal to win over the people who wouldn't normally consider theatre as an outing, or who avoid it because of any preconceived notions or past experience. We want to show people that these characters on stage are much less foreign to them than they may think, and this is why we chose to do High Life this summer. Lee MacDougall's characters are artfully crafted into three dimensional people who would be just as believable offstage as they are on. The fact that it is set in a Canadian city and includes many enjoyable "Canadianisms" gives the audience a "way in" when experiencing the performance. Theatre is not dead, and we refuse to let it die!


Shake Our Hands

Any and all contributions to High Life will allow a strong group of young artists to establish their professional careers in Toronto. Our team consists of two stand-up comedians, veterans of the stage, Troy Stark and Blayne Smith; we also welcome Victor Pokinko and Christian Tribuzio, two fresh graduates of the Joint UofT/Sheridan Theatre program. Together, these four make up our loveable cast of morphine-addicted junkies. We adore them, and you will too.

Blayne Smith is an up-and-coming Toronto stand-up comic. Known for his high energy storytelling, Blayne exposes funny and weird life experiences that come with being a metalhead. He performed on season two of iChannel's No Kidding series and will be appearing in season three of MTV's Losing It. In 2013, he performed as a part of Canadian Music Fest, the Dark Comedy Festival, and was a 2013 Tim Sims Award Nominee. Blayne has opened for Aisha Tyler, Robert Kelly and performed in clubs along the East Coast on his recent U.S-Canadian tour. http://metalcomedy.com/

Troy Stark’s sharp writing, sarcastic attitude, and bizarre life experiences make him one of Toronto’s most original voices in Canadian comedy. Before diving fully into stand-up comedy, Troy was a writer for The AV Club. He recently finished a 10 week stint on the road with his #NomadSummer tour, East Coast All Day 2013 stand-up tour. He’s performed in Canada’s top clubs, including Yuk Yuks, Absolute Comedy, The Comedy Cave, The Comedy Nest, Comedy Works, and has appeared at The Ottawa Explosion Fest and he's been featured on MTV's Losing It. He and Blayne are the co-creators and stars of the web series The Shit Hawks, which recently premiered its second season, and produces a monthly show, Classy Drunk at the Emmet Ray.  http://thetroystark.com/

Kalina Hada-Lemon (Director/Producer) and Rachel Dottermann (Producer/Designer), we are your heads of production team! Together we have tackled almost every role in the theatre, from acting to directing, producing to stage managing, and have formal film training both on and off-camera. We have been working together for years, have two award-winning shows behind us and are now thrilled to be in the big city! It couldn't be more exhilarating to be sharing our work with Toronto and becoming a part of its integral artistic community.


If Your Money Tree is also Malfunctioning

Hey, I hear you, but money isn't the only way you can help us out! Spread the word via Facebook, Twitter, and all the other thousands of social networking sites out there...share this indiegogo campaign and get all your friends and neighbours involved. Also, like and follow the Beyond the Round page at https://www.facebook.com/beyondtheroundproductions

Anything you can do to spread the word will greatly benefit us and our project!

story:
What's going on!?

Spawned by the American Repertory Theater and the Moscow Art Theater, Empirical Rogue has been producing theater in New York City since 2011.

In December, we start rehearsals for an exciting new adaptation of Nikolai Erdman's black comedy, Suicide!?

This have-to-see-it-to-believe-it farce speaks directly to the experience of many Americans, still struggling to move forward in a stagnant economy. In the last few years, we've all felt less secure, less optimistic, and more desperate.

Suicide!? is the play that has the temerity to ask "what the f*** is going on here?"


We're going to bring audiences together to laugh like stupid, rethink the world, and connect with all the other brilliant, good-looking audience members that will be coming. You read that right.


A comedy about suicide? What's the story?

Finding himself without a job, without hope, and without escape, Simon Podsednik stands on the brink between losing everything and ending it all. Concerned friends and family stage an intervention, but their frantic attempts to fix things might do more harm than good.

Adapted from the Stalin-censored 1928 play of the same name, Suicide!?, now updated and restaged in 2013 New York, pulls back the curtain on the desperate times and desperate measures that accompany a flailing economy. Alternating between gritty humor and painful insight, Suicide!? pushes us to ask: what is our true cost of living, and what is the price we are willing to pay?


How much will that cost, and can I get some fun swag?

We need to raise $8,600 to make this timely, hilarious, complex show a reality. This is as shoestringy a budget as you're likely to see in NYC theater. We can make it work because we're highly trained and experienced, and most of all, we believe in this play.


$2,200 will pay the entirety of renting our space, the Interart Theater, for four weeks of rehearsals and four weekends of performances. Deals like this are unheard of, and it's only possible because the owners and other space occupants believe in us, too.

$800 will go toward furnishing the set, designed by Dante Olivia Smith.

Just $500 will cover all the lighting needs for the production: gels, instruments, cable, you name it.

$1,200 will cover complete costumes for all 10 actors, including laundry. Trust us on that last bit. Designs by Summer Lee Jack, and her inspirations, can be seen here.

We'll spend $500 on props: many many props, plants and guns and knives and more.

$200 will produce thousands of promotional bookmarks, our go-to piece of physical marketing. They're small, memorable, and useful. Oo!

$2,000 will cover travel expenses for our 10 cast members for two months. It costs over $100/month to ride the subway in NYC!

Another $1,200 will cover travel expenses for our six crew members: stage manager, production designer, production assistant, lighting designer, costume designer, and our director, Tim Eliot.

These are all the elements that we need to bring together -- rent, materials, marketing, and basic (minimum-legally-required-by-unions) remuneration.


Every little bit helps, and in return, we have some cool perks:

$1+     Thanks in our program! Put your name in sweet, sweet black and white.

$10+   A personalized social media shout-out by one of our team members. We hope that sincere flattery will get us everywhere.

$30+   One free VIP ticket to the show: comes with a FREE DRINK. That's riiiiight.

$50+   ANOTHER free VIP ticket to the show, with TWO free drinks. A steal!

$70+   Digital copy of the first act of the script before we open AND a digital copy of our production album after we close. Instant insider status.

$100+  A commemorative bound hardcopy of the entire script, signed by the creative team, mailed or hand-delivered directly to you!

$250+  A hardcover copy of the production album, signed by the creative team. Check out the digital production album from our last show here.

$500+  Official Associate Producer credit on the production.


These perks are all cumulative -- if you get the $70 perk, you get the $50, $30, $10, and $1 perks too.



How's this gonna help!?

Science has proven that art makes people nicer and more intelligent!

We knew that already, and yeah, we want to have fun and make things better. Almost all of us live in New York City, possibly the world's biggest financial hub. Most of us subsist on very little, as do a majority of NYC's inhabitants. All of us are theater artists.

We're compelled to pursue this career, instead of investment banking or stock trading, because we know that our society is only as strong as it is vibrant, connected, and understanding.

We're looking for big-hearted investors. People who want to change the world in slow, kind, incremental ways. People who want to create art, gather people together, laugh out loud at difficult things, and come away a little wiser, a little more understanding, and a little more hopeful.

This is what society is made of, and it's what this play is all about. That, and coffin jokes.


Last year, we produced a stunning production of Romeo and Juliet that reimagined a defunct urban space as a vibrant, unprecedented stage. New Yorkers of all stripes, including hundreds of schoolchildren, came and rocked out. Check out the production album here.

In January, we produced a one-time reading of MacBeth that raised over $1,000 for Occupy Sandy's hurricane-relief efforts.

Our team members have worked all over America and NYC and we're overjoyed to be bringing Suicide!? to the stage. We hope you're just as excited to help out!


Money is tight right now -- can I still help!?

Heck yes! We need to spread the word as far and wide as possible, so get on the facebook, the twitter, and the email, and tell everyone you know about this crazy-fun show you just heard about. You can even share this campaign page directly! Click around!

Also, we need a tuba!

Alternating between gritty humor and painful insight, Suicide!? pushes us to ask: what is our true cost of living, and what is the price we are willing to pay?


How much will that cost, and can I get some fun swag?
We need to raise $8,600 to make this timely, hilarious, complex show a reality. This is as shoestringy a budget as you're likely to see in NYC theater. We can make it work because we're highly trained and experienced, and most of all, we believe in this play.

$2,200 will pay the entirety of renting our space, the Interart Theater, for four weeks of rehearsals and four weekends of performances. Deals like this are unheard of, and it's only possible because the owners and other space occupants believe in us, too.
$800 will go toward furnishing the set, designed by Dante Olivia Smith.
Just $500 will cover all the lighting needs for the production: gels, instruments, cable, you name it.
$1,200 will cover complete costumes for all 10 actors, including laundry. Trust us on that last bit. Designs by Summer Lee Jack, and her inspirations, can be seen here.
We'll spend $500 on props: many many props, plants and guns and knives and more.
$200 will produce thousands of promotional bookmarks, our go-to piece of physical marketing. They're small, memorable, and useful. Oo!
$2,000 will cover travel expenses for our 10 cast members for two months. It costs over $100/month to ride the subway in NYC!
Another $1,200 will cover travel expenses for our six crew members: stage manager, production designer, production assistant, lighting designer, costume designer, and our director, Tim Eliot.
These are all the elements that we need to bring together -- rent, materials, marketing, and basic (minimum-legally-required-by-unions) remuneration.

Every little bit helps, and in return, we have some cool perks:
$1+     Thanks in our program! Put your name in sweet, sweet black and white.
$10+   A personalized social media shout-out by one of our team members. We hope that sincere flattery will get us everywhere.
$30+   One free VIP ticket to the show: comes with a FREE DRINK. That's riiiiight.
$50+   ANOTHER free VIP ticket to the show, with TWO free drinks. A steal!
$70+   Digital copy of the first act of the script before we open AND a digital copy of our production album after we close. Instant insider status.
$100+  A commemorative bound hardcopy of the entire script, signed by the creative team, mailed or hand-delivered directly to you!
$250+  A hardcover copy of the production album, signed by the creative team. Check out the digital production album from our last show here.
$500+  Official Associate Producer credit on the production.

These perks are all cumulative -- if you get the $70 perk, you get the $50, $30, $10, and $1 perks too.


How's this gonna help!?
Science has proven that art makes people nicer and more intelligent!
We knew that already, and yeah, we want to have fun and make things better. Almost all of us live in New York City, possibly the world's biggest financial hub. Most of us subsist on very little, as do a majority of NYC's inhabitants. All of us are theater artists.
We're compelled to pursue this career, instead of investment banking or stock trading, because we know that our society is only as strong as it is vibrant, connected, and understanding.
We're looking for big-hearted investors. People who want to change the world in slow, kind, incremental ways. People who want to create art, gather people together, laugh out loud at difficult things, and come away a little wiser, a little more understanding, and a little more hopeful.
This is what society is made of, and it's what this play is all about. That, and coffin jokes.

Last year, we produced a stunning production of Romeo and Juliet that reimagined a defunct urban space as a vibrant, unprecedented stage. New Yorkers of all stripes, including hundreds of schoolchildren, came and rocked out. Check out the production album here.
In January, we produced a one-time reading of MacBeth that raised over $1,000 for Occupy Sandy's hurricane-relief efforts.
Our team members have worked all over America and NYC and we're overjoyed to be bringing Suicide!? to the stage. We hope you're just as excited to help out!



Money is tight right now -- can I still help!?
Heck yes! We need to spread the word as far and wide as possible, so get on the facebook, the twitter, and the email, and tell everyone you know about this crazy-fun show you just heard about. You can even share this campaign page directly! Click around!
Also, we need a tuba!

story:
Home Grown Theatre Co.: An all student production company – with experience.

Home Grown Theatre Co. is a non-profit company (501(c)3 status pending) run solely by students. In summer 2013, Home Grown will be doing three completely high school student productions: Frost/Nixon, Into the Woods, and Metamorphoses. That's right, these productions are made up of just students, from the company founder (who graduates high school in May), to the entire cast and crews making each show. But just because these productions are in the hands of the “dreaded teenager” doesn't mean they aren't of quality, professionalism, and skill. In fact, these productions will have all of this and more. Last summer, Home Grown produced an all-teen benefit of the hit Broadway musical RENT, with proceeds from ticket sales ranging in the $6,000 range and going to the theatrical charity Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS. The entire production was the experience of a lifetime, giving everyone involved (most of whom will be returning this season) an extraordinary preparedness for life and the journey into the future. All of the funds raised for this season support the education of those involved, and the time we learn the most is when we're on our own with no help, after all. Not to mention as much of the ticket proceeds as possible will again go to the charity Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS.



Charity + Education + You = An extraordinary opportunity to do something different



A stellar lineup of shows for 2013 – with a stellar production team.

Home Grown Theatre has chosen a careful line-up this year that is sure to excite audiences just like last year's production of RENT. That being said this stellar lineup also comes with a stellar production team working behind it, each member hand-picked by founder Hersh Ellis himself for their motivation and professionalism.



“We're all emotionally invested in all parts of the show. We own it. We want it to be our best.” - Home Grown Theatre Co. Artistic Director Hersh Ellis in an interview for The Jewish Chronicle



Home Grown Theatre Co. is proud to announce its 2013 summer season. Kansas City’s only entirely student run theatre company, under Artistic Director Hersh Ellis, Home Grown is launching three brave, unique and bold productions ranging from a haunting reinvention of a Sondheim classic to a beautifully staged exploration of change.


Frost/Nixon

June 5-9 at 8:00pm

Written by Peter Morgan

Directed by Will Barboza

Concept art for Frost/Nixon under direction by Will Barboza, Director in Residence.

British talk-show host David Frost has become a lowbrow laughing-stock. Richard M. Nixon has just resigned the United States presidency in total disgrace over Vietnam and the Watergate scandal. Determined to resurrect his career, Frost risks everything on a series of in-depth interviews in order to extract an apology from Nixon. The cagey Nixon, however, is equally bent on redeeming himself in his nation's eyes. In the television age, image is king, and both men are desperate to out talk and upstage each other as the cameras roll. The result is the interview that sealed a president's legacy.

Nominated for the 2006 Tony Award for Best Play and 2008 Academy Award for Best Picture.

"…a thoroughly modern Shakespearean tragedy…Peter Morgan has given us a behind the scenes look at a well-publicized event, and used his imagination to create a riveting entertainment…most notably, the midnight phone call from an inebriated Nixon to Frost that, like a show stopping song in a musical or an outstanding opera aria, has the audience bursting into applause." — CurtainUp.

"…ripe entertainment…The cheerily oblivious limey lightweight and the brooding, mortally wounded political animal: Austin Powers vs. Macbeth." — Washington Post.

Into the Woods

July 2-3 and 5-7 at 8:00pm

Music and Lyrics by Stephen Sondheim

Book by James Lapine

Directed by Hersh Ellis

Music Direction by Joseph Bricker

Concept art for Into the Woods under direction by Founder Hersh Ellis and music direction by Joseph Bricker.

Everyone's favorite storybook characters are brought together for a timeless yet relevant piece and rare modern classic. The story follows a Baker and his wife who wish to have a child, Cinderella who wishes to attend the King's Festival, and Jack who wishes his cow would give milk. Everyone's wish is granted, but the consequences of their actions return to haunt them later with disastrous results.

Artistic Director Hersh Ellis, who directed last year’s inaugural production of RENT, will re-imagine the staging in this unique production of a poignant and sophisticated classic.Into the Woods will be deconstructed to its core as a story about people finding their way in face of disaster after a seemingly “happily ever after.” This isn’t your cookie-cutter Disney fairy tale.

Appropriate for Middle School and up.

Into the Woodsis a Tony award winning musical for Best Score and Best Book of a musical.

Metamorphoses

July 23-27 at 8:00pm

Written by Mary Zimmerman

Directed by Hersh Ellis and Hailee Windsor

Concept art for Home Grown Theatre Co.'s production of Metamorphoses under the direction of founder Hersh Ellis and Hailee Windsor.

A magical journey into Ovid’s world of transformation and enchantment. In breathtaking images, classic characters from Greek mythology experience love and loss, joy and pain, as the inevitable consequences of their own actions transform them. Metamorphosesconsists of nine thought-provoking vignettes that are sure to dazzle.

Winner of several Tony Awards in 2002.

"Shows that theatre can provide not just escape but sometimes a glimpse of the divine." - TIME Magazine.

"Entrancing… an evening of almost magical changes, wrought through the unique imagery of Theatre" -Chicago Tribune.

Metamorphoses is performed in and around a massive pool occupying most of the stage. You have to see this spectacle to believe it. Artistic Director Hersh Ellis (Into the Woods, RENT) and Associate Artistic Director Hailee Windsor (RENT musical staging) will co-direct this production of “epic” proportion.

Appropriate for Middle School and up.



A carefully calculated budget and plan – with room for as much quality as possible.

Running and producing three shows is by no means cheap, but experience has helped us figure out how to minimize costs while giving everyone a high quality production. Numerous expenses have to be accounted for, including the rental of the theater and appropriate equipment, performance rights, insurance, and phone and web hosting bills. Professional and school theatrical companies have the resources and money to have access to all of this easily. Since Home Grown is a non-profit company made up of only students, it just has you. (But we're so incredibly lucky!)

Here is a break down of how much everything will cost and where your money will go:

Theater Rental = $2000

Set: 2 shows = $1000

Royalties for 15 performances = $3075

Into the Woods: $440 x 5 shows = $2200

Metamorphoses: $100 x 5 shows = $500

Frost/Nixon: $75 x 5 shows = $375

Insurance = $250

Web hosting for 1 year = $105

IndieGoGo Fee = $635.94

Total Cost: $7066 

You may have noticed that rehearsal and office space, costumes, props, make-up, print shop fees, and microphones aren't included in this mix. All of these have either been kindly donated to us, or we are reusing them from previous productions.

Stretch Goal

Metamorphoses = $800 +

We have also set up a stretch goal. Should we be fully funded, any additional money donated will go straight into Metamorphoses, our third show of the season. Currently, we have set up the budget so that it will be funded via profits from tickets sales on our first two shows. But if we are able to raise more money now, than more will be available along the road for charity.



Thank you for supporting the future of the arts.





FAQ (Frequently Asked Questions)

Do I need a Paypal account to contribute?

You will need to make a Paypal account if you wish to contribute using the Paypal option if you don't already have one. Otherwise, you can contribute via credit/debit card automatically.

If Home Grown Theatre Co. is a non-profit 501(c)3 company, does that mean my donations are tax deductible?

Our 501(c)3 status is pending. We are in the process of confirming it, and we apologize for the inconvenience. Please donate and choose one of our great perks instead!

Where does the money from the ticket sales go and how is it used? Or what is Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS?

Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS (BC/EFA) is a nonprofit charitable foundation that uses the American theatre community  to help support people with AIDS and other critical illnesses. For more information about BC/EFA, visit their website at: http://www.broadwaycares.org/.

This company is really run by students with no professionals or teachers?

Yes, and to top it off, most of our team is still in high school. We have a few college students, but the majority of us are under the age of 18. It is the only theatre company in the Kansas City area to do so, and probably one of a few in the entire country. But we can assure you, all of us are extremely motivated and devoted to Theatre, and we wouldn't do this unless we thought we couldn't deliver something of value and worthwhile.

How can I get tickets to a show?

We are working on getting a website up and running. We plan on implementing some sort of online ticketing system soon, while we will also be selling tickets at the door and will accept both cash and credit cards. In the meantime, we suggest our Early Access Perk, which will give you the best chance to get tickets to a show.

story:
NEW:  Our S-T-R-E-T-C-H goals are here!  Scroll down...

UPDATE

We reached our goal with 28 days left in the campaign!  The amount we wanted to raise was modest and what we felt was attainable -- and we attained it!  The entire cast and company are SO grateful to our generous contributors.

All funds raised to our goal go to the artists

Even though we surpassed our goal, ALL the funds raised will still be shared by the artists -- the actors, director, stage manager and playwright of this show, who are all working for free and a share of the modest box office from this festival production.  Surpassing our goal means that we are that much less dependent on the box office for any compensation after rehearsing full time for a month followed by 7 performances over the 10 days of the festival.

Also indiegogo/paypal deducts 9% of your contribution as their fee.  So we really won't have attained our goal until we're 9% past it!

Now that we've achieved a small stipend for the amazing pros who are working on this show by making our original goal, we've set STRETCH goals to entice you to make this production even better than it was going to be.

Support a World Premiere!

My name is Sugith Varughese and I'm a produced film and television screenwriter and actor.  Now my first stage play has been accepted by the prestigious Summerworks Theatre Festival in Toronto!

It's a satire about the conflict between my generation and the millenials--the ones who came of age in 2000 and beyond.  It's called ENTITLEMENT.

In the play, an out of work screenwriter takes as job teaching scriptwriting to college kids.  When an ambitious student challenges his methods, the screenwriter has to fight for his job.  It's about the transformation of education to edutainment and the growing power of an entitled generation to assert their will--but at what cost?

As an out of work screenwriter (award-winning!--look me up on imdb.com or wikipedia.org), I taught scriptwriting courses at colleges and the play's inspired by my experiences.

It's funny.  And timely.  I'm thrilled the Summerworks jury thought enough of it to accept the play as part of the 2013 festival.

As fanastic as acceptance into the festival is, it means that I, as well as the director, the actors and other artists involved in the production only get paid from the box office receipts.  And the funds to produce the play must be raised by me.

Being my first play, I will do whatever it takes to produce it at Summerworks.

But I could use some help--which will go DIRECTLY to the actors, director and stage manager who are working for free to put on the play.  Instead of hoping for something out of the box office, once expenses like the props and set get paid for, YOUR HELP will give them some assurance that they aren't working for nothing.

They believe in the play and are donating their time and talent NOW.  Your contribution will modestly compensate them beyond what we might get from the box office during the festival.

A union-sanctioned show

The artist members of Canadian Actors' Equity, (the union for stage performers and directors), are working under a festival agreement, which gives them the opportunity to work for free in exchange for an artist share of the box office from the festival.  A fee is paid to CAEA to provide the artists with health insurance for the month leading up to the festival performances, (which must be recoupled from box office receipts, along with all the other expenses before the artists receive any monies.)  We are proud to be members of Equity and are grateful that the festival agreement enables Equity members to work on this kind of show and bring their high levels of professional standards to the production.

What We Need & What You Get

I hope I can raise at least $3000 which would be shared by:

  • 3 cast members, Dora-winning actress Karen Robinson, seasoned veteran actor Sam Khalilieh and an exciting newcomer Christo Graham
  • the director, Dora-winning actor and director David Ferry
  • the stage manager, Michael Sinclair
  • the playwright and producer, Sugith Varughese (also an award-winning screenwriter and actor)

Besides supporting the premiere of Entitlement, your contribution will net you some pretty cool perks like:

  • a copy of the script, signed by the playwright
  • a copy of the band Folk Off's CD
  • access to the secret missing video of someone smoking crack on a Ford
  • drinks with the cast and playwright
  • private talkback after the show with the cast and playwright
  • a private dialogue class with acclaimed director David Ferry

as well as the knowledge that your contribution will help support the participation of some of Canada's best theatre artists in the premiere of Entitlement.

LAST MINUTE ADDITIONAL PERK:

ALL contributors will receive a link to a certain missing video of a really big guy possibly smoking something in front of a Ford... and singing the theme song to Entitlement.

What Your Contribution Means

Everyone has a story about encountering someone with a sense of entitlement.  It seems like entitlement is the product of our times.  That's what this play is about.

It's a searing satire about the conflict between generations.  We want the over-40 and the under-25 demographic to come.  We want generational brawls to break out in the aisles!  (Not really.)  We want people to either see themselves or see someone they recognize in this play.

Your contribution makes that possible.  The timeliness of this play means that it will have an impact on those who see it.  It's possible that this production may be the first of many, if the play's the success we believe it can be.

And the people behind this play aren't beginners.

  • Director David Ferry has been nominated ten times for DORA awards, winning three times: best actor, best director and a shared best lighting design. He has been nominated for Genie, Gemini and Canadian Comedy Awards, and has won a Nellie for best radio actor, and the inaugural Toronto Drama Critics award for best actor (Blasted.) He was the 2011 recipient of the Barbara Hamilton Award. He has a coveted Harold award.
  • Karen Robinson has 3 DORA nominations, 1 win - Best Actress; 1 STERLING win (Edmonton) - Best Actress;  Salento Int'l Film Festival (Italy) - Best Actress; NAACP Theatre Award - Best Ensemble; 1 BETTY nomination (Calgary) - Best Actress; 1 GEMINI nomination - Best Supporting Actress; 1 REEL BLACK nomination - Best Actress
  • Sam Khalilieh is a seasoned actor, veteran of two Summerworks shows, whose stage credits are numerous as well as many film and TV credits.  He can currently be seen on stage in an amazing production of The Passion Play in Toronto
  • Christo Graham is an exciting newcomer making his Toronto stage debut.  He's also an accomplished musician and he and his band Folk Off will be doing cover versions of rock songs for the show
  • Sugith Varughese is an award-winning screenwriter of numerous hours of scripted TV, including 10 episodes of the Muppet series Fraggle Rock to episodes of the crime drama Blue Murder.  He won the first York Trillium Award for Most Promising Writer - Television and was appointed the first screenwriter-in-residence for the Toronto Public Library. He is also an actor with 75 credits in film, TV, stage and radio and an award-winning short film director.  He also taught scriptwriting and acting at the college level.

But we only get paid out of box office receipts for our show at Summerworks.  

Even if we had sold out houses, each share of the box office would be worth a little over $500 after our expenses are paid.  That's for four weeks of rehearsals and 7 performances during the festival. Not much. Not what artists of this calibre are worth.  They are all professionals and members of Canadian Actors Equity.  

IF this were a regular play, the actors, stage manager and director fees alone would be in excess of $20,000 - at union scale.  That's what these professionals are giving up to do this play.  But that's what doing a festival show means.  The artists give up the normal wage for a chance to do new work that they believe in.

Their passion, talent and commitment is worth more than the box office can provide. So all your contributions will go directly to them.  And we won't have to rely so much on the box office for our compensation.  

We are all excited to be doing this work and the production will be as professional as any regardless of what we get paid.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • You can get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • LIKE the Entitlement Facebook page
  • SHARE the link to this page and to our Facebook page
  • COME to the show! Tickets are only $15 and $11 of that goes to us.  Go to summerworks.ca for showtimes or tickets.

Indiegogo has share tools.  Please use them!

Late News from Europe

Recently, I learned that the play has been shortlisted by a prestigious theater in Belgium for translation and publication in French!  This is a tremendous vote of confidence in the script and I couldn't be more pleased the text travels across borders.

NEW!  Our S-T-R-E-T-C-H Goals are here!

STRETCH GOAL No. 1:  Colour programs among other things

We've raised our initial goal of $3000 which will be shared by the artists working on this show, but raising another $500 will enable us to provide colour programs, rather than the xeroxed black and white ones we had budgeted for.  As you can see from the photos included in the Gallery in this campaign, colour makes a difference!


STRETCH GOAL No. 2:  Brand new set furniture

Often with festival shows, the set is cobbled together from existing pieces or borrowed.  Giving us an extra $500 will give us the ability to purchase the right furniture, (I know it isn't much money for furniture, but thankfully, Ikea will provide some excellent pieces that will be new rather than used.)  The major set piece for the show is a portable white board that flips and that alone is $750 to buy.  The extra funds will enable us to make the show look as good as it can.


STRETCH GOAL No. 3:  Bonus stipends for the other artists

While the members of Canadian Actors Equity working on the show work for free, there are other artists, like the ridiculously talented assistant director, and the sound/projection designer who receive a small stipend rather than take the risk of sharing in the box office.  The extra funds will go to increase their stipend which, believe me, they've earned!

Thanks for contributing to "Entitlement at Summerworks 2013".  I'm utterly blown away with your generosity and kindness.

These stretch goals are designed to inspire us to make the best show we can and inspire YOU to share and cajole others who will take us over the top and make the show far better than we had expected it could be.  Tell your friends!  And come to the show and see how we've spent your contributions!

-Sugith Varughese
story_txt:
NEW:  Our S-T-R-E-T-C-H goals are here!  Scroll down...
UPDATE
We reached our goal with 28 days left in the campaign!  The amount we wanted to raise was modest and what we felt was attainable -- and we attained it!  The entire cast and company are SO grateful to our generous contributors.
All funds raised to our goal go to the artists
Even though we surpassed our goal, ALL the funds raised will still be shared by the artists -- the actors, director, stage manager and playwright of this show, who are all working for free and a share of the modest box office from this festival production.  Surpassing our goal means that we are that much less dependent on the box office for any compensation after rehearsing full time for a month followed by 7 performances over the 10 days of the festival.
Also indiegogo/paypal deducts 9% of your contribution as their fee.  So we really won't have attained our goal until we're 9% past it!
Now that we've achieved a small stipend for the amazing pros who are working on this show by making our original goal, we've set STRETCH goals to entice you to make this production even better than it was going to be.
Support a World Premiere!
My name is Sugith Varughese and I'm a produced film and television screenwriter and actor.  Now my first stage play has been accepted by the prestigious Summerworks Theatre Festival in Toronto!
It's a satire about the conflict between my generation and the millenials--the ones who came of age in 2000 and beyond.  It's called ENTITLEMENT.
In the play, an out of work screenwriter takes as job teaching scriptwriting to college kids.  When an ambitious student challenges his methods, the screenwriter has to fight for his job.  It's about the transformation of education to edutainment and the growing power of an entitled generation to assert their will--but at what cost?
As an out of work screenwriter (award-winning!--look me up on imdb.com or wikipedia.org), I taught scriptwriting courses at colleges and the play's inspired by my experiences.
It's funny.  And timely.  I'm thrilled the Summerworks jury thought enough of it to accept the play as part of the 2013 festival.
As fanastic as acceptance into the festival is, it means that I, as well as the director, the actors and other artists involved in the production only get paid from the box office receipts.  And the funds to produce the play must be raised by me.
Being my first play, I will do whatever it takes to produce it at Summerworks.
But I could use some help--which will go DIRECTLY to the actors, director and stage manager who are working for free to put on the play.  Instead of hoping for something out of the box office, once expenses like the props and set get paid for, YOUR HELP will give them some assurance that they aren't working for nothing.
They believe in the play and are donating their time and talent NOW.  Your contribution will modestly compensate them beyond what we might get from the box office during the festival.
A union-sanctioned show
The artist members of Canadian Actors' Equity, (the union for stage performers and directors), are working under a festival agreement, which gives them the opportunity to work for free in exchange for an artist share of the box office from the festival.  A fee is paid to CAEA to provide the artists with health insurance for the month leading up to the festival performances, (which must be recoupled from box office receipts, along with all the other expenses before the artists receive any monies.)  We are proud to be members of Equity and are grateful that the festival agreement enables Equity members to work on this kind of show and bring their high levels of professional standards to the production.


What We Need & What You Get
I hope I can raise at least $3000 which would be shared by:

3 cast members, Dora-winning actress Karen Robinson, seasoned veteran actor Sam Khalilieh and an exciting newcomer Christo Graham
the director, Dora-winning actor and director David Ferry
the stage manager, Michael Sinclair
the playwright and producer, Sugith Varughese (also an award-winning screenwriter and actor)

Besides supporting the premiere of Entitlement, your contribution will net you some pretty cool perks like:

a copy of the script, signed by the playwright
a copy of the band Folk Off's CD
access to the secret missing video of someone smoking crack on a Ford
drinks with the cast and playwright
private talkback after the show with the cast and playwright
a private dialogue class with acclaimed director David Ferry

as well as the knowledge that your contribution will help support the participation of some of Canada's best theatre artists in the premiere of Entitlement.
LAST MINUTE ADDITIONAL PERK:
ALL contributors will receive a link to a certain missing video of a really big guy possibly smoking something in front of a Ford... and singing the theme song to Entitlement.


What Your Contribution Means
Everyone has a story about encountering someone with a sense of entitlement.  It seems like entitlement is the product of our times.  That's what this play is about.
It's a searing satire about the conflict between generations.  We want the over-40 and the under-25 demographic to come.  We want generational brawls to break out in the aisles!  (Not really.)  We want people to either see themselves or see someone they recognize in this play.
Your contribution makes that possible.  The timeliness of this play means that it will have an impact on those who see it.  It's possible that this production may be the first of many, if the play's the success we believe it can be.
And the people behind this play aren't beginners.

Director David Ferry has been nominated ten times for DORA awards, winning three times: best actor, best director and a shared best lighting design. He has been nominated for Genie, Gemini and Canadian Comedy Awards, and has won a Nellie for best radio actor, and the inaugural Toronto Drama Critics award for best actor (Blasted.) He was the 2011 recipient of the Barbara Hamilton Award. He has a coveted Harold award.
Karen Robinson has 3 DORA nominations, 1 win - Best Actress; 1 STERLING win (Edmonton) - Best Actress;  Salento Int'l Film Festival (Italy) - Best Actress; NAACP Theatre Award - Best Ensemble; 1 BETTY nomination (Calgary) - Best Actress; 1 GEMINI nomination - Best Supporting Actress; 1 REEL BLACK nomination - Best Actress
Sam Khalilieh is a seasoned actor, veteran of two Summerworks shows, whose stage credits are numerous as well as many film and TV credits.  He can currently be seen on stage in an amazing production of The Passion Play in Toronto
Christo Graham is an exciting newcomer making his Toronto stage debut.  He's also an accomplished musician and he and his band Folk Off will be doing cover versions of rock songs for the show
Sugith Varughese is an award-winning screenwriter of numerous hours of scripted TV, including 10 episodes of the Muppet series Fraggle Rock to episodes of the crime drama Blue Murder.  He won the first York Trillium Award for Most Promising Writer - Television and was appointed the first screenwriter-in-residence for the Toronto Public Library. He is also an actor with 75 credits in film, TV, stage and radio and an award-winning short film director.  He also taught scriptwriting and acting at the college level.

But we only get paid out of box office receipts for our show at Summerworks.  
Even if we had sold out houses, each share of the box office would be worth a little over $500 after our expenses are paid.  That's for four weeks of rehearsals and 7 performances during the festival. Not much. Not what artists of this calibre are worth.  They are all professionals and members of Canadian Actors Equity.  
IF this were a regular play, the actors, stage manager and director fees alone would be in excess of $20,000 - at union scale.  That's what these professionals are giving up to do this play.  But that's what doing a festival show means.  The artists give up the normal wage for a chance to do new work that they believe in.
Their passion, talent and commitment is worth more than the box office can provide. So all your contributions will go directly to them.  And we won't have to rely so much on the box office for our compensation.  
We are all excited to be doing this work and the production will be as professional as any regardless of what we get paid.


Other Ways You Can Help
Some people can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

You can get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
LIKE the Entitlement Facebook page
SHARE the link to this page and to our Facebook page
COME to the show! Tickets are only $15 and $11 of that goes to us.  Go to summerworks.ca for showtimes or tickets.

Indiegogo has share tools.  Please use them!
Late News from Europe
Recently, I learned that the play has been shortlisted by a prestigious theater in Belgium for translation and publication in French!  This is a tremendous vote of confidence in the script and I couldn't be more pleased the text travels across borders.
NEW!  Our S-T-R-E-T-C-H Goals are here!

STRETCH GOAL No. 1:  Colour programs among other things
We've raised our initial goal of $3000 which will be shared by the artists working on this show, but raising another $500 will enable us to provide colour programs, rather than the xeroxed black and white ones we had budgeted for.  As you can see from the photos included in the Gallery in this campaign, colour makes a difference!

STRETCH GOAL No. 2:  Brand new set furniture
Often with festival shows, the set is cobbled together from existing pieces or borrowed.  Giving us an extra $500 will give us the ability to purchase the right furniture, (I know it isn't much money for furniture, but thankfully, Ikea will provide some excellent pieces that will be new rather than used.)  The major set piece for the show is a portable white board that flips and that alone is $750 to buy.  The extra funds will enable us to make the show look as good as it can.

STRETCH GOAL No. 3:  Bonus stipends for the other artists
While the members of Canadian Actors Equity working on the show work for free, there are other artists, like the ridiculously talented assistant director, and the sound/projection designer who receive a small stipend rather than take the risk of sharing in the box office.  The extra funds will go to increase their stipend which, believe me, they've earned!
Thanks for contributing to "Entitlement at Summerworks 2013".  I'm utterly blown away with your generosity and kindness.
These stretch goals are designed to inspire us to make the best show we can and inspire YOU to share and cajole others who will take us over the top and make the show far better than we had expected it could be.  Tell your friends!  And come to the show and see how we've spent your contributions!
-Sugith Varughese

story:
(Our video was recorded at the famous Hotel Utah Saloon open mic, where you will find Our Humble Composer haunting every Monday night.)
 
The Ape Woman, a new Rock Opera by San Francisco composer and performer May van Oskan, took the East Coast by storm in 2012. Now we're bringing it to the Bay, all we need is the silver platter to put it on.
 
We'll be performing at the indie theatre hub of downtown San Francisco, The Exit Theatre, for two weeks in June. Step into our after-hours circus tent and let us entertain and woo you.
 
This show moves like a freight train, as the harrowing true story of Victorian sideshow phenomenon Julia Pastrana is recounted by the four men who decided her sordid fate over 150 years ago. The backbone of the show are fourteen original songs, sung by one actress who portrays both Julia and her successor Marie Bartel. The pieces meander cleverly between sultry jazz ballad, classical requiem, and rock epic, supported by the complex vocal harmonies of three real-life sisters. Their voices, blended with their mother’s electric guitar and a band comprised of old hometown friends, creates a uniquely confident, almost telepathic fabric of sound.
 
Songwriter Jemima James remarked "DON'T MISS THIS SHOW - It's brilliant, captivating, ballbusting, heartbreaking. Bring your handerchiefs and go." The Ape Woman was featured in The Boston Globe last December, where we sold out Club Passim. Now we're bringing this ferocious tearjerker to the greatest city in the world.
 
We're reinventing our sound for our new space at the Exit Studio, but we still need to bring half our cast (at least five people) to San Francisco for two weeks! We need funding for airfare, theater rental, promotion, and supplies to keep our performers fed, happy, and looking fabulous for you.
 
We are ridiculously pleased to offer you sparkling rewards for your generosity! Original artwork by Hiller Goodspeed, Olivia Pattison, Alisa Javits, or Maury de Geofroy is yours for the asking, along with the original cast World Premiere recording from our very first run on Martha's Vineyard.
 
Even more famously, if you get your big wallet out (or team up with some friends with slightly smaller wallets), you can purchase the divine experience of a private house show, anywhere in the contiguous US, performed by Our Strange Diva May van Oskan and however many of her beloved costars she can drag along. Get out your fanciest pants and she'll compose and record a brand new song, just for you.
 
If we don't reach our goal, we're still going up-- it's up to you to decide how magnificent this show will be, and how broke we will go in producing it. It is our dream to create a sordid-yet-cozy Victorian living room in the snowglobe of your imagination, and only you will make this dream come true.
 
If we raise more than our target, we won't waste it! We're heading back to the East Coast in July to play a fabulously prestigious theatre festival, and the more we break even out here, the more terriffic (and possible) our next adventure will be. So feel free to be extra generous!
 
We're also recruiting our guerrilla publicity squadron. Got stilts? Wigs? Glitter-encrusted abandoned parade floats? The ability to distribute palm cards and adhere stickers in creative locales? Please like us and share us, and we'll share our stuff and like you right back. We love to make a scene, and would love if you would join us in full regalia.

story:
"Will Work For" Presented by terraNOVA Collective's 10th Annual soloNOVA Arts Festival. Unemployment and the adventure begins! On a journey into the unknown, Dacyl Acevedo has to dodge through booby-trapped interviews, face demons of her employment past, hold tight to her dream while surviving the economic crash. Will Work For is a farcical and satirical journey into the new world of work and tells of how one person is surviving. It's told through the art of storytelling, clown and spoken word physical theatre. World Premiere!

To purchase tickets: http://willworkfor.brownpapertickets.com/

9pm, May 25th / 7pm, May 28th / 1pm, June 1st

Dear friend,

As you may already know, I’ve been working on my solo show, Will Work For over a year now in collaboration with Tamilla Woodard. The show was selected for the 10th Annual soloNOVA Arts Festival with terraNOVA Collective for its’ world premiere!

The show is based on events in my life after getting laid off during the financial crisis of 2008 and explores the struggles I faced throughout my period of long-term unemployment.  Previously, I’d performed pieces of my original work in SOUL Latina with Latino Flavored Productions Inc., The Faith Project with Tamilla Woodard at Bowery Poetry Club and True Story Project: Faith with Visible Theatre. This is my first full-length solo performance that I’m self-producing.

I’ve been extremely fortunate to have enlisted the help of an amazing creative team: Jo Cattell, Direction; Nathaniel Nicco-Annan, Choreography; Marios Aristopoulos, Sound Design; Chris Marston, Video Projection Design; Heather Anderson, Costume Design, Photos & Illustrations. Right now, I’m in the middle of the rehearsal process and my creative team is inspiring me to discover new ideas for the show every day!

At this stage of development of the show, presenting a full production of the show for the first time in such a prestigious festival and giving my designers the support they need to do their work comes with increased costs that I’m simply not able to manage alone. For example, in addition to the material for the show, I’d like to have my Video Projection Designer videotape the performance for future development and promotion of the show. This won’t be possible without your financial support. Your donation would allow me to realize all the hard work that I’ve been doing for over a year now and showcase the extraordinary work crafted by my collaborators to its’ fullest potential. This will help to make the soloNOVA Festival just the first stop in the show’s ultimate on-going success.

Will Work For is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Will Work For must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. 

Thank you for your generous support.

Sincerely,

Dacyl Acevedo

 

To purchase tickets: http://willworkfor.brownpapertickets.com/

9pm, May 25th / 7pm, May 28th / 1pm, June 1st

@ IRT Theater, 154 Christopher St., buzzer 3B, between Washington & West St., New York, NY 10014

http://www.terranovacollective.org/solonova-2013.html

"This work was created in part through The Field Artist Residency program, supported by the Lambent Foundation"

story:
Hi!  My name is Connye Florance. I'm a professional vocalist (BET "Jazz Vocalist of the Year" 2000; SouthArts "Esteemed Southern Artist" 2006; Nashville Jazz Workshop Heritage Award for 'Artistic Excellence', 2013)  and actress  performing and promoting our national treasure  -  jazz. 

My team and I are working to raise $25,000.00 to cover 1/4 of our budget needs for artistic collaboration, community outreach and phase 2 re-boot for ,

"Jazz Rhapsody...A Southern Songbird's Tribute To The Legacy of Jazz"

OUR GOAL:  is to relaunch this "outstanding" show in spring of 2014 for our fans and friends in the Middle Tennessee Area then continue from there to collaborate with universities, colleges and community venues across the southeast in a series of mini-tours.

After premiering in Nashville in 2006, gaining superb audience response at all performance stops along the initial leg of our journey, including: Cumberland University, Hiawassee College, Wisconsin Lutheran College, Martin Methodist College and Indiana Wesleyan University, events forced us into hiatus in 2008. Now, we're back and working hard once again to "get this show on the road", sharing and honoring the musical legacy of artists like Duke Ellington, Bill Strayhorn, Billie Holiday, Alberta Hunter, Langston Hughes and others whose artistry helped shape our cultural landscape.

Your generous, tax-deductible contributions will help us keep jazz a living force within full reach of the next generation... by helping to put "Jazz Rhapsody...A Southern Songbird's Tribute To The Legacy of Jazz" back into the visible market - allowing us to showcase and collaborate with artists in other regions.  Your support will help put us in the places where college, university and community arts presenters go to find quality arts and cultural enhancement projects to bring to their students and surrounding communities.

AS THE CROWN JEWEL OF AMERICAN CULTURAL HERITAGE, JAZZ IS AN AMERICAN TREASURE~  WORTHY OF CELEBRATED HONOR, RENEWED COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND MARKET VISIBILITY.  Such is the seed and purpose of the"Jazz Rhapsody" Project.

Our goal is to redevelop and tour "Jazz Rhapsody..." in a series of short (3 month) celebration tours - engaging college, university and community performing arts groups in collaboration as we tour the show...ultimately expanding the outreach and impact of jazz music through this unique fusion of live jazz, spoken-word & theatre....  or 'jazz theatre' as we like to call it.

We need your help - to honor and promote the crown jewel of American cultural heritage...Jazz.  Help us grow our collaboration and outreach opportunities for

"Jazz Rhapsody...A Southern Songbird's Tribute To The Legacy of Jazz".

"A truly masterful performance, and equally masterful work of creative artistry."   
Lou Outlaw, Vanderbilt University; 
Board Member, National Museum of African American Music

What We Need & What You Get

  • We're seeking to raise 25,000.00 - approximately one fourth (1/4) of our redevelopment and touring budget - to cover costs related to creating collaboration, performance and showcasing opportunities. These costs include:
  • Updates to promotion and marketing materials, incl. videotaping & editing
  • Rehearsal space rental fees
  • Rehearsal/arranging fees to musicians
  • Administrative & production assistance fees
  • Showcasing and booth rental fees at regional and national conferences
  • Collaboration fees, incl. postage, travel to meetings, stipends
  • Laptop computer to service conference booths and administrative needs
  • Legal fees incl. publishing license renewal fees, contracts, etc.
        As THANKS for your generous contributions, you could receive:

  •  MP3s or CD of selections  from our "Jazz Rhapsody Live" premier recording
  • Colorful "Jazz Is..." T-shirt   or
  • DVD of our 2014 taping of the show.
  • We're confident you love and respect jazz and our artistry enough to help us reach our fundraising goal. But if we don't, we'll use the money to continue taking prioritized steps towards our purposed goal ... to promote and celebrate jazz heritage while collaborating with other artists through the Jazz Rhapsody Project.

The Impact

 Jazz is an impacting American legacy and national jewel. By donating to our project, you will be helping to put "Jazz Rhapsody" on the road, bringing live jazz, jazz heritage and artistic collaboration opportunities to a variety of communities, some of whom are largely under served in the area of accessible, quality arts programming ~ including many of our HBCU (Historically Black College and University) communities. With a fully funded budget,($100,000.00) we can take "Jazz Rhapsody" Project artistic collaboration and outreach to these and other such schools and under served communities at little or no cost to them.

  • We take pride in maintaining our reputation for artistic excellence!
  • Great reviews our first time out confirm we have an "absolutely outstanding" show worthy of support and visibility. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you don't have funds to contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help!

  • You can help us by scatting some noise about our campaign!! Skee~doo~be DO BE telling your friends!!
  •  Petition your favorite college or community dance ensemble, arts presenter or venue to partner with us!
  • Use the way-too-easy indiegogo share tools to help jazz up our efforts!

THANK YOU!
