COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND MARKET VISIBILITY.  Such is the seed and purpose of the"Jazz
Rhapsody" Project.Our goal is to redevelop and tour
"Jazz Rhapsody..." in a series of short (3 month) celebration tours - engaging college, university and community performing arts groups in
collaboration as we tour the show...ultimately expanding the outreach and impact of jazz music through this unique fusion
of live jazz, spoken-word & theatre....  or 'jazz theatre' as we like to call it.We need your help - to honor and promote the crown jewel of American cultural heritage...Jazz.  Help us grow our collaboration and outreach opportunities for "Jazz Rhapsody...A Southern Songbird's Tribute To The Legacy of Jazz"."A truly masterful performance, and equally masterful work of creative artistry."    Lou Outlaw, Vanderbilt University;  Board Member, National Museum of African American Music
What We Need & What You Get
We're seeking to raise 25,000.00 - approximately one fourth (1/4) of our redevelopment and touring budget - to cover costs related to creating collaboration, performance and showcasing opportunities. These costs include:
Updates to promotion and marketing materials, incl. videotaping & editing

Rehearsal space rental fees 
Rehearsal/arranging fees to musicians 

Administrative & production assistance fees

Showcasing and booth rental fees at regional and national conferences
Collaboration fees, incl. postage, travel to meetings, stipends
Laptop computer to service conference booths and administrative needs
Legal fees incl. publishing license renewal fees, contracts, etc.

        As THANKS for your generous contributions, you could receive: 
 MP3s or CD of selections  from our "Jazz Rhapsody Live" premier recording 

Colorful "Jazz Is..." T-shirt   or 

DVD of our 2014 taping of the show.
We're confident you love and respect jazz and our artistry enough to help us reach our fundraising goal. But if we don't, we'll use the money to continue taking prioritized steps towards our purposed goal ... to promote and celebrate jazz heritage while collaborating with other artists through the Jazz Rhapsody Project.

The Impact Jazz is an impacting American legacy and national jewel. By donating to our project, you will be helping to put "Jazz
Rhapsody" on the road, bringing live jazz, jazz heritage and artistic collaboration opportunities to a variety of communities, some of whom are largely under served in the area of accessible, quality arts programming ~ including many of our HBCU (Historically Black College and University) communities. With a fully funded budget,($100,000.00) we can take "Jazz Rhapsody" Project artistic collaboration and outreach to these and other such schools and under served communities at little or no cost to them.
We take pride in maintaining our reputation for artistic excellence!
Great reviews our first time out confirm we have an "absolutely outstanding" show worthy of support and visibility.  

Other Ways You Can HelpEven if you don't have funds to contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help!
You can help us by scatting some noise about our campaign!! Skee~doo~be DO BE telling your friends!! 

 Petition your favorite college or community dance ensemble, arts presenter or venue to partner with us!

Use the way-too-easy indiegogo share tools to help jazz up our efforts!
THANK YOU!

story:
Why We Are Here

Nine years ago I saw Nick Whitby's play "To the Green Fields Beyond" directed by Sam Mendes at the Donmar Warehouse and fell immediately in love with it.

Back then I was a busy actress toying with the idea of becoming a theatre director. A few years later, through passion, motivation and hard work, I established myself as an exciting new director committed to promoting fresh ideas, new writing, and talented actors. Since falling in love with ‘Green Fields’, I read the play at least once a year, trying to figure out how I could produce it so that the Italian audiences could discover and fall in love with it like I did.

Although I didn’t have a producer or a production company behind me, I was determined to secure the rights to the play in the hope to share ‘Green Fields’ with the Italian audiences. So I contacted the play’s author, Nick Whitby (through his company True West), and thanks to his support I was able to secure the rights for 3 years. Francesca Silveri and I translated and adapted the play, which received Nick’s seal of approval. He thinks an Italian production of his wonderful play would be very interesting indeed. I have looked for a production company who would share my passion and with the means to bring my artistic vision of ‘Green Fields’ to the stage for the past 3 years, but I’ve not found it yet.

Mine is not only a case of financial limitation. The Italian theatrical panorama is very different from the one in the UK. Big venues can afford to pay for expensive productions (which includes buying the rights to the plays), reserving the right to any artistic decision. This, more often than not, limits creativity and certainly does not allow emerging directors to prove their worth. Because of the difficulties involved in this process, all the big theatres in Italy often stage the Classics. It’s down to the people who love the theatre to change this trend that is eating away, or even obliterating, Italy’s artistic heart.

The rights are about to expire but I decided that since I began this endavour on my own, I will also see it through on my own. Nick Whitby and Rachel Fisher from True West have given me extraodirnay support over the past 3 years. The same can be said about Francesca Silveri and all the actors who have been behind me in my search for a production company. They've followed the ups and downs without ever losing hope that sooner, rather than later, I will be able to stage a production of this beautiful play.

Georgia Lepore (Director)

 

What We Need* 

Daily Production Costs (Artistic) :

Cast:  11 members      Gross: 75                       Total   825

Public Liability Ins. and National Ins.                            318

SIAE (copyright for the play and music and public

performance fees)                                                         99

Daily Production Costs (Technical):

Technicians:  3 members   75                             Total   225

Public Liability Ins. and National Ins.                              87

Theatre/Studio Theatre rental                                       550

Daily Total         2140

Stage Production Costs:

Costumes                                                                      900

Rehearsal Space                                                         1500

Promotional material                                                      300

Scenery/Set Design                                                       200

Total       2900

*(all amounts in Euros)

 

If You Can't Donate — You Can Still Help!

Whether or not you are able to contribute to this campaign, you are in a position to help us reach (or surpass!) our goal. Please spread the word about our show and campaign using whatever social media and other tools you have available.

Remember: Every dollar you help raise through your friends, family, Twitter followers and contacts in general, is as if you had donated it yourself.

                                   

Perchè Siamo Qui

Nove anni fa al Donmar Warehouse di Londra ho visto questo bellissimo testo di Nick Whitby con la regia di Sam Mendes e me ne sono innamorata. L'ho letto e riletto, anno dopo anno, pensando a come produrlo in modo che anche in Italia potessero conoscerlo e innamorarsene come me.

Nel 2009, da sola, senza una produzione alle spalle, mi sono messa in contatto con lo stesso Whitby tramite il suo legale Rachel Fisher, e con il loro prezioso supporto ho chiuso un accordo che mi ha dato l'esclusiva del testo in Italia per 3 anni. La traduzione fatta con  Francesca Silveri ha ottenuto la piena approvazione di Nick (che ama molto l'Italia, e sarebbe felicissimo di vedere il suo testo rappresentato in italiano) e ha raccolto le adesioni degli attori del mio "cast ideale" (potete vederlo nella "Gallery"), riempiendomi di gioia e entusiasmo.

Ho passato gli ultimi 3 anni a cercare una produzione adeguata all'importanza del testo. Ne ho anche trovate, ma per un motivo o per l'altro non abbiamo mai chiuso. Tanti complimenti, tanto interesse, tanto supporto e incoraggiamento, ma niente produzione; "troppi attori", pare. Tutti pronti a ospitare lo spettacolo nei loro teatri ma non a produrlo.

I diritti stanno per scadere ma io ho deciso: ho cominciato da sola e andrò avanti da sola. Amo troppo questo progetto e le persone che ne fanno parte per lasciarmi scoraggiare dagli ingranaggi dell'obsoleta macchina produttiva italiana. Il supporto di Nick e di Rachel in questi anni è stato eccezionale, come quello di Francesca e di tutti gli attori che hanno seguito con me le vicissitudini produttive non perdendo mai le speranze di mettere in scena questo bellissimo testo.

Spero vogliate aiutarci anche voi. Un vostro contributo, anche minimo, sarà importantissimo per noi. Tanti piccoli, singoli, passi, compongono un lungo cammino.

Georgia

 

La Storia Che Vogliamo Raccontare

"To the Green Fields Beyond (Oltre I Verdi Campi)" di Nick Withby, autore inglese contemporaneo, è andato in scena per la prima volta al Donmar Warehouse di Londra, con la regia di Sam Mendes e la partecipazione tra gli altri di Dougray Scott, Ray Winstone e Hugh Dancy. Basato su fatti reali e ambientato durante la Grande Guerra, il testo racconta la storia dell'equipaggio multietnico di un carro armato inglese, la notte prima di un attacco in territorio francese. Gli otto uomini, capeggiati dal carismatico Tenente Child, vengono a conoscenza di qualcosa che li porterà a discutere tutta la notte tra loro per prendere una decisione cruciale: fare il loro dovere e morire, oppure disertare e salvarsi. Ognuno di essi porta nel confronto il proprio vissuto, la propria filosofia, la propria religione; offrendo così sulla vita, la morte e la guerra punti di vista diversissimi tra loro ma estremamente attuali nella ricerca di un "senso" a tutto questo. A dare ulteriori elementi di attualità al testo è la presenza di un giornalista americano, giunto sul fronte in cerca della "grande verità" sulla guerra. E’ una voce fuori dal coro, la voce della "giovane" America (non entrata ancora nel conflitto) contrapposta a quella della "vecchia" Europa, e in questa ricerca si scontrerà non poco con la realtà della prima linea e degli uomini che la vivono. I "campi verdi" del titolo rappresentano per i protagonisti una sorta di soglia da varcare, una meta che li aspetta e che rappresenta il loro destino, l’ultimo luogo da attraversare sulla terra, un luogo di morte proiettato verso un "oltre" sconosciuto, oltre il campo di battaglia. "Green Fields" è infatti il termine che indica la fine dell’ultima esercitazione dell’equipaggio, e la frase "To the green fields beyond" risuona prima dell’epilogo come un comando militare pronunciato insieme da tutti e otto gli uomini. Una speranza di vita cui fa riferimento il colore verde, contrapposto al marrone del fango da cui provengono, e al rosso del sangue attraverso cui devono passare. Ciascun membro dell’equipaggio infatti, indossa una fascia intorno al braccio di colore marrone, rosso e verde il cui significato verrà svelato solo alla fine dell'opera.

 

Come Potete Aiutarci - Come Vi Ringraziamo

Se volete potete aiutarci con delle donazioni per le quali, oltre alla nostra eterna gratitudine, vi ringrazieremo tutti aggiungendo il vostro nome nella Costellazione dei Grazie* e con:

Campo d'Addestramento  $10 (7,56 euro)

Soldato Semplice     $ 25 (18,91 euro)

La locandina autografata dagli attori e 2 biglietti omaggio per una sera a scelta dopo il debutto.

Primo Luogotente     $ 100 (75,65 euro)

La locandina autografata dagli attori, il DVD dello spettacolo e 2 biglietti omaggio per la sera del debutto.

Generale di Brigata   $ 1000 (756,53 euro)

La locandina autografata dagli attori, il DVD dello spettacolo, la T-shirt ufficiale dello spettacolo, 2 biglietti omaggio per la sera del debutto e la qualifica di Produttore sui credits.

*(proiezione che concluderà lo spettacolo: un cielo costellato dei vostri nomi per dire a tutti "grazie di cuore")

Se non potete donare, potete comunque aiutarci a promuovere la nostra campagna condividendola con i vostri contatti Facebook, Twitter o mail.

La diffusione è importante quanto le donazioni. Anche il tempo che ci dedicate è prezioso per noi.

Grazie di cuore,
Georgia

story:
Who is Ann Coulter?

Broken Glass proudly presents the world-premiere production of ANN, OR OTHER PEOPLE, a psychodrama/fantasia that follows Ann Coulter's quest to find a life of meaning and purpose after the dissolution of her media career. Written by Jonathan Mayer and directed by Taylor Tobin, this hilarious, cutting, satirical and bizarre new play takes an in-depth look into the mind of everyone's favorite political pundit. When the cameras are gone and the make-up comes off, just who is the real Ann Coulter?


ANN, OR OTHER PEOPLE opens October 20th, 2011 at the Access Theater - 380 Broadway at the corner of White St.


Starring: Vinny Anand, Lilly DeForest, Alan Tyson and Kendra Leigh Landon

with: Jenni Lawton, Bridget McMillan, and Amanda Savan


executive producer: Kate Moran

producer: Nathan Zebedeo

musical director: Alex Goley

choreographer: Ani Niemann

set design: Jenn Tash

light design: Adele Rylands

costumes: Erin Frumet


Check back often for photos, videos and more!

Where Your Money Goes

$10 = 30 minutes of rehearsal time
$25 = Fireguard license
$50 = 1 fantastic blonde wig
$75 = 100 programs
$100 = 3 costume pieces
$150 = A/V equipment
$200 = 100 posters
$250 = 1/2 of the cost for rental insurance
$500 = 1/4 of our total theatre rental costs for performances

Who is BROKEN GLASS?

BROKEN GLASS is a company of collaborative theatre artists. Using classic texts as our inspiration, we seek to create new and original works that address and illuminate today's pressing sociopolitical issues. Our goal is to provide audiences with an extremely relevant theatre experience. We believe that our work is only as good as the conversation it provokes. And we can only start the conversation with your help!

The Director: Taylor Tobin is a Brooklyn-based theater and performance artist.  A 2009 graduate of the Tisch School of the Arts/Playwrights Horizons Theater School, she currently serves as the co-artistic director of Broken Glass.  Since graduation, she has been involved in projects at the Public Theater, the Ontological-Hysteric Theater, the Bushwick Starr and Performance Space 122.  ANN, OR OTHER PEOPLE is her directorial debut with Broken Glass; past directing credits include JESUS CHRIST SUPERSTAR, HAMLETMACHINE, EVERY AFTERNOON (A DIALOGUE), and the staged workshop reading of ANN, OR OTHER PEOPLE. 
The Writer: Jonathan Mayer is a writer, videographer, and arts educator. He has directed plays with Dance Theatre Etcetera and taught in schools and community centers throughout Brooklyn. Other plays include Mother Goose and SouthTube Two.

Other Ways You Can Help

Any and all support is greatly appreciated. Spread the word about Broken Glass and ANN, OR OTHER PEOPLE! Stay connected via Facebook, Twitter, our website and mailing list. (Links below) And come see ANN opening October 20th - tickets on sale now!

story:
About

Lancaster City Unstoppables is a dance and drill team that activates the young minds, provides an outlet for the youth to be creative, brings the community together and the happiness of self-expression.

Our Program

Lancaster City Unstoppables (LCU) is a youth program that gives children in our communities an opportunity to come together and celebrate, collaborate and be part of a meaningful experience that will unite our community. LCU is directed and founded by, Vincent Smith, and offers dance, mentoring and smmer program. LCU goal is to rearrange how our youth view their lives by allowing them to activate their creative process. The drill team will be held at the Crispus Attacks Center in Lancaster, PA and will run from May thru September, with the plans to add a summer camp. 

Contribution

We need your help! Your generous contribution will provide equipment and uniforms. Please help provide our youth with the opportunity to express themselves creatively and learn skills that will empower them to become active participants in creating a better society. Let our youth know you care and value their creative expression and continued growth.

Any and all funds raised will go towards Lancaster City Unstoppables.

Impact

By contributing to LCU, you can change a life! Youth who are confident in themselves and participate in an extracurricular activity have a lower incident of negative influences.

 

Cant Tribute

Help us get the word out!

Share on your Facebook and Twitter!

Tell your friends and family!

Contribution
We need your help! Your generous contribution will provide equipment and uniforms. Please help provide our youth with the opportunity to express themselves creatively and learn skills that will empower them to become active participants in creating a better society. Let our youth know you care and value their creative expression and continued growth.
Any and all funds raised will go towards Lancaster City Unstoppables.


Impact
By contributing to LCU, you can change a life! Youth who are confident in themselves and participate in an extracurricular activity have a lower incident of negative influences.
 
Cant Tribute
Help us get the word out!
Share on your Facebook and Twitter!
Tell your friends and family!

story:
About COWBOY MOUTH 

by Sam Shephard & Patti Smith

Two misfits, Slim and Cavale, are holed up in what seems to be a basement apartment. Cavale has kidnapped Slim from his wife and child with big plans to turn him into a Rock Star. Cowboy Mouth is Sam Shepard's most auto-biographical play and was written with Patti Smith at the Chelsea Hotel. This production starts off as a party and transforms into a visceral, immersive performance equipped with drinks and live music.  

This production is a benefit for the historical Paul Robeson Theater in Ft. Greene, Brooklyn. All box office proceeds will help bring the Paul Robeson Theater back to life with hopes to expand its audience within the Brooklyn community.

Directed by Mark Gallagher

With Cory Michael Kosel, Lisa Jill Anderson and Marco de Ornella

April 25 at 8pm

April 26 at 8pm

April 27 at 11pm

Location: The Paul Robeson Theater (40 Greene Ave, Brooklyn, NY)

Your Donation Will Help Us....

  • Purchase necessary props and costume pieces ($200)
  • Cover the cost of production rights ($300)

About the Paul Robeson Theater

It is the mission of Brooklyn’s historical Paul Robeson Theater to enrich and strengthen the community through art, culture and education. The theater provides an accessible and open forum for creative expression and showcases a versatile array of innovative work that reflects the legacy of Paul Robeson himself.

 

*"Cowboy Mouth" is presented by special arrangement with SAMUEL FRENCH, Inc.

story:
Play your part in celebrating outstanding achievements in the promotion and development of dance from Africa and its Diaspora in the UK!

 

The Project

Taking place on 22 February 2013 in the creative hub of London’s Clerkenwell district, the 2nd ADAD Lifetime Achievement Award ceremony will showcase the achievements of six nominees for the award all of whom have made a monumental contribution to the British cultural offer.   Will the winner be Carol Straker, Namron, Peter Badejo, Imani Jendai, Nii Tagoe, or Mark Elie?  All will be revealed on the evening of February 22nd. 

The Organisation

ADAD is a national arts charity that supports the practice and appreciation of dance of the African Diaspora.  We want dance of the African Diaspora to be visible and valued as part of the British cultural experience.  ADAD has a unique role, working on behalf of talented dance artists who are part of the African Diaspora, to support their development and raise the profile of their work.

ADAD exists to:

  • Enable artists through continuing professional development.
  • Develop new pathways to a sustainable future through education and training.
  • Build networks through hosting events and sharing information.
  • Foster pride in dance of the African Diaspora through celebrating heritage.

 

Project needs

In order to make this event the best that it can be we hope to raise £1,000.  100% of your contribution will be used to fund these event production costs:

  • Marketing material
  • Award trophy and cash prize
  • Photographic documentation
  • Catering
  • Flowers and room dressings
  • Miscellaneous event costs

 

The Impact

The contribution made by individuals specialising in Africa Diaspora dance to the arts world has been largely overlooked.  ADAD’s Lifetime Achievement Award aims to counter this reality.  By donating to this event you are investing in addressing this invisibility and ensuring that the pool of human knowledge keeps growing to boot!

 

Other ways you can help

  • Spread the word through Facebook, Twitter and good old fashioned word of mouth.
  • Volunteer to be a part of the event delivery team on 22 February.  Simply email paula@adad.org.uk

 

Thank you in advance for all your assistance and generous contributions.

story:
UPDATE 10/3/2014: We have hit our Indiegogo goal  with 5 days left in our campaign. With additional funds raised, we will be able to expand the current reach of the program, with a goal of creating even more intensive free dance training opportunities for  our All-Stars who are transitioning into high school. Donate today to help us provide more kids with more training!


All About the DwC All-Stars

The Dancing with Class (DwC) All-Stars program provides professional ballroom dance instruction and performance opportunities to middle school students from across Chicago, with an emphasis on reaching kids who live in under-resourced communities. As schools continue to face budget cuts and closures, innovative programs that provide social support and development are increasingly urgent. The DwC All-Stars offers a unique solution by expanding access to an art form and social activity that inherently builds leadership skills, self-confidence and tolerance.

“Dancing helps me make friends,” says 12-year-old Fernando O. (pictured at right with dance partner Ria). “A lot of kids ask me “how do you do it? How do you do the steps?” and I say, “It’s easy. I’ll teach you.”

Fernando and his fellow All-Stars would not be dancing today if it weren’t for the Dancing with Class program. Now is your chance to inspire a new generation of dancers to dream big and achieve excellence.


What Your Contribution Achieves

The All-Stars have many ambitions for the year ahead. Your contribution will help them achieve the following:

•  Entering their first-ever large-scale dance competition

•  Performing at Chicago Summerdance and the Chicago Children’s Book Fair

•  Attending and Performing in the 2015 Salsa Congreso

•  New costumes, new choreography, new performance opportunities

•  Creating additional dance scholarship opportunities for high school students

All contributions go directly to support the training and development of kids in the program. In 2014, supporters will be invited to participate in many special performance and workshop opportunities involving the All-Stars throughout the year. Supporters will also be invited to join the Dancing with Class team for a night of star treatment at the “Glow for It!” Gala on October 4.


    The Impact

    Most DwC All-Stars have been participants in the Dancing with Class – Core Program, which serves 60+ CPS elementary schools each year. As a whole, Dancing with Class has introduced social dance to approximately 25,000 Chicago youth since 2007. More than 100 students have gone on to participate as Dancing with Class All-Stars since 2012. With your help, we can continue to expand the reach and provide talented and motivated kids with the support they need to find joy and achieve success both on the dance floor and in their daily lives.

    “I see our All Stars unite across social groups and differences, master complicated material, gain confidence, become leaders, and develop discipline,” says Artistic Director Chris Van Houten. “But most of all I see our All Stars discovering joy through social dance, and I am so proud to help bring joy to these very special young dancers.”


    Other Ways You Can Help

    Whether or not you are able to make a monetary contribution, you can play an important role in helping the Dancing with Class All-Stars achieve their goals. A great way to help is to share links to this campaign page with your networks. An email to friends with a link to this campaign is especially helpful. You can also share the link via Facebook, Twitter and other Social Media.

    Please also consider attending one of our special events during the month of September to meet some of the All-Stars and provide moral support as they prepare to reach their performance goals for the 2014-15 school year.

    Thanks for your support – Let’s Glow for It!

story:
We are Latricia Davidson, Emmanuel Elpenord, Vera Khodasevich, Eunjung Lee, Django Palty, Cristina Pitter, Kirill Sheynerman, and Schylar Westbrook. Together, we are the graduating 2012 class of Bachelor in Fine Arts actors from Brooklyn College, City University of New York.

 

On April 16, 2012 we will host our Acting Showcase. Having spent the last four years in intensive training, we are ready to start our professional careers. Launching our futures begins with the people we know and the connections we make. This showcase provides us with the opportunity to introduce ourselves and our creative work to members of the theater, film, and television industry of New York. Our showcase is the first step of many on our path towards expanding our professional network to create a successful future as actors.

 

During this campaign, we need to raise $3000. Presenting the showcase in a prime location that encourages and facilitates industry attendance is vital to our success. We're delighted that we'll be performing in a theatre space on Theatre Row, which is located in the heart of Times Square; most of the funds raised will go towards the costs of renting this space. Other costs include materials for publicizing, as well as catering costs (light food and beverages) for the three performances on April 16.

 

By donating to our campaign you will be directly involved in the creation of a fantastic showcase. And of course you're invited to come and see our performances as well! After all the preparations and rehearsing, it is sure to be a great show!

story:
Hi everyone! I’m Dasha Lavrennikov.

I am a dancer and choreographer,  who was born in Russia, grew up and trained on the East Coast of the U.S (at Concord Acadmey and Connecticut College), and is currently based in Sevilla, Spain. 

I have recently received a great honor:   I am one of 65 artists selected to receive a danceWEB scholarship, out of an applicant pool of over 1023 dancers and choreographers worldwide. It's a very important recognition of my work as an emerging artist in contemporary dance and a life-changing opportunity for me. 

 

DanceWEB is essentially a 5-week week residency program, within the frame of ImPulsTanz - Vienna international Dance Festival, taking place in July/August. 


It allows 65 young professional dancers and choreographers from a diversity of countries and backgrounds the possibility to continue an intense multinational professional training program while being provided with space, time, resources and mentorship to develop and exhibit their artistic work in the field of Contemporary Dance and Performance. Moreover it provides the opportunity to develop important networks with artists from all over the world. ImPulsTanz is the largest international Dance Festival in Europe, and thus one of the best places to develop future international collaborations and networking for young artists.  Two artistic mentors and renowned international choreographers Benoît Lachambre & Robin Poitras, will facilitate our choreographic work.  Impulsetanz is essentially a gathering of creative thinkers, performers, dancers, teachers, and theorists in the fields of contemporary dance and performances. 

 

Participating in the danceWEB program is a tremendous opportunity for me, providing space, time and mentorship for artistic exploration, collaboration and growth. I will share the artistic work I create and the knowledge gathered with my local dance communities upon my return, with the hopes of promoting further cultural and artistic exchange.


Why do I need to raise money if I have already been awarded a scholarship??

Dear friends I am asking for your support to make this dance project possible for me. In order to participate in this danceWEB programme this summer 2012, I need to secure 1/3 of the scholarship ($ 2,850).  The European Commission as well as several Austrian funding organizations will fund the remaining 2/3 of the expenses. In addition to the tuition cost, I will be providing my own personal funding for airfare and meal expenses for the duration of 5 weeks. 

There are very few resources for emerging artists and their professional development in the US, as well as in Spain where I currently live.

Therefore I must rely on private donations from family, friends, and wonderful supporters like you.

This funding needs to be provided by July 1st, 2012.

Thus I am in need of $2850 to cover my expenses and make this project a reality. With your support I will be able to complete the amount needed so that I can attend danceWEB this summer!!!

Any amount you can contribute helps!

Please feel free to spread the word about this campaign to anyone you know and think would be interested in helping me out.

Thankyou so much for your time and support! 

 

A bit about me: 

I am a young artist committed to and interested in working outside of the commercialized arts sector, using the creative and performance process to explore, reflect on, question and comment on issues and themes that touch our contemporary society and the human being in its diversity.  I am interested in inventing alternative realities on stage as well as through interventions in urban spaces through the use of poetic multi-sensorial languages that allow us to communicate, collaborate with, and provoke the audience as well as those engaged in the creative process. 

Over the past few years I have been fortunate to get to work and play creating, collaborating, and performing in diverse international projects in France, Spain, Denmark, Russia, Germany, Peru, Colombia, Brazil, India and the United States.  I have witnessed and experienced how the artistic process transforms lives and communities; the creative process allows each and every human being (who participates as performer or active spectator) to explore, express, communicate and generate a dialogue between our inner subjective and outer objective worlds.  

What moves and shakes me up? How can we explore and transcend dominant social structures, represenations and images of the body, and the culture of fear and anxiety within our contemporary society through dance and performance processes?

Let’s mutually enter into a constantly conscious state of questioning, transgression, and intercommunication: provoking emotions and using bodies as a point of interaction, points of departure, a permeable quality that exchanges energy, intelligence, sensations, and narratives.

 I am diving into an exploration of how to use my creative artistic process to transform dominant vertical social relations into horizontal spaces of critically conscious playful and rebellious exchange: here movement, touch, breath and voice allows one to permeate frontiers of the body, sharing and exchanging energy, meaning, and sense of humanity. 

 

Alongside the creative process, productions, and artistic collaborations, I am committed to developing methods and techniques to provide what I believe to be a pertinent experimental performing arts education to children, adolescents and adults. I am concerned with increasing access to quality performing arts education in particular in respects to marginalized populations in cities/towns.  Over the last years I have witnessed how dance , physical theater, and performance practices develop body mind awareness, our human creative empathetic capacities, as well as our multi-sensorial somatic capacities. Building and developing self esteem and our sense of solidarity through performing arts practices we are able to exchange experiences, knowledge and our diverse visions of the world through our multiples intelligences and generic human creative capacity to respond our environment and struggle for human dignity, regardless of how oppressive, disfunctional, and fractured this reality may be.



Here is the break down of what I'm receiving as part of danceWeb. You'll see what an incredible gift and honor this is for an emerging choreographer like me!

  • Individual coaching by the danceWEB artistic mentors Benoît Lachambre (CA) & Robin Poitras (CA)
  • Participation in the research projects of ImPulsTanz 2012 (ProSeries and CoachingProjects)
  • Participation in the technique workshops of ImPulsTanz 2012 
  • Free Admission to all performances of ImPulsTanz 2012
  • Free Accommodation in Vienna for the period of the Scholarship Programme (single or double room)
  • Free Access to approx. 300 awarded dance film videos as well as to screenings of documentations and to the dance film productions of artists and companies who perform at the ImPulsTanz
  • Exchange of ideas and contact with the international teachers and choreographers of ImPulsTanz 2012
  • Lecture demonstrations & talks
  • Special projects exclusively offered to danceWEB scholarship holders
  • representation in the yearly growing, international danceWEB-database at www.jardindeurope.eu

story:
The Company

Founded in 2008, theatre re- creates and produces strong visual and physical theatre shows on the edge of mime and theatre. (www.retheatre.fr)

 

The Show

“I possess that rare quality among gamblers; I always know when to stop. It’s only fair to warn you before we begin.”

The Gambler is the story of a man forever reliving one decisive moment. Edgar spends all his time at the green table, imagining what a spin of the wheel could bring. A chance meeting with a woman reminds him of a world outside the game and suddenly he has a choice to make. Dreams and reality are the stakes in this beautifully staged, engaging and evocative new production by theatre re-.

 

The Impact

This production is supported by Arts Council England and Haringey Council (north London, UK). Our project addresses exclusion of individuals from the community as a result of addiction. We will focus on gambling as a metaphor for all addictions. Part of our development process involves opening a meaningful dialogue, through feedback sessions after regular showings, with members of the community, particularly in relation to societal problems stemming from addiction.

We want to give our audience the highest standard of everything and we want to bring in as many members of the public as possible, especially those who don’t see much theatre.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The Gambler will be shown at The Space on the Isle of Dogs (London, UK) from 15th-26th November 2011. We are a strong artistic team with a great story to tell but we need a little help from you to complete our budget. Donations will contribute mainly towards production costs (transportation, costume, set), marketing costs (flyers,  posters and e-newsletters) and administrative costs (postage, insurance).

 

For $10, you will get a signed flyer of the show and regular updates on our progress.

For $20, you will get to meet the cast after the show, a signed flyer of the show, and regular updates on our progress.

For $50, you will get your name on the program in the special thanks, to meet the cast after the show, a signed flyer, and regular updates on our progress.

For $100, you will get your name on theatre re’s website as an associate producer for The Gambler, a signed poster of the show, your name on the program in the special thanks, to meet the cast after the show, and regular updates on our progress.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

The most helpful thing you can do for us is to come and see our work! Beyond that, if you are able and willing please help us to promote The Gambler through word of mouth, Facebook, Twitter and any other way you can possibly think of.

 

The Team

Guillaume Pigé is an actor, director, mime and magician. He is the founder and artistic director of the company theatre re-, which produces strong visual shows on the edge of mime and theatre. Guillaume has toured work in Ireland (Dublin), France (Lyon, Paris, Avignon) and the UK (London, Edinburgh). In London, Guillaume trained and worked with companies and theatre directors such as Le Théâtre de l’Ange Fou, Simon McBurney of Complicité, Bill Gaskill and Andrew Visnesvski.

Adam Taylor is a writer and main collaborator on The Gambler. He has written scripts through collaboration with actors, musicians, directors and other writers, as well as in isolation. His plays have been staged in theatres including Soho Theatre, Watford Palace and The Unicorn as well as the Latitude Festival.

Alex Judd is the composer and musician on The Gambler. Alex writes extensively for dance and drama projects, most recently having composed music for performances at The Roundhouse, The Place, Artsdepot, The Cochrane Theatre and Lauderdale House.

Tugba Tamer is a freelance dancer and performer and part of the cast on The Gambler. Born in Istanbul (Turkey) she began her ballet training at the age of 7. She then formally began her artistic career as an actress at the National Theatre of Istanbul at age 13, where she took part in numerous theatre plays for the six following years. She later completed her Drama and Dance studies along with methods such as Alexander Technique, Stanislavski and Meyerhold's biomechanics. She just completed her 3-year diploma in Corporeal Mime at the London International School of Corporeal Mime. Tugba is also actively developing and promoting Art events in the UK.

Lighting design by Pierre Gouverneur

Costume design by Noëlle Claude
story_txt:
The Company

Founded in 2008, theatre re- creates
and produces strong visual and physical theatre shows on the edge of mime and
theatre. (www.retheatre.fr)
 
The Show
“I possess that rare quality among gamblers; I always
know when to stop. It’s only fair to warn you before we begin.”
The Gambler is the story of a man
forever reliving one decisive moment. Edgar spends all his time at the green
table, imagining what a spin of the wheel could bring. A chance meeting
with a woman reminds him of a world outside the game and suddenly he has a
choice to make. Dreams and reality are the stakes in this beautifully staged,
engaging and evocative new production by theatre re-.
 
The Impact
This production is supported by Arts Council England
and Haringey Council (north London, UK). Our project addresses exclusion of
individuals from the community as a result of addiction. We will focus on
gambling as a metaphor for all addictions. Part of our development process
involves opening a meaningful dialogue, through feedback sessions after regular
showings, with members of the community, particularly in relation to societal
problems stemming from addiction.
We want to give our audience the highest standard of
everything and we want to bring in as many members of the public as possible,
especially those who don’t see much theatre.
 
What We
Need & What You Get
The Gambler will be shown at The
Space on the Isle of Dogs (London, UK) from 15th-26th November 2011. We are a
strong artistic team with a great story to tell but we need a little help from
you to complete our budget. Donations will contribute mainly towards production
costs (transportation, costume, set), marketing costs (flyers,  posters
and e-newsletters) and administrative costs (postage, insurance).

regular updates on our progress.

story:
If we reach our $2,000 goal, an anonymous donor has agreed to match $1,000 of the total raised!

- Help us reach $2,000, and your gift will be matched 50%!   

So, what's the deal?

An Evening With Kirk Douglas is really two darkly comedic one-act plays: The Death of Kirk Douglas and Kirk Douglas Goes to Heaven, both of which were written by Katherine Maughan. They'll have their worldwide premiere as part of the New York International Fringe Festival (FringeNYC) this August - very exciting!

Kerry McGuire (UCB), is directing, and we have a truly fantastic cast, including: Winston Noel (ESPN), Morgan Jarrett (The Today Show), Brian Faas (Vh1), Brandon Scott Jones (UCB), Austin Rye (The Jerry Springer Show), and Chrissie Gruebel (Comedians for Change).
 
We've also got Anna Kowalczuk as Stage Manager, Ellena Chmielewski as our Costume Designer, and Claire Ayoub as our Producer. 
 
The show is going to be really, really good, because all of these people are really, really, REALLY good!

And what's the show about?

When high-strung Maisie Kingsley and her husband, Walter, embark on a trip to celebrate their first wedding anniversary, they don’t plan to hit anyone with their car. But after killing an old man in a hit & run, (the victim also happens to be the legendary actor Kirk Douglas), the couple are forced to confront the secrets they’ve hid from each other, their panic in the face of a manslaughter, and the body that’s now laying in a motel bathroom.

Meanwhile, an overworked Saint Peter mans the gates of Heaven on the day of Kirk Douglas’s scheduled arrival. Joined by a frustrated Jesus, a demanding God, an earnest Evangelical, a stripper, and more, Peter must struggle to survive the day and give Kirk Douglas the Heavenly welcome he deserves.

The show is appearing at La MaMa's 99-seat First Floor Theatre (74A East 4th Street), from August 10-26th, 2012 ... which means it's getting so close you guys, so close! 

What are you spending my money on?

Mostly cheesepuffs for the cast & crew...

(Actually, that's a lie.) We are putting up an entire theatrical production, and that gets expensive. Just some of the costs involved include:

  • Rehearsal space for 20+ hours
  • Insurance
  • Costumes
  • Sets/props
  • Professional tech & hiring a director
  • Design work/Publicity Stills
  • Printing programs
  • Postcards/flyers/other promotional materials
  • Advertising

It's crazy! But we want to put on a good show and have a good audience, so it's necessary ... We've put in our own money, and we're working for free, but we need help. So if you can, make a gift, and if you can't, keeping reading!

 Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute that's okay! Here are three other ways to help:

  • Send this page to a friend or three!
  • Like us on Facebook: An Evening With Kirk Douglas
  • Come see the show! Tickets go on sale July 20th and you'll be able to buy them here: FringeNYC Tickets 

About FringeNYC

The New York International Fringe Festival (FringeNYC) is the largest multi-arts festival in North America, with more than 200 companies from all over the world performing for 16 days in more than 20 venues. FringeNYC has served as a springboard to Broadway and Off-Broadway for many years, introducing the world to shows like "Urinetown" and "Silence: The Musical." When accepted to participate, it gives untested writers/performers a chance to put their work up at some of the city's best Off-Broadway and Off-Off Broadway venues.

 Got any questions? Just e-mail us at info@aneveningwithkirk.com. Thanks!

story:
LITTLE RADICAL THEATRICS

WHO WE ARE

  • LRT began in 2009 with two young actors in  Westchester County, NY who were aging out of youth theater and could no longer pay the heavy participation fees and wanted to bring to their community lesser known and unique musicals to increase the diversity of the arts around them while giving everyone a chance to participate who earned a role without participation fees. 
  • LRT produced its first production in August of 2009, the musical Urinetown at the Schoolhouse Theater in Croton Falls. The show had a sold-out run. 
  • In June of 2010 LRT produced a re-imagining of Sweeney Todd at the Play Group Theater in White Plains
  • In 2011 LRT became a year-long production company with its first full season: The Westchester Premiere of Reefer Madness, the Westchester Premiere of Smile and The Mystery of Edwin Drood  
  • Our second season in 2012 featured the Westchester Premiere of Andrew Lippa's The Wild Party, the NY Regional Premiere of Bloody BLoody Andrew Jackson, and Stephen Sondheim's A Little Night Music
  • In just three years LRT has produced eight full musicals including three county premieres and one NY Regional Premiere!
  • LRT has been covered in the Journal News, Rockland County Times, Patch.com, broadwayworld.com, theatermania.com playbill.com, on WVOX and WFAS
  • LRT is a non profit 501c3 corporation that means all your donations are tax-deductible
  • LRT was recently awarded a grant by ArtsWestchester, the Arts Council of Westchester! 

What We Need & What You Get

 

  LRT is looking for help in funding its third full season. We have some WONDERFUL shows planned. We also are using the 2013 season to embrace our extremely diverse artists by providing roles and shows with opportunities for everyone! 

 

  • BAT BOY: THE MUSICAL
    Story and Book by Keythe Farley and Brian Flemming
    Music and Lyrics by Laurence O'Keefe
    WINTER 2012

    Based on a story ripped straight from The Weekly World News tabloid, BAT BOY: THE MUSICAL is a faux-horror musical comedy about a half boy/half bat creature who is rescued fro
    m a cave near Hope Falls, West Virginia, and taken in by the empathetic wife of the local veterinarian. “Edgar," as he's named, quickly learns to speak and act in civilized ways as a "normal" boy – even falling in love for the first time. Danger looms, however, when a murderous rampage sweeps Hope Falls, and the town learns of a deep, dark secret, and the shocking story of Bat Boy's unholy origin is revealed. This off-kilter satire offers clever send-ups to other celebrated Broadway musicals, a hilarious book, surprising twists and turns of plot, and a lesson in the agony of being different and accepting your inner beast.
  • ZOMBIE PROM
    Book and Lyrics by  John Dempsey
    Music by Dana P Rowe
    SPRING 2013

    One of the most celebrated Off-Broadway shows of the past fifteen years will finally be brought to light for new audiences! Based on a story of "atomic adolescent angst" by John Dempsey and Hugh M. Murphy, with music by Dana P. Rowe and book and lyrics by John Dempsey, ZOMBIE PROM asks the question, "What's a pretty senior like Toffee is to do when her rebel-without-a-cause boyfriend Jonny (whose name is noticeably spelled without the 'h') dies after he charges off on his motorcycle to the nuclear waste dump, only to come back as an oozing zombie hell-bent on graduating?" The school's principal orders him to drop dead while a slick sensationalist news reporter seizes on him as the freak du jour, making for a rollicking romp through the atomic 1950's. With super-charged doses of "Little Shop of Horrors" and "Grease", this girl-meets-ghoul musical explodes with exciting mutations of doo-wop, pop ballads, rousing gospel and rock to release a radioactive feel-good glow upon the entire nuclear family!
  • PARADE
    Book by Alfred Uhry 
    Music and Lyrics by Jason Robert Brown

     Based on the true story of the trial and lynching of Leo FrankSUMMER 2013In 1913, Leo Frank, a Brooklyn-raised Jew living in Georgia, is put on trial for the murder of 13-year-old Mary Phagan, a factory worker under his employ. Already guilty in the eyes of everyone around him, a sensationalist publisher and a janitor's false testimony seal Leo's fate. His only defenders are a governor with a conscience, and, eventually, his assimilated Southern wife who finds the strength and love to become his greatest champion. Branded "daring, innovative and bold," PARADE tells the tragic, true story of the trial and lynching of a man wrongly accused of murder. Brought to emotional and theatrical life by acclaimed playwright Alfred Uhry and composer-lyricist Jason Robert Brown -- earning TONY Awards for 'Best Book' and 'Best Score' -- this mounting will mark the Westchester debut of the revised version, just in time to observe the trial's centennial. 

 

But...where is my money going?

   Even though we do our best to keep costs down, producing any show adds up.  As we charge no participation fees, all we can count on are ticket sales and donations. And ticket sales alone NEVER pay for an entire show. As a very very generous contributer your money would go to

  • Stipends for our musical director , director, choreographer, musicians, crew and designers. They are young but they work SO very hard and deserve at least a little money
  • Costumes and set materials. To immerse our audience in the world of these shows, we want to match the talent onstage with the highest prduction values possible. Your money will help pay for costume rental and/or materials to make costumes and materials to build our set!
  • Floor, house and personal mic rental so that you can hear the gorgeous voices of our actors above the wonderful band.
  • Theater space rental. We need a place to perform our wonderful shows! Our theaters are brand new houses with state of the art lighting and amenities but they most certainly do not come cheap!

We have wonderful incentives to offer for your donation including personal thank-yous, show tickets, t-shirts, original photography, producer credit and more!

NO matter how much we get? ANY little bit helps. $500 covers one stipend, or half of our musicians for one show, or costumes for one show so no matter how much we end up raising? You can bet your money is going to a good cause and help us out immensely! AND its all tax-deductible

WHY THESE SHOWS MATTER

 

  LRT has taken this season and dedicated it to not only promoting diversity in our artists and in the performing arts but to producing shows about individuals who are facing prejudice  for just being a little different than those around them. We are all young artists and many of us have faced bullying growing up for not quite fitting in with our peers and this has had a profound effect on all of us at LRT. These shows are important because whether  comedies or dramas they are about people overcoming bullying and intolerance. Theater is such a powerful and immediate art form where each performance is a special and unique experience shared only once by the performers and the audience. As the cost of a broadway ticket rises the attendance especially of young people who cannot afford a broadway ticket decreases. We want to bring these important quality productions to people who might otherwise not have a chance or the money to see a show. Please help us encourage young artists, and people of all ages to support the performing arts and support the important messages in these productions! 

Other Ways You Can Help

   If you can't contribute, we urge you to purchase a ticket to one of our shows by visiting www.littleradicaltheatrics.com. We also urge you to spread the word about our company and our mission in the community. 

If you can't attend the show or contribute, please help us by spreading the word. Every penny we raise will help us to present the best productions possible! IndieGoGo makes this easy to do with their sharing tools!

Thank you so much for your support!

story:
Help me make my dream of making theater--on my terms-- possible!

WHAT IT IS:

Mickey & Sage - a play by Sara Farrington 

Mickey & Sage is Sara Farrington's inaugural full-length production in her very own Brooklyn performance space, Foxy Films. 

January 20th-29th, 2012 @ 8pm 
Foxy Films Performance Space
170 Tillary St., Brooklyn NY


More on Mickey & Sage...


Mickey & Sage is a disturbing play, disguised in a funny play. It explores childhood fear and how kids misinterpret the world. Mickey is an aggressive little 11-year old played pitch-perfectly by Jack Frederick. Sage is a hyper-active 9-year-old played scintillatingly by Erin Mallon. Mickey & Sage have been thrust into a terrifying world, thanks to two very bad parents and one very strange neighbor, Harvey, played ever-so-delicately by Don Carter. 


The great thing about Mickey & Sage is that the always audience gets it, but the kids never do. It's really fun.


WHAT I NEED:

I finally don't need to pay for rehearsal or performance space! Yes!

But here's where I'm looking for help with financing:

Actor fees, including weekly rehearsal and performance pay (for a 6 performance run.)

Designer fee, including a stipend for my set designer.

Basic set pieces, including a picket fence and slamming screen door.

Props.

Wine and refreshments for during the show.


WHAT I HOPE TO ACHIEVE (WITH YOUR HELP!):

With your help, I hope to make Foxy Films a fully functioning theater that exists solely to produce my and my fellow playwright's work and very little cost to them or you.

The great thing about Mickey & Sage is that the always audience gets it, but the kids never do. It's really fun.

WHAT I NEED:

I finally don't need to pay for rehearsal or performance space! Yes!
But here's where I'm looking for help with financing:
Actor fees, including weekly rehearsal and performance pay (for a 6 performance run.)
Designer fee, including a stipend for my set designer.
Basic set pieces, including a picket fence and slamming screen door.
Props.
Wine and refreshments for during the show.


WHAT I HOPE TO ACHIEVE (WITH YOUR HELP!):
With your help, I hope to make Foxy Films a fully functioning theater that exists solely to produce my and my fellow playwright's work and very little cost to them or you.

story:
Short Summary

I am Colleen Ross, or B-girl Bean. I have been break dancing since 2000 and I have helped organize break dance competitions since 2007. My goal is to bring positive, uplifting hip hop events to communities around the Seattle area.

Queen vs Queen is an event which will occur in the Seattle area on August 11th. It is a partnership between 206 Zulu Malikas, Northwestbgirls.com and The City of Burien. It will include a 1 on 1 b-girl invitational competition, 2 on 2 open break dance competition, 3 on 3 open all-styles competition, street dance workshops and performances.

Contributing to Queen vs Queen will aid in the mission to:

  • Raise Awareness of the strength and diversity of females in the male domniated break dancing scene.
  • Advocate for women's stories to be heard and unique styles expressed through invite competitions, show, ventors and workshops.
  • Unite through a celebration of street dance styles with a female focus.
  • Create an annual event presence to inspire girls and women to join the break dance scene and for the level of competition to continue to increase to include dancers from around the world. 

What We Need & What You Get

The budget for Queen vs Queen is $3140. Here's the break down:

    • $500: Airfare assistance for b-girls who need a little help. Most dancers get between $50-$75 assistance.
    • $100: Transportation to get visiting dancers to and from the event and airport.
    • $300: 3 Workshop Teachers, each teaching a FREE workshop, open to the whole community.
    • $250: Compensation for 5 judges for all-styles and 5 judges for break dancing.
    • $400: Compensation for 2 djs, the female DJ travels from Las Vegas to be a part of this event.
    • $80: Compensation for 2 hosts.
    • $300: Housing for visiting dancers.
    • $1000: Cash Prizes are divided between 1st and 2nd place winners of all competitions.
    • $160: Thank you gifts for all the women who travel to Queen vs Queen to compete, dj, host, and judge.
    • $50: Posters and flyers to promote the event.

Awesome Perks for funding Queen vs Queen include: Your name on event shirt, a personal dance class and personalized thank you photo!

If the entire buget is covered I will be able to make Queen vs Queen more accessable to the community by making it a FREE event. If not, a small fee of $5-$10 will be charged at the door.

The Impact

Funding for this project allow me to not only hold a high quality and low cost event, it allows me to invite and help dancers who would not otherwise be able to afford this trip.

The event, Queen vs Queen, is not an end in inself. The goal is to draw a large group of female dancers together to connect, grow and recognize that they are not alone. These dancers are then able to go out into their communities and help younger female dancers develop and compete right along with male dancers. The goal is a celebration of female talent to inspire more connect and growth in the hip hop community.

The local b-girl group, Northwest B-girls, has already started to feel the impact of this a growing b-girl community. Through competing together, practicing together as well as performances this group has been growing and building the abilities and confidence of b-girls in Seattle.

A qualifier for 2 invite spots in Queen vs Queen was help in Shoreline, WA this May. This event was FREE and open to the community through a partnership with The City of Shoreline Teen Program. This event included 10 female competitors and 5 female judges. Competitors came from as far as Calgary, Canada and Portland, Oregon. The excitement at this event showed the desire and hunger b-girls have to be a part of this event and to celebrate b-girling. 

 Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Share the link to this campaign and event!

Come to Queen vs Queen.

Uplift through Hip Hop culture.

story:
Trapped in a nowhere time and place, three sisters search for love and
meaning in Chekhov’s classic tale about the irony of hope. In a funny,
haunting, and daring new adaptation by Allie Stapleton, Synecdoche 3
Sisters explores the fundamental question: if dreams are necessary in
order to live, what do you live for when your dreams disappear?

Featuring an ensemble cast of Brisbane’s best independent and emerging artists, including Nicole Bilson, Kerith Atkinson, Caroline Levien, and Danny Murphy, and designed by Kade Sproule and Jason Glenwright, this is storytelling at its most provocative.

story:
About The Travels

The Travels is a new Epic play by Aaron Ricciardi, with songs by Kelly Hoppenjans (music) and Ricciardi (lyrics). Mashing up styles that range from Brecht to dystopian fiction to South Park, this innovative work turns the genre of musical theatre on its ear. 

The Story

Welcome to the U.S. of A.  Other countries suffer biblical consequences for their filthy ways, but the U.S. of A. is the most perfect place on Earth--at least that’s what Mr. Travel preaches every day on the nation’s only TV show. A trippy dystopian tale with an eclectic soundtrack, The Travels follows Teeny, Mr. Travel’s rule-breaker of a daughter. Teetering on adulthood and perplexed by this cruel world, Teeny learns to see past smoke and mirrors…and she starts a revolution. 

Our NYMF Production

The Travels will be produced at the New York Musical Theatre Festival (NYMF) this July as an official selection of the Next Link Project. Hundreds of shows were submitted to NYMF’s prestigious Next Link Project this year, and our play is one of just ten that were chosen by a Grand Jury of working theatre practitioners, who are all leaders in their fields. NYMF provides a launching pad for the next generation of musicals and their creators to ensure the continued vitality of America’s greatest art form. [title of show], Chaplin, and the Tony- and Pulitzer Prize winning Next to Normal all had early productions at NYMF before they went to Broadway. We are thrilled to join such prestigious company this summer, under the keen direction of Travis Greisler (Rated: RSO, The Orion Experience). 

What We Need

We’ve been fortunate to receive donations from fantastic supporters of The Travels, but we need your help to complete our fundraising!  It takes a village to put on a show, and your donation will help us pay top-notch actors, musicians, and other staff members.  All of the money we raise goes directly to getting our show on stage.  

Thanks so much for checking out our page, and we hope you consider donating to this bold and exciting production!

story:
Teatro Ma and Ludwig are two independent and self-managed companies who have decided to collaborate and develop this project. We have been revisiting in a contemporary way a play dealing with the universal themes of humanity. 

With Il giardino dei ciliegi we want to talk about the tragedy of families shattered by the economic crisis. The Orchard's characters seem like deaf people trying to talk to each other. It seems like Chekhov himself is shouting at them, poetically, to do something and save themselves. But there is no hope, except for those who listen to their body and instinct. The Chekhovian condition is the condition of an entire society, depressed and anxious, that cannot afford bread but plays the lottery. Using these themes as a starting point, we have been exploring the human dynamics that affect the play's characters. 

The Cherry Orchard is one of the most performed and well-known plays by Chekhov. A path of rediscovery is therefore necessary to justify its staging. Even without a production, we started in February a research process needing continuity, time and study. That is why we have decided to launch a crowdfunding campaign.

Do you want to help us? You can support us. 


Teatro Ma /Ludwig

                                                                    ///////////                                                          

Teatro Ma e Ludwig sono due compagnie indipendenti e autogestite, che hanno deciso di collaborare per sviluppare questo progetto, rivisitando in chiave contemporanea il testo che per eccellenza tratta i temi universali dell'umanità. 


Con il giardino dei ciliegi oggi noi vogliamo raccontare il disastro di famiglie distrutte dalla crisi. Infatti i personaggi del giardino sembrano sordi che cercano di dialogare tra loro. Sembra che lo stesso Cechov voglia gridare poeticamente ai personaggi di fare qualcosa per salvarsi, ma non c’è speranza, se non per chi ascolta il proprio corpo ed il proprio istinto. Lo stare cechoviano è lo stare di un’intera società, che, depressa e ansiosa, non può permettersi il pane, ma gioca alla lotteria. Partendo da queste tematiche abbiamo voluto affrontare un’indagine su tutte quelle dinamiche umane che i personaggi dell’opera subiscono.

Uno dei testi più rappresentati e conosciuti di A. Cechov, infatti, merita oggi un percorso di ri-scoperta che giustifichi la stessa messa in scena. 
Pur non avendo nessuna produzione, abbiamo avviato, da febbraio fino ad oggi, un processo di ricerca, che necessita continuità, tempo e studio. Da qui la decisione di lanciare un crowdfunding.

Vuoi aiutarci? Puoi sostenerci.

Teatro Ma / Ludwig


This is our Facebook link:

https://www.facebook.com/groups/1700551313502711/1702749713282871/?notif_t=like

story:
What is the Seattle Play Series?

Founded in 2013, The Seattle Play Series is a new works festival that celebrates the vibrant people and culture that make up our beloved, but rapidly changing, Emerald City. Each iteration of the Seattle Play Series will focus on telling stories from a different Seattle neighborhood, highlighting the character and identity of that area. We have already successfully completed a staged reading and performance of plays about Green Lake, and for this next series we're focusing on Capitol Hill!

What is a staged reading?

A lot of you probably already know the answer to this, but for those of you who don't, a staged reading is the step between writing a play and a full production. Actors are brought in to read the lines aloud, sometimes accompanied by small amounts of action, in order to give the playwrights and directors a sense of what still needs to change in the script and give them ideas about how to stage the full production. It also gives the playwrights a chance to interact directly with actors and an audience in order to get their opinions on the roles and lines they have created, which is why this staged reading will feature an optional talk-back session at the end for attendees to voice their opinions and ask questions.

Where Will All the Money Go?

In order to maintain a professional level of performance, it takes a lot of manpower, blood, sweat, tears, paper, and money.

Here's what we need:

Capitol Hill Collection

  • Venue Rental Fees: $200
  • Marketing: $150
  • Office Supplies: $50
  • Actor Stipends: $400
  • Director Stipends: $100
  • Crew Stipends: $100
Total Expenses
  • $1,000

Who's Involved?

Our amazing 2015 team is composed of writers, directors, and actors that are active members of the Seattle theatre community. The ten brand new plays that make up the Capitol Hill Collection were written by local Seattle playwrights:
Writers:
  • Suzanne Bailie
  • Ina Chang
  • Leonard Goodisman
  • David Gordon
  • Marcus Gorman
  • Nathan Jeffrey
  • Kathryn Jenkins
  • Jerry Kraft
  • Eleanor Moseley
  • Lyssandra Norton
With direction by a team of four amazing ladies, our cast features eight incredibly talented actors that have graced many a local stage, including Taproot Theatre, Village Theatre, The 5th Ave Theatre, Seattle Children's Theatre, ACT, Seattle Shakespeare Company, Book-It Repertory, and Wooden O:
Artistic Team:
  • Louise Butler* - Production Manager
  • Tina Polzin - Director
  • Aneesh Sheth* - Director
Cast:
  • Shannon Agostinelli
  • Kevin Bordi
  • William Hall Jr*
  • Llysa Holland
  • Amanda Keogh
  • Aneesh Sheth*
  • Greg Stone*
  • Benjamin Wippel
* Member Actor's Equity Association

I've Donated. What Now?

First, thank you! Now that you've donated, save the date and be sure to tell people about our campaign and our performances. Use the share buttons to talk about our campaign on social media and invite your friends to join you on July  13th & 14th at 7:30pm at the Colonial Room to see our reading and join in our talk-back. 

As for when you will get your rewards:

  • If you will be attending the reading, we will have the posters to give to you there.
  • If you can not attend the reading, we will send you your poster to you shortly afterwards.
  • If you have donated enough to get a book, we will be sending those out once we have finished editing the plays after the staged reading, so you will get the finalized versions that are heading into full production. We anticipate sending those out in November, at the latest.

Thank You!

story:
The Story

Theatre SKAM, one of Victoria’s top alternative theatre companies, is presenting the long awaited premiere of its homage to the ‘grandmother of all fans’, Joan Mans, this March 17th through 26th, 2017 as part of the Belfry Theatre’s Spark Festival.

“I expect I am like our audience. I can’t believe it has taken SKAM this long to premiere this new work, which began to develop in 2009 when Joan was alive. It’s like the play has become as annoying as Joan was when she was alive and talking your ear off about something. Enough already. Here we go.”

- Artistic Producer Matthew Payne

For over thirty years, Joan attended arts happenings in Victoria, finishing most evenings at Swan’s Pub, dancing to live music. In 2007 she entered extended care after she fell and was declared incapable. Actor and playwright Matthew Payne went from avoiding the often-chatty Joan to befriending her. Their enduring friendship is at the heart of this project.

“… [S]he was a celebrated -- and slightly notorious -- figure in this city's close-knit cultural scene. She was the arts equivalent of the sports "super fan," and it seemed she attended every cultural event in Victoria. A short, stout woman with a cropped bob, she was everywhere, always alone.”

Adrian Chamberlain, Times Colonist

Joining Matthew Payne onstage will be Lynda Raino and Treena Stubel, and a chorus of students from SKAM Studios' Children's Ensemble, and members and friends of Victoria’s The Choir, led by Choir Leader Marc Jenkins. Joan has brought together community across disciplines and ages to honour and celebrate a woman who embraced the rich and vibrant arts of Victoria, like no other.

 

Sandy Cumberland, Stage Management

James Fagan Tait, Direction

Shannon Macelli, Production Management

Brooke Maxwell, Sound Design and Composition

Conor Moore, Lighting and Projection Design

Matthew Payne, Performer

Lynda Raino, Performer

Patricia Reilly, Costume Design

Graham McMonagle, Assistant Costume Design

Treena Stubel, Performer

 

Featuring SKAM Studios' Children's Ensemble and Marc Jenkins & The Choir and Friends

 

We need you, Champion!

We are seeking ten champions to donate $100 each towards the project. This is the final push  and allows us to move forward without hesitation, in much the same spirit that Joan embodied. No regrets. The project is dear to our hearts and this premiere will be the beginning of a bright future. Our intention is to tour the project, and to connect Joan's story to individual communities across Canada. Your contribution honours a legendary Victoria citizen many will remember, and affords others a chance to meet Joan for the first time. Thank you.

Your contribution honours a legendary Victoria citizen many will remember, and affords others a chance to meet Joan for the first time. Thank you.

story:
Dirt is Where Flowers Grow is an original play written by Ashley L. Calderón. This play will take place at the Teatro Latea in New York City. The performance dates are December 14th-17th. Six performances in total. Opening and Closing night will start @7pm. Two shows @8pm and the other two @3pm. 

At Lucy's Burger Joint, young waitress Grace comes face to face with spiraling events that force her to choose between what is right and what is easy. Constantly at odds with her mother, Miriam - fierce, opinionated and legal guardian of Grace's son, Jeremy, the two get caught in a fiery dispute between who gets to have custody over him. Tommy, Grace's regular at the restaurant, provides insight and help with his detective background in guiding her down the path to victory against her mother, but at what cost when love gets involved? And if not love, lust from Tommy's big shot lawyer friend, Stan who forces Grace into a corner, testing her desperation. Will Grace win custody of her son? How far will she have to go and will she be pushed to revisit her dark past?
Inventive, timely and modern, Ashley L. Calderón gives a close look at what it means to overcome obstacles, even family and the sacrifices we must make to achieve our goal. 

We at Blended City decided that this play will have the potential to be a unique and creative theater experience. Each of us on this team comes from a different background, whether it be ethnicity, language and life experiences that will elevate this play beyond ordinary boundaries. This will be a challenge for the actors, the director and Blended City making this the perfect play for all of us to explore, learn and grow as artists in today's world. 

In order to get this excellent piece of theatre off the ground and on the stage, we need YOU! Your generous donations will go towards theatre rental, production design, and marketing.  Being a part of this journey goes towards this unique production that comes with many perks - personalized shout outs on Social Media, Autographed Memorbilia, One on One acting coaching and behind the scene access right before the show!  

We can't wait to share it with you.  As a contributor, you can rest assured that you won't be disappointed.  

Thank you!

story:
Pop Heart Productions (UK).

We are a young and upcoming production company based in Brighton. We intend to promote a fresh and youthful approach to theatre influenced by french new wave cinema and the mumblecore school of film. Our primary focus is to firstly attract a more youthful crowd to the theatre but secondly to create and stage productions with narratives that are appealing and relatable regardless of their demographic.  

Decade 20.

This campaign is to promote our brand new production "Decade 20" which will premiere at this years Brighton Fringe Festival on 8th and 9th May. "Decade 20" tells the story of Nick and Melissa. When Melissa finished with Nick an era ends and all their friends and family are left wondering where to go from here. 

How you can help.

With your contribution we will be able to buy costumes, props and materials to add to the aesthetic of the play. In addition it will help us to produce promotional material such as fliers and posters for the event. We are an energetic and resourceful young production company and have the ability to make whatever money you donate go a long way.
Perks.
With that in mind we have a some interesting perks for you to take advantage of .

£10 (x10) – signed poster by cast.

£15 (x8) - sponsor cast member, shout out in programme, signed poster by cast.

£25 – (x2) Signed poster, shout out in programme and we have 2 characters to rename (1 per contributor). Sensible suggestions only please.

£50 – you record the voice of a character, attend the after-show party, shout out in programme, signed poster by cast, free companion ticket (when you buy a ticket).

If you can't afford to donate?

Don't worry, do what you can to promote the show on social media, link to our video or even feel free to contact us to donate your time. 
Tickets Available @ http://boxoffice.brightonfringe.org/theatre/878...

story:
About us:

Static Noyze was founded in 2006 by five college friends who shared a common belief that through artistic innovation, unbridled passion and professional savvy, they could unleash a new kind of hip hop dance company on Boston. The founders wanted to establish a group that would impact the community on a grand scale. 

The group was received with great success and quickly became a well-known name in the Boston dance scene. Since then, Static Noyze continues to produce innovative theatrical pieces that capture audiences. 

Since its creation, Static Noyze has been blessed with opportunities to perform and compete throughout New England. The company has placed first at esteemed international competitions such as World Of Dance, Prelude Urban Dance Competition, and Impact DanceFest. In addition, Static Noyze is known for earning awards for Best Theme, Best Costume, and Crowd Favorite.  

What We Do:

In an effort to promote the company's diversity, Static Noyze teaches weekly hip hop and contemporary classes around Boston that showcase the many styles of the choreographers/teachers within the company. A different member teaches each week, creating a drop-in class that varies in style, choreography, and interpretation. 

In addition to weekly studio classes, Static also hosts workshops several times a year. We travel to elementary/middle/high schools in the area to perform and teach, as well as bring dancers in master classes. We strive to provide our community with opportunities to train with master teachers, and so we host choreographers from other cities in an effort to expose the Boston dance community to more inspiring talent.

What We Hope:

Static Noyze is ready to take our work to the West Coast. We are a company that consists of professional scientists, teachers, financial consultants, and computer programmers. We are a group of passionate professionals who also teach and choreograph. We are on a mission to spread our love for dance around the world. Our approach to dance is creative, abstract, contemporary, entertaining, and exciting. 

We would like to benefit our Boston dance scene by bringing our experiences and exposure on the west coast home. This professional development will promote our vision of innovative, theatrical hip hop. We are eager to network and learn from our fellow dancers in California and bring back our newfound knowledge, training, and skill. 

We plan to bring our most dedicated dancers and choreographers to compete at the World Of Dance Finals, an honorable invitation we received after placing first at several World Of Dance East Coast events. We also plan to teach at several local studios while we're there and take advantage of our proximity to training studios by taking classes. With your help, we can achieve this dream and benefit the dance communities on both coasts.

Our costs:

$4,500 - Travel Fees (subsidized plane fare, hotel stay, transportation)
$700 - Registration fees (required by World Of Dance organization)
$550 - Costumes/Props
$250 - Studio rental (necessary for proper preparation/rehearsal)ca
