story_txt:
¿Qué es esto?Esto es, querido amigo o amiga, una campaña de crowdfunding. Estamos, en estos tiempos inciertos, luchando por llevar el teatro y la cultura desde Canarias hacia el resto de la península. Por eso pedimos tu colaboración. A cambio, los mejores asientos para las funciones que elijas y contenidos exclusivos sólo para los mecenas. 


Quiénes somos
Teatro la República

La Compañía de Teatro La República nace en el año 1997 bajo la dirección de Nacho Cabrera con el deseo de proponer una visión diferente del trabajo teatral. 
Desde entonces ha acuñado éxitos lejos de las leyes de mercado y de visiones comerciales abordado a autores como William Shakespeare, Yolanda Pallín, Juan Mayorga, Borja Ortiz de Gondra, Suso de Toro.
La República es una compañía comprometida desde el noble arte del teatro con la realidad social y política de nuestro tiempo. 
Destacadas entre sus puestas “Ciudadano Yago” Versión de Otelo de Shakespeare,  (actualmente en cartel), “Hamelin” de Juan Mayorga, “Cuando las mujeres asaltaron los cielos” versión de Macbeth de Shakespeare, “NWC – No War Cabaret”de Nacho Cabrera “Dedos” de Borja Ortiz de Gondra, “Nano” deSuso del Toro, etc….
Sala Cuarta Pared
25 años de experiencia nos han permitido convertirnos con el tiempo en una sala diez:



Somos un núcleo plural y dinamizador de las artes escénicas contemporáneas.


Mantenemos un claro apoyo a las nuevas dramaturgias en nuestra programación.


Somos punto de referencia para un público heterogéneo, nada elitista, que busca un teatro comprometido y de su época.


Albergamos festivales de danza y teatro, tanto propios como externos, que enriquecen la programación de cada temporada.


El espectador disfruta en nuestra sala del privilegio de la proximidad con el escenario y de la versatilidad del espacio.


Nuestra línea de programación busca montajes renovadores y arriesgados porque nos gusta ser un espacio abierto al cambio.


Además de la programación externa exhibimos la producción propia, con nuestra Compañía Cuarta Pared dirigida por Javier Yagüe y la compañía residente de danza, Provisional Danza, de Carmen Werner.


Promovemos otras actividades, como encuentros con compañías, charlas, descuentos… en respuesta a la inquietud de nuestros espectadores.


Ofrecemos ventajas extra a través del Club de Socios, porque si confías en Cuarta Pared, eres de Cuarta Pared.


La respuesta del público nos avala. Unos 35.000 espectadores siguen nuestra programación cada temporada.


Difusión escénica
Reymala y Teatro la República unifican esfuerzos de logística y distribución a través de Difusión Escénica, que será la herramienta de comunicación, negociación y contratación de espectáculos de ambas compañías, además de otras producciones nacionales e internacionales.


Con esta unión se busca generar sinergias en una industria, la cultural, que no está pasando por su mejor momento, y que necesita reinventarse para seguir viva.


Equipo actoral

Yanara Moreno




Graduada en Dirección Teatral en la Escuela Nacional de Instructores de Teatro de Cuba. Como actriz comenzó desde los siete años en la TVCubana y con nueve,
en teatro profesional con la Compañía Teatro Estudio, Cuba. 
Cuenta con un amplísimo currículum como actriz de teatro, cine y televisión en su país natal, interpretando grandes obras del teatro universal. 
Ya en Canarias, ha participado en producciones tan importantes como “Tres”, “Las Criadas” “Abre el ojo”, “Don Juan Tenorio”, “Casa de muñecas”, “Boeing-Boeing”, “A vuestro gusto”, “Overbukin”, “La zapatera prodigiosa”, “Bodas de sangre” o “De vuelta al baile” y con Cías como: La República, Profetas de Mueble Bar,  Clapso. Prod. DD&company, 2RC Prod...etc.
En cine, en producciones como “Hello Hemingway” Dir: Fernando Pérez o “La Isla Interior” de Felix Sabroso y Dunia Ayaso.
En televisión ha participado como actriz en bcadenas  como Antena3 Canarias o TV Canaria.
Vincula su trabajo como actriz a la docencia, ejerciendo desde el año 2004 como profesora de teatro en La EMM “Candidito” en La Villa de Teror.

Miguel Ángel Maciel


Se inicia en el teatro en el año 1976 formándose con maestro de la talla de Felisa Yenny, Lito Cruz, Augusto Fernández.
Inicialmente se integra a grupos de teatro independiente hasta llegar a formar parte de las compañías más importantes de Buenos Aires, en teatros como, el Teatro General San Martín o el Teatro Nacional Cervantes.
Ha trabajado con destacados directores de la escena argentina como Santiago Doria, Rubén Schumager, Carlos Alvarenga, Hector Tealdi, Alejandra Boero, entre otros.
En permanente formación ha realizado talleres con directores como Will Keen o Eva Lesmes.
Actualmente desarrolla su actividad como actor y creador en la  Compañía  La República.
En otro orden de cosas ha sido Secretario de Organización de la Unión de Actores de Canarias hasta marzo del 2012.
Entre sus trabajos en España podemos destacar :
“Ciudadano Yago” (Nacho Cabrera)Versión de “Otelo” de Shakespeare. Cía La República  “Las Criadas” (Jean Genet) Ganadora Premio Réplica 2013 Mejor Espectáculo y Mejor Vestuario por Profetas de Mueble Bar “Hamelin” ( Juan Mayorga)  Cia La República
Toni Báez


Comienza sus estudios teatrales a mediados de los noventa en la Escuela de Actores de Canarias, a la vez que asiste a diferentes seminarios de interpretación impartidos por el maestro Jorge Eines. Años más tarde y después de haber colaborado con diferentes compañías teatrales de Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, decide trasladarse a Madrid donde se titula en arte dramático por la escuela de interpretación Jorge Eines. Cabe destacar sus trabajos a las órdenes de Mario Gas en el Matadero de Madrid con el montaje “Ascensión y caída de la ciudad de Mahagonny” y “Belgrado” en el Teatro Español a las órdenes de Carlos Bolívar. Con Tábatha Producciones en el Palacio de Congresos de Murcia, “A golpes de Tango”;  “Agamenón. Volví del supermercado y le di una paliza a mi hijo” de Rodrigo García dirigida e interpretada por él mismo y más recientemente su participación en “El crimen de la perra Chona”.  

Daniel Tapia Alberto


Actor licenciado en la Escuela de actores de Canarias, empezó a formarse a los 16 años adquiriendo una férrea base en pantomima y esgrima. Amplió sus conocimientos en materias como didáctica teatral, espacio escénico , producción, gestión y distribución de espectáculos teatrales, Esgrima Mediaval, Narración Oral , Melodrama, y demás disciplina de la mano de Robert Muro, Fernando Bercebal, Philippe Gaulier, Patrick Pezzin, Thierry Taboni, Victoria Blasco, Benjamín Alonso, José Luis Raymond, Adolfo Vargas, Jep Meléndez, Renato Gato, Stefano Perocco y otros profesionales de renombre. Amplia sus estudios en Italia bajo la tutela de Adriano Iurssevich.


Como actor ha trabajado en diversos montajes, llegando a formar parte en compañías como , Cabaretutumba, Abubukaka, REYMALA, Artifest, Troysteatro. Con sus producciones Ha trabajado en EEUU, ITALIA, PERÚ y diversos festivales como Almagro, Fira Tárrega, Almería, Burgos, Almeria, Alcalá de Henares, entre otros.


Actualmente trabaja de Actor y Productor de la compañía REYMALA, como Distribuidor de “Difusión Escénica”

Sara Álvarez Hernández


 En Cádiz pasa a recibir formación en EmeTeatro, escuela de Germán Corona, director del Centro Dramático Nacional con el montaje “Cementerio de automóviles”, de Fernando Arrabal. Pasando luego a su compañía y haciendo gira por parte de Andalucía y Madrid, durante 5 años.
Termina obteniendo la titulación Superior de Interpretación escénica por la escuela de Actores de Canarias en la promoción 2009-2013, o la número 13.
Ha trabajado como figurante y acróbata, tanto para la compañía alemana Titanick con su espectáculo “Firebirds”, como para La Fura dels Baus, con “Afrodita o el juicio de Paris”.
Ha trabajado como actriz en HelenaTurbo Teatro, en un homenaje a Pérez Galdós,en el musical “Pippi”, de Jabiiniciativas,  con Espectáculos del Plata, en el infantil “El país de las moscas”, y en el recién estrenado espectáculo para bebés “Ahora”, con los montajes para bares “Las Rameras errantes” en verso, “El Superfollón”, “Familia, dulce familia”, y el también recién estrenado “Inseguridad social”, bajo la dirección de Jorge Reyes, con Teatro la República en una lectura dramatizada a nivel nacional, con la obra “El año que se rompió mi corazón”, bajo la dirección de Nacho Cabrera.
Como mérito, mencionar su premio a mejor actriz revelación en el festival de teatro clásico de Moratalaz con el montaje “La comedia de los asnos”, bajo la dirección de German Corona.




Textos: QY Bazo






QY Bazo somos Enrique y Yeray Bazo.  Hemos sido galardonados con el XIV Premio de Teatro Mínimo Rafael Guerrero por la obra Modelo 17 05 y con el Premio de Textos Teatrales Jesús Domínguez, por la obra Tesla/Edison. Hemos escrito y estrenado:
Adaptaciones: El dardo en la palabra (2010) de Lázaro Carreter y ¿A quién le importa? (2013) de Jorge Berlanga. 
Infantiles: la versión de Brundibár (2008) de Hans Krása y ¿Qué sabes del timple? (2012), espectáculo nominado a Mejor Espectáculo Infantil en los Premios Réplica de Teatro de Canarias.
Obras colectivas: Voces fuera de lugar (2011); Mujeres de papel (2013), donde trabajamos el Orlando de Virginia Wolf; Archipiélago Dron (2013) y Pastel de Lagrange (2013), en la que colaboramos con Juan Mayorga.
Formatos breves: Modelo 17 05 (2013); Entre líneas (2013), texto seleccionado en el Primer Certamen de Monólogos del Teatro Cuyás; Paraíso temporal (2013), estrenada en OCUPA Madrid; Interferencias (2013) y El hombre del chaleco verde (2014), que forma parte del documental Mapa de recuerdos de Madrid.
Somos colaboradores habituales del Nuevo Teatro Fronterizo de José Sanchis Sinisterra y hemos sido becados por la Sala Cuarta Pared en el EN BLANCO 2012, donde escribimos Última transmisión, y nos invitaron a participar en el EN BLANCO 2.O, donde escribimos Los Impostores. 



Nacho Cabrera (Dirección escénica)





Licenciado Superior en Arte Dramático, consolidando estudios entre la RESAD y la EAC, así como cursos abiertos en la William Layton, etc.. Completa estudios con Stephan Suschke Co-Director del Berliner Ensemble. Perfecciona estudios de investigación en la ULPGC, con el trabajo “La creación colectiva Europa vs América”.
Una amplia experiencia en dirección le avala desde 1998 en distintos campos. Destacamos en el campo de la lírica “El empresario de las Canarias”, de G.B. Martíni/P., “Diario de un desaprecido”, de Leos Janácek, “Rita” y “El elixir de amor” deGaetano Donizetti, “Los Cuentos de Hoffmann” de Offenbach, etc.. así como numerosas zarzuelas, entre las que destacamos “Bohemios” de texto original de Perrín y Palacios y música de Amadeo Vives, “Agua, Azucarillos y Aguardiente” de F. Chueca, etc..
Distintos espectáculos de música clásica, conciertos y espectáculos entre los que se destaca “Beethoven, Canciones Populares Europeas“, .”En clave de Sol“, “ABBA Mia“, “Superconstellation“, “Platero”, etc… También espectáculos musicales para televisión “Gofiones. 40 años navegando“, “Homenaje a Perico Lino“, “La transtienda“, Galas de Carnaval, etc..
Así mismo ha dirigido numerosas puestas en escena para oratorios, coro y orquestas.
En el campo de la escena teatral ha dirigido diversas compañías y productoras entre las que destacamos La Repúbica, Producciones del Mar, Difusión Escénica, Reymala, Caravan LAB, Mocan Teatro, Merde per tutti, La bella compañía, Teatro sospechoso...
En el ámbito del teatro su trabajo va desde la comedia al drama, destacando entre sus puestas “Ciudadano Yago” Versión de Otelo de Shakespeare,  (actualmente en cartel), “Hamelin” de Juan Mayorga, “Cuando las mujeres asaltaron los cielos” versión de Macbeth de Shakespeare, “NWC – No War Cabaret” de Nacho Cabrera, “Dedos” de Borja Ortiz de Gondra, “Nano” deSuso del Toro, etc….


En paralelo también ha desarrollado su carrera como actor en teatro con montajes como “Poemas de Pedro Lezcano”, “Poemas y cartas a Lorca“, “Fábula del Insomino“, “La mosca detrás de la oreja“, “La farinera“. “De un modo Sentimental”, “El oso”, “Sueño de barrio”, “Chatarra”, etc…
En series de televisión como “El juramento de Puntabrava” … y presentado programas de tv. como “Farándula” y “Caminando Gran Canaria”
Su experiencia también le avala como dramaturgista y guionista donde podemos destacar “Chatarra”, “NWC – No War  Cabaret”, “Y ellos me enseñaron el teatro”, “Olé Torero”, etc… y textos publicados como “Kursk”, “Cuando las mujeres asaltaron los cielos”. 
En otro orden de cosas, es miembro oficial de Junta Directiva de la ADE (Asociación de Directores de Escena de España), miembro fundador de APTC (Asociación de Productoras de Teatro de Canarias)
En el área docente, es profesor del CSMC (Conservatorio Superior de Música de Canarias) desde el año 2003, donde ha sido Jefe de Estudios y de Departamento del mismo. Ha dirigido diversas aulas de teatro en numerosos centros de Bachillerato y colegios. Director de la Escuela de Teatro Muncipal de Ingenio y de Agüimes. Director del TET (Teatro Escuela de Temisas).
Su trabajo ha podido verse en Canarias, Sevilla, Portugal, Valencia, Zaragoza, Navarra, La Coruña, Valladolid, Gijón, Las Palmas, Cáceres, Madrid, Jaén, Compostela, Salamanca, etc… y en países como Chile, Colombia, Perú, Marruecos, Reino Unido (Manchester), etc…



Sinopsis
“Los impostores” es la una historia sobre la pavorosa cotidianidad, aquella que hace que nos hace mentir y esconder los despojos de nuestro y otras vidas, según el frecuente y acostumbrado devenir de cada familia de bien.
Este ha sido históricamente un país de sepultureros, donde la mejor solución a las cosas es sentir el terraguero de silencio que cae sobre el ataúd de la verdad. Este país es una colectividad donde preferimos inhumar a exhumar, y donde anteponemos el encantamiento y el hechizo de los camposantos silenciosos y mágicos. Somos un país donde preferimos compartir nuestras vidas con los efluvios del alma, que con los destellos de la verdad…
 “Los impostores” es un campo de batalla que desde la unidad de guerra más pequeña, la familia, nos deja al descubierto la carnaza de la que estamos hechos los hombres, a pesar de la querencia que decimos manifestar por el prójimo más cercano. 
Los charlatanes y mentirosos tienen su cobertura más segura en el ámbito de la familia, como también sucede en las grandes corporaciones y lobbies que gobiernan este país.
Nuestros impostores son visitados por una particular de voz de la conciencia, en forma de “abuelo ausente”, que lo único que viene a hacer finalmente, es subrayar un texto que además habla del desasosiego…. “no hay solución”.
Y al final nos asaltan las dudas. ¿Después de tantas mentiras continuadas, seríamos capaces de distinguirla de la verdad en nuestra memoria? ¿Y si quisiéramos abrirnos en canal a la verdad, podríamos recuperar todo lo oscurecido por nuestros propios recuerdos?. 
Hemos aceptado la amnesia como pacto, desde el cotidiano espectador, hasta la prensa de este país pasando por la justicia que nos protege. El oxímoron del “instante eterno”.
Para transportarlo todo a escena, proponemos el viejo sistema de colocarnos en el lugar del otro, en el lugar de lo “mas verdadero” y que no es otra posición que la del “abuelo ausente”… Justamente este es el personaje, que proponemos sacar del armario para observar el resto vida que se recluye en una gran vitrina a modo de armario o tumba, como expositor de nuestras propias vidas. Aunque a lo mejor, y de manera más precisa, quizás deberíamos decir que pretendemos arrastrar al público al interior del armario del “abuelo ausente”. 
¿Y si nos situamos en otra cara del poliedro planteado por los autores?. ¿Y si este personaje, fueran el plano de lo real, y desde esa realidad fuéramos capaces de ver la partida de que los que están en otro plano están jugando? ¿Y si damos el valor preciso a las reflexiones de los autores asumiendo eso de que “juego entre dos o más personas mediante el que se engañan a sí mismas, un juego que es el juego del autoengaño mutuo”.?Destino de los fondosLos fondos serán destinados a finalizar de la construcción de la escenografía.
Notas finales
Llevamos meses de trabajo intenso para tener a punto esta producción en Noviembre. Estamos deseando que participes para que vivas con nosotros la experiencia de ser mecenas, productor, amigo y confidente.
¡Conviértete en impostor!

story:
Short Summary

Hello, my name is Ryan Johnson, professional dancer and actor. I've had the pleasure of sharing my talents with the world by performing in various shows, including: The Beatles Love by Cirque du Soleil, the Off-Broadway hit STOMP in New York City and worldwide tours through partnerships with the US embassies. Now I have partnered with Quynn Johnson, an amazing dancer, author, and arts educator to give back to the world! 

Together we have created SOLE Defined, a production celebrating the fusion of percussive dance, including: tap dance, stepping, body percussion and South African Gumboot dance all set to live music and digital arts. SOLE Defined has performed at the Kennedy Center in Washington DC, the International Cajon Festival in Lima, Peru and colleges and universities across the United States. Now we are ready to take SOLE Defined to the next level! Creating a touring show with an arts and education component to help children learn math and science through movement and dance. We believe the performing arts saves lives through its ability to engage audiences through positive self expression. With your support, we will bring the arts to communities worldwide.

Our mission is to present SOLE Defined  in schools, universities, and festivals worldwide. We  believe in the power of arts integration and are in the process of creating the SOLE Defined Arts Education program for youth grades K-12th grade.

If you're unable to make a monetary donation, but still want to help us reach our goals please email us at soledefined@gmail.com

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal, is to raise $10,000 to support the development and creation of the following: 

Website creation: $1,000.00

Company photo shoot: $1,000.00

Electronic press kit: $1,000.00 

An EPK provides theater, festivals and schools with information on the company, the directors, the artist, mission and a few photo's and footage. 

Video shoot for demo reel and interactive teaching tool to be used during all arts and education program will cost about $3,000.00 to film and edit. 

We would like to attend Artist Presenters Conference (including: APAP, NACA, national performance network and ISPA NYC): Approx.: $900-1,000 each and doesn't include travel/ hotels for the company. These conference will allow SOLE Defined to showcase our performance, meet with booking agents across the globe and push our arts and education program.

Your donations will also support hiring a lawyer to help review all non-profit paper work and submission for our non-profit status. We believe these elements are important to our growth as a company and vital to bringing change to our communities. 


We've also have great  perks to thank you for your donation. 
$35: Thank you card from SOLE Defined

$50: SOLE Defined company T-shirt.

$75:  SOLE Defined company hoodie.

$100: invite to a SOLE Defined donor dance class and Q&A

$150: 2 complimentary tickets to a Sole Defined performance.

$250:  An invitation to a private rehearsal including wine and cheese. 

$500 donation reward includes a SOLE Defined gift basket + a company t-shirt + company hoodie + 2 complimentary tickets + a bottle of wine.

$1000 donation reward includes a private workshop for your studio or company. 

$2000 donation reward includes a SOLE Defined performance and workshop.

The Impact

From personal experience, we believe arts education can be mind changing in the lives of youth. As kids, arts education programs taught us to dream and imagine a world that could be shaped through movement.  It gave us an outlet and kept us away from some of the cruel realities of the world. We've learned how to creatively express ourselves, our ideas and to communicate emotions with others when our voice could not. This is why your donations are so important to us, not only are we looking to develop a touring show, we are also developing an arts and education program to take into school systems in each city we perform in.  We strongly believe that with your support we can bring positive change and give kids a new "celebrity" to look up to. 


Risks & Challenges

Our biggest challenge is to have a dream and to find people who are just as passionate about that dream to help support it. Growing up we were both told that dance isn't a "real job", go to college and get a degree! So we did!  Yet for us the art is our way of life, our way of self expression and our way to bring change to the world. We have self funded our company, using our personal savings and applying to festivals that give our company opportunities to grow. However, securing continuous support  as well as securing  multiyear grant for the company and our work within the community has been challenging! With the proper funding we would be able to take our message of arts and education to the world, attend art presenter conferences, hire videographers and photographers, and create the true production value for the show. Our goal is one part performance and one part educating by using the arts as that tool to do so.

Other Ways You Can Help

 Every dollar helps us get closer to our goal, but if you aren’t able to help out, that is quite all right! We understand. There are many ways you can help other than through monetary means -- We accept Love and Positive Energy! As well, sharing our Indiegogo page on Facebook, Twitter, email, any other type of social media, and through word of mouth would be incredibly helpful. You shall find some helpful ‘share’ buttons at the top of this page! 

With your support we will take Sole Defined to the next level.

Video shoot for demo reel and interactive teaching tool to be used during all arts and education program will cost about $3,000.00 to film and edit. 
We would like to attend Artist Presenters Conference (including: APAP, NACA, national performance network and ISPA NYC): Approx.: $900-1,000 each and doesn't include travel/ hotels for the company. These conference will allow SOLE Defined to showcase our performance, meet with booking agents across the globe and push our arts and education program.
Your donations will also support hiring a lawyer to help review all non-profit paper work and submission for our non-profit status. We believe these elements are important to our growth as a company and vital to bringing change to our communities. 
We've also have great  perks to thank you for your donation. $35: Thank you card from SOLE Defined
$50: SOLE Defined company T-shirt.
$75:  SOLE Defined company hoodie.
$100: invite to a SOLE Defined donor dance class and Q&A
$150: 2 complimentary tickets to a Sole Defined performance.
$250:  An invitation to a private rehearsal including wine and cheese. 
$500 donation reward includes a SOLE Defined gift basket + a company t-shirt + company hoodie + 2 complimentary tickets + a bottle of wine.
$1000 donation reward includes a private workshop for your studio or company. 
$2000 donation reward includes a SOLE Defined performance and workshop.
    The Impact 
From personal experience, we believe arts education can be mind changing in the lives of youth. As kids, arts education programs taught us to dream and imagine a world that could be shaped through movement.  It gave us an outlet and kept us away from some of the cruel realities of the world. We've learned how to creatively express ourselves, our ideas and to communicate emotions with others when our voice could not. This is why your donations are so important to us, not only are we looking to develop a touring show, we are also developing an arts and education program to take into school systems in each city we perform in.  We strongly believe that with your support we can bring positive change and give kids a new "celebrity" to look up to. 

    Risks & Challenges Our biggest challenge is to have a dream and to find people who are just as passionate about that dream to help support it. Growing up we were both told that dance isn't a "real job", go to college and get a degree! So we did!  Yet for us the art is our way of life, our way of self expression and our way to bring change to the world. We have self funded our company, using our personal savings and applying to festivals that give our company opportunities to grow. However, securing continuous support  as well as securing  multiyear grant for the company and our work within the community has been challenging! With the proper funding we would be able to take our message of arts and education to the world, attend art presenter conferences, hire videographers and photographers, and create the true production value for the show. Our goal is one part performance and one part educating by using the arts as that tool to do so.
Other Ways You Can Help
  Every dollar helps us get closer to our goal, but if you aren’t able to help out, that is quite all right! We understand. There are many ways you can help other than through monetary means -- We accept Love and Positive Energy! As well, sharing our Indiegogo page on Facebook, Twitter, email, any other type of social media, and through word of mouth would be incredibly helpful. You shall find some helpful ‘share’ buttons at the top of this page! 
With your support we will take Sole Defined to the next level.

story:
About MPAACT

MPAACT exists to develop, nurture, and sustain Afrikan Centered Theatre (ACT), an artistic expression grounded in the many cultures and traditions of the Afrikan continent and its Diaspora. With a vision focused on creating new work and collaborative art, MPAACT produces and educates with the goal of increasing understanding and appreciation of (ACT) and its interrelated disciplines.

For the past 24 seasons, we have boldly followed this mission.  As we continue to grow in our mission we find that we need additional resources to keep the work alive.  This is where you come in…

Your donation will help support our 25th season…DO BLACK LIVES MATTER?

With your donation we will be able to support our artistic and administrative staff and the stories of Black culture that are so important for our country’s healing in these times of angst and unrest.


What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is $10,000 to help us to move into the new season with no worries…oh, and that season preparations starts in 21 days J

OUR SEASON THEME: DO BLACK LIVES MATTER?

OUR UPCOMING SHOWS:
LAWD THE CVS IS BURNING: A GOSPEL MUSICAL STAGE PLAY - BY: CARLA STILLWELL (STANDING PRODUCTION)
UPSTATE - BY: AARON TODD DOUGLAS 
FERAL - BY: SHEPSU AAKHU
WHEN GOOD BROCCOLI GOES BAD - BY: CARLA STILLWELL FOR THEATRE FOR YOUNG AUDIENCES

FOR MORE INFO VISIT OUR WEBSITE: www.mpaact.org

All donations are welcome...but:
For a gift of $100 you will receive: A SEASON PASS for 2 to UPSTATE and FERAL! 


Why We Do What We Do

Because if we don't tell the stories of African Americans and those from the Afrikan Diaspora...who will? 
With recent events it is clear that ignorance of the Black experience is at the root of many of our societal ills.  We seek to tell contemporary stories that help move us all closer to understanding by moving the conversation forward with candor. 

Why We Need Now

In these tough economic times we have managed to continue to make amazing, award winning theatre and we will continue to do so...we know how to "make do". But we would like to foster an environment where our staff can dream big and create art as big as their imaginations without personal sacrifice.  Your donation will help us get to that goal. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Additionally, you can also...

- Make sure you put us on your calendar and come see some of our art

- We can always use volunteers and interns so email us at: imformation@mpaact.org if you are interested.

story:
**************************************************

YAAAAAAAAY! WE ACHIEVED OUR CROWDFUNDING TARGET!
Thank you, thank you, thank you! We couldn't have done it without the 133 people who contributed and the countless others who supported us by sharing and promoting the project. What an extraordinary bunch you are. We won't let you down! 

Yesterday we were trending on the homepage of indiegogo, in the top-spot of theatre projects, and there we remain 'InDemand', which basically means people can keep donating to the cause forever - great for any latecomers, and a useful platform as we enter new, ambitious territories for the project. We are still accepting donations, and every penny will go towards a bigger and better future for Three Generations Of Women (more on this soon).

What exciting times ahead - we do hope you'll stay on the journey with us - we will continue to give (far less frequent!) updates, if you're happy to receive them.  But for now we'll leave you with an inspiring montage of various #3gensofwomen supporters sharing their #mumsbestadvice gems, below. (Feel free to share your own on social media!)

This entire project is all thanks to the people that have fed into it in various ways. THANK YOU for keeping it going. And if you've enjoyed learning about the project, please do continue to share it with friends.

Love Broken Leg Theatre. x

*************************************************

A HUGE thank you to The Balcombe Charitable Trust for their incredibly generous grant of £1,000 towards our Three Generations of Women project. We are utterly over the moon and extremely cheered by the faith that they, and so many of you, have shown in us and our community-focused work.

So, that takes us up to almost £4,200 now and the target is in sight! We are determined to get as close to it as possible. This is our Eye of the Tiger moment! Please help us sprint down the final stretch by sharing the campaign far and wide...

**************************************************

WHAT'S THE BEST ADVICE YOUR MOTHER EVER GAVE YOU?

 

As we enter our final week of crowdfunding, we have been asking women to contribute family pearls of wisdom, to spread the word about our Three Generations of Women project across social media.

You can find some of the images submitted under the gallery tab above.
To read more or add your own, use hashtags #3gensofwomen #mumsbestadvice  

**************************************************

£1 WEEKEND!!
Thanks to everyone who helped make our £1 weekend such a success! We raised £195 in just 2 days and continue to accept contributions both big and £1-sized!


**************************************************

Three Generations of Women

A living archive documenting the experiences of women in the UK over the last 100 years, through online and face-to-face storytelling and sharing.

The overall ambition of this Broken Leg Theatre project is to complete the inspirational new play, Three Generations of Women, which aims to articulate stories from women, and then to tour it nationally.  This original play, written by Anna Jefferson and Alice Trueman, has contemporary relevance and proven wide appeal, being inspired by real-life stories researched with women who have grown up in the UK during the last 100 years.

Complementary to this, the company wants to work with hundreds more women to document their experiences, both online and face-to-face, encouraging them to find their own voice and tell their story.


The Aim

The money raised via this campaign will help us:

• To grow and develop the online archive, described by the Independent on Sunday as a ‘new digital archive that is chronicling the lives of British women over the past hundred years’. To enable tens of thousands of stories to be shared; for women to be able to easily upload audio, so they can share and listen to recordings made on their phones.

• To finish and tour the play which dramatises the differing experiences of grandmother, mother and daughter across three generations, and a family secret held as a direct response to societal expectations of women. We will work with experienced director, Kirsty Housley, to develop the production to tour it to: 

• To host forums up and down the country to continue these vital, exploratory conversations with women.

• To run creative writing workshops, encouraging women to find their voice and tell their own story.

The workshops and forums will take place in partnership with the theatres, connecting directly with audiences and engaging with the wider community.



The Story So Far

At the end of 2013, with the help of Arts Council England funding and our Co-Producer, Greenwich Theatre, we began work on Three Generations of Women, carving out a new working practice by blending storytelling with a participatory development process, working in partnership with community groups, arts organisations and local authorities to begin conversations with women across the UK. The stories shared are platformed on a highly successful interactive website which continues to grow as a living archive, with around 2000 stories submitted to date, by women ranging in age, from 16 to 82.

The website (www.threegenerationsofwomen.co.uk) and forums have so far proved a safe space where confessional stories and personal experiences are shared openly. The company feels it has planted the first seeds of a virtual and actual community where women can share their stories, and we and our partners believe that the project has the potential to become a lasting record of the social experience of three generations of women, transforming personal oral history into inspiring theatrical record. 

You can read press coverage related to the project here 


The Next Step

Building on successful industry and public showcases, and substantial media support, Broken Leg Theatre and our Co-Producer, Greenwich Theatre, embark on a national tour of Three Generations of Women, which will forge relationships with reputable venues and audiences, and develop the project's model of public engagement in tandem with the production. Interactive elements both off and onstage are at the heart of the tour, intending to catalyse and grow the community of women’s voices already invested in the project. 


The Company

Alice Trueman (www.alice-trueman.com) and Anna Jefferson (www.annajefferson.co.uk) are the co-directors and playwrights of Broken Leg Theatre and together wrote and researched 'Three Generations of Women' as well as their last, award-winning production, 'My Second Life.'

The Three Generations of Women project is working with the following all-female collaborators:

Kirsty Housley (www.kirstyhousley.co.uk) is a freelance theatre director and writer, associate director of Complicite, and works extensively in new writing and devising. Recent collaborations include Penny Dreadfuls, Theatre Uncut, Chris Goode&Co, Paines Plough and The Paper Birds. Kirsty has worked at The Young Vic, Northern Stage, The National Theatre, West Yorkshire Playhouse and The RSC. Awards include the Oxford Samuel Beckett Theatre Trust and the 2011 Northern Stage Title Pending Award.

Producer Beccy Smith (www.touchedtheatre.co.uk) is experienced developing new work, producing significant new shows for Wildspark and Stillpoint in the past year. With a background in dramaturgy she has worked with venues and companies around the UK, including on strategic tours and producing new work for Karavan Ensemble, Petras Pulse and her own company TouchedTheatre.

Our cast bring a huge breadth of experience spanning 50 years on stage, TV and radio:

Gabriella Schmidt

Emily Spetch

Moir Leslie

Gilly Daniels 


Risks & Challenges

This project invests substantially in a number of strategies for audience development as central to its overall ambitions. These initiatives are supported by strong relationships with our four primary touring venues, and build security into our ambition.

All of our strategies are designed to minimise risk.

We also included an industry standard contingency at 5% to support unexpected expenditure and matters arising along the way.


Other Ways You Can Help

We welcome any contribution, big or small, from women and from men! But if you cannot contribute financially to the campaign that doesn't mean you can't help.

The big thing is to get the word out - share this campaign, visit our website, have a read, get inspired, and ask all the important women in your life to add their stories!

Come on the journey with us - help get these voices heard.

Thank you,

Broken Leg Theatre x


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

All photos by Amy Griffin

Thanks to our Co-Producers, Greenwich Theatre, for all their support

story:
Dear MaZi Friend,
We are a team of women who love to dance! We have taken our passion a step further by performing and most of the events we do are philanthropic in nature...we volunteer via dance!

**NOTE: Once the fundraiser has closed, Mazi will e-mail you to ask which showcase date you would like to attend!

Who joins MaZi Dance Chicago (MDC)?

Many of us have previously trained or performed professionally. MDC is a way for us to continue to carry the dance torch because it's our calling! Despite our other careers or full-time jobs, we rehearse up to four times each week to learn choreography from almost every dance discipline, build our artistry, and work to be in performance shape!

Where does MDC perform?

We perform at various local events and venues, partnering with organizations around town to dance and entertain at fundraisers, fests, nursery homes, and more. We also do MaZi Dance Fitness showcases at the studio located in Wicker Park - where it all began 6 years ago this October!

Our dream?

To share our hard work and talent with YOU in a theater. We feel a weekend of dance in this setting would be an amazing and gratifying reward ... and bring us back to our performing roots!

When's the show?

We have a performance date set for Thursday & Friday, November 5th & 6th at 7:30 PM at Hamlin Park Theater!

What We Need & What You Get
We are asking for $2400 to cover:

Venue for 2 nights and tech rehearsal
Additional rehearsals with MDC choreographers
Program design and printing
Photographer and videographer
Complete costuming for +/- 20 women
The Impact
Your donation will allow us to perform in a venue we otherwise could not. We never charge for our performances, and our company monthly rates only cover studio usage and program administration. 


Risks & Challenges
We've never put together a full evening program outside of MaZi Dance Fitness walls, so this is an exciting new challenge we're ready to take on! We've worked for months - and in some cases, years!

Other Ways You Can Help
If you cannot make a monetary donation, we could use any of the following:

- If you make jewelry or costumes, we could use your help

- Share on Twitter or Facebook

- Help us spread our event fliers around town

- Reading this story...which you just did! :)

story:
Lust & Marriage is going on tour!

Hello lovelies!

I'm Eleanor O'Brien, the artistic director of Dance Naked Productions.  I've spent the last 10 years making theater about intimacy, sexuality, relationships & desire.  You may have seen my solo show GGG: Dominatrix for Dummies, or one of the ensemble productions of Inviting Desire (which I directed, performed and produced) or my newest solo show Lust & Marriage. 

I'm cuckoo for coconuts about theater that that evolves human consciousness, especially as it pertains to sexuality.  My mission is to create shows that are provocative and thought-provoking and joyful.   I believe that humans learn through storytelling, and I want to tell stories that both illuminate and celebrate our erotic lives. 

I believe Lust & Marriage is a catalyst for conversations about  love and desire.  About what happens when you open the relationship.  About whether or not it's possible to be monogamish.  The show shares an honest portrayal of the challenges and joys of living outside the box .  I think these are conversations that we should be having, especially as our cultural ideas about what marriage continue to grow and change, and one size no longer fits all (not that it ever did!). 

I now have an unprecedented opportunity to share this story with a wider audience. 

I won the CAFF lottery.  CAFF stands for Canadian Association of Fringe Festivals. (I have been applying to this lottery for the last 10 yeas).  Winning means that I get into ANY  fringe festival in Canada, which allows me to  build a summer tour.  It means  I will be able to share this show with hundreds of people across the North American, starting in Montréal and going all the way to Vancouver, BC.  I will be on tour, living out of my van,  for FOUR months!  Winning the CAFF is a big deal. 

Unfortunately, winning the lottery in this case does not mean you get in free.  I still have to pay all the entrance fees (close to $5,000!). 

(You see where this is going don't you?)  ; )

But let me give you a little background. 

In 2014 I went to Santa Fe to work with renown solo show coach Tanya Taylor Rubenstein.  I knew I wanted to create a show about polyamory (and I knew I couldn't do it alone!).  She helped me find the spine of the story.  While working on the script at Breitenbush, I met a wonderful musician (Jonah Mantranga) who created a score.  My dad drew the cartoons I used on my original set.  I workshopped  the show in Portland as part of the Fertile Ground Festival of New Work, where I learned a LOT.  

(this was the original postcard)

People seems to really respond to the show.  I got some sweet reviews, and  I was invited to bring it to Seattle, where I did a two week run at the Theatre Off-Jackson.

From Seattle I did a run in Santa Fe, and then the non-profit Sex-Positive World sponsored performances in Los Angeles, London and Brussels (where I learned that even if people don't know who Dan Savage is, the show still works!)

(btw  - I wrote Dan Savage into the show because he has longed been my go-to for advice about everything carnal.   I deeply admire his willingness to speak honestly about sexuality.  While he has not seen the show, I have his blessing on the endeavor ~ he even recorded a line for the voice-over!) 

As I've toured, I've continued to evolve and rethink and rewrite the show.  It's grown enormously from the first workshop version.

(this was the postcard I made for Seattle)

But when I won the CAFF, I knew that I would to make some major adjustments.  At 90 minutes,  Lust & Marriage was too long for the fringe format.  (Most shows are an hour).  So I brought in TJ Dawe to be my dramaturg.    TJ Dawe is a solo show artist  from Vancouver, BC.  His work is renown on the fringe circuit, and for very good reason.  He is one of the finest storytellers I've ever seen.  I saw one of his shows in 2004 (he premiers a new show almost every year)  and that show inspired me to write GGG:Dominatrix for Dummies.  I could not ask for a more perfect editor- he knows the form  incredibly well.  He has helped me hone and polish the script, pushed for me to be more honest, more vulnerable, and I am beyond grateful to have his guidance. 

I also brought in Antonio Sonera to direct my remount.   I have known Tony since I was 14 years old (when we co-starred in Cinderella Wore Combat Boots at Artists Repertory Theatre!) and he is now the artistic director of Bad Ass Theatre Company.  As a director, he lives up to that name.  He is kicking my ass in such a good way.

The icing on the cake has been having Rody Ortega, a wonderful sound designer,  add to the original soundscape that Jonah created.

Lust & Marriage is now a tight 75-minute gem of a show.  It's a love story, it's a comedy, it's an intimate look into long-term desire.

I'm really proud of it.  I think it's ready.  And I'm so excited to take it on tour.

I will start in Portland, where I"ll do 2 shows before I leave town.  (May 26th at Headwaters & May 27th at Shaking the Tree). 

Then I'll hop in my van (actually, my husband's van, which he is letting me drive across Canada, bless his heart) and I will head east across the U.S. to my first city, Montréal.

(I'm thrilled that I get to go to Quebec.  I've never been and I've romanticized it for years.  I can't wait to practice my high school french! )

After the Montéal fringe,  I head back west and perform at fringes i Toronto, Winnipeg, Edmonton and Vancouver.   I will be gone from June 3rd to September 23rd.

In August, there will be a  southern detour from Edmonton to perform Lust & Marriage at Burning Man (which is particularly awesome, since pivotal scenes take place there, and I haven't been back since 2009, and performing at Burning Man OMG!).  

(the latest postcard iteration!)

With a little luck and some good P/R - I think this show might find wings.  I hope that hundreds of people get to see it, maybe even thousands.  

But the thing is,  the expenses are mounting.  I borrowed the money (thanks Seattle fans!) to pay for the entrance fees, but that was only the beginning. 

 Even doing everything on a shoestring, and borrowing favors from everyone, I still need to raise at least $5000 to pay my co-collaborators, rent rehearsal space, buy advertising, and GET MYSELF ACROSS THE U.S. AND BACK! (Fuel ain't cheap!)

I would LOVE LOVE LOVE your help.   

If you'd like to see the show in Portland, pick the ticket perk for one of the two performances.  If you can't see it in Portland (or somewhere in Canada) pick the DVD perk and let me send you a recording.  

For all contributors, I will be sending regular updates from my trip across the continent.  (For as little as a buck, you'll get to hear the inside scoop!  Complete with pictures!)

(Oh, have i mentioned one of my side projects during this tour will be to find all the places I can get legally naked  - and dance!) 

Speaking of which -

I am launching this tour with a FREE dance party on Memorial Day (May 25th) at Collins Beach on Sauvie's Island.  I would LOVE to see you there!  (ALL of you!)   For details (and weather updates) join the facebook page.  It's going to be so much fun.  (Unless it rains.  Then we'll have to think of something else). 

I really look forward to keeping in touch with you guys while I'm on the road.  I would love to send you a postcard (or several) from the wilds of Canada (or the wilder Burning Man!).

And when I get back,  I'd be delighted to see you at one of my shows, or my sex & creativity workshops, or perhaps I'll perform live for your private event ! (see perks).

I'm humbled and grateful for all of your help and assistance.  You make it possible for me to create the kind of theater that changes and challenges the entrenched views about culture and sexuality, one audience member at a time. 

You guys, we are making the world a more juicy, joyful place!  THANK YOU!!

So much love,

Eleanor

Eleanor O'Brien
Dance Naked Productions, artistic director

(A big shout-out to photographer Lloyd Lemmerman for all the photos!)
story_txt:
Lust & Marriage is going on tour!Hello lovelies! 
I'm Eleanor O'Brien, the artistic director of Dance Naked Productions.  I've spent the last 10 years making theater about intimacy, sexuality, relationships & desire.  You may have seen my solo show GGG: Dominatrix for Dummies, or one of the ensemble productions of Inviting Desire (which I directed, performed and produced) or my newest solo show Lust & Marriage.  I'm cuckoo for coconuts about theater that that evolves human consciousness, especially as it pertains to sexuality.  My mission is to create shows that are provocative and thought-provoking and joyful.   I believe that humans learn through storytelling, and I want to tell stories that both illuminate and celebrate our erotic lives.  I believe Lust & Marriage is a catalyst for conversations about   love and desire.  About what happens when you open the relationship.  About whether or not it's possible to be monogamish.  The show shares an honest portrayal of the challenges and joys of living outside the box .  I think these are conversations that we should be having, especially as our cultural ideas about what marriage continue to grow and change, and one size no longer fits all (not that it ever did!).  I now have an unprecedented opportunity to share this story with a wider audience.   I won the CAFF lottery. 
 CAFF stands for Canadian Association of Fringe Festivals. (I have been 
applying to this lottery for the last 10 yeas).  Winning means that I get into ANY  fringe festival in Canada, which allows me to  build a 
summer tour.  It means  I will be able to share this show with hundreds of people across the North American, starting in Montréal and going all the way to Vancouver, BC.  I will be on tour, living out of my van,  for FOUR months!  Winning the CAFF is a big deal.  
Unfortunately, winning the lottery in this case does not mean you get in
 free.  I still have to pay all the entrance fees (close to $5,000!).  (You see where this is going don't you?)  ; )But let me give you a little background.  In 2014 I went to Santa Fe to work with renown solo show coach Tanya Taylor Rubenstein.  I knew I wanted to create a show about polyamory (and I knew I couldn't do it alone!).  She helped me find the spine of the story.  While working on the script at Breitenbush, I met a wonderful musician (Jonah Mantranga) who created a score.  My dad drew the cartoons I used on my original set.  I workshopped  the show in Portland as part of the Fertile Ground Festival of New Work, where I learned a LOT.   
(this was the original postcard)People seems to really respond to the show.  I got some sweet reviews, and  I was invited to bring it to Seattle, where I did a two week run at the Theatre Off-Jackson. From Seattle I did a run in Santa Fe, and then the non-profit Sex-Positive World sponsored performances in Los Angeles, London and Brussels (where I learned that even if people don't know who Dan Savage is, the show still works!) (btw  - I wrote Dan Savage
 into the show because he has longed been my go-to for advice about 
everything carnal.   I deeply admire his willingness to speak honestly about sexuality.  While he has not seen the show, I have his blessing on the endeavor ~ he 
even recorded a line for the voice-over!)  As I've toured, I've continued to evolve and rethink and rewrite the show.  It's grown enormously from the first workshop version. 
(this was the postcard I made for Seattle)But when I won the CAFF, I knew that I would to make some major adjustments.  At 90 minutes,  Lust & Marriage was too long for the fringe format.  (Most shows are an hour).  So I brought in TJ Dawe to be my dramaturg.    TJ Dawe is a solo show 
artist  from Vancouver, BC.  His work is renown on the fringe circuit, and for very good reason.  He is one of the finest storytellers I've ever seen.  I saw one of his shows in 2004 (he premiers a new show almost every year) 
 and that show inspired me to write GGG:Dominatrix for Dummies. 
I could not ask for a more perfect editor- he knows the form  incredibly well.  He has helped me hone and polish the script, pushed for me to be more honest, more vulnerable, and I am beyond grateful to have his guidance.  I also brought in Antonio Sonera to direct my remount.   I have known Tony since I was 14 years old (when we co-starred in Cinderella Wore Combat Boots at Artists Repertory Theatre!) and he is now the artistic director of Bad Ass Theatre Company.  As a director, he lives up to that name.  He is kicking my ass in such a good way.The icing on the cake has been having Rody Ortega, a wonderful sound designer,  add to the original soundscape that Jonah created.Lust & Marriage is now a tight 75-minute gem of a show.  It's a love story, it's a comedy, it's an intimate look into long-term desire.I'm really proud of it.  I think it's ready.  And I'm so excited to take it on tour.I will start in Portland, where I"ll do 2 shows before I leave town.  (May 26th at Headwaters & May 27th at Shaking the Tree).  Then I'll hop in my van (actually, my husband's van, which he is letting me drive across Canada, bless his heart) and I will head east across the U.S. to my first city, Montréal.(I'm thrilled that I get to go to Quebec.  I've never been and I've romanticized it for years.  I can't wait to practice my high school french! )After the Montéal fringe,  I head back west and perform at fringes i Toronto, Winnipeg, Edmonton and Vancouver.   I will be gone from June 3rd to September 23rd. story:
Boomer's Story

Vertigo gives undergraduate playwrights the opportunity to have their original scripts realized into full-fledged productions. By producing student-written theatre, Vertigo hopes to be a creative and dynamic presence on campus, encouraging students to take artistic risk. 

Vertigo is the only student theatre organization on campus that produces entirely student-written work. We strive for our shows to live beyond Northwestern. 

Vertigo was founded in 1994. That makes us 19 years old!

Why Boomer's Story

Boomer's Story, written by junior Max Abner, is an adventure from start to finish. In attempts to get his beautiful cowboy boots back to his Pa, Boomer finds himself in his greatest adventure yet. From guns, love, and outlaws, Boomer leaves the country to head to Citytown in order to get his stolen books back. 

Your donation to this show would go towards making student written theatre come to life, and opportunities to people in all areas of theatre to test their limits and discover new passions. 

What is the money for?

All donations are for major design elements in order to make the show happen.

Sets: Sophomore, Kenzie Smith. In her first full set design on Northwestern's campus, Kenzie is working on making different background drops, paint, and antique pieces to make the Wild West come alive in the historical Shanley Pavilion.
Lights: Sophomore, Prateek Singh. In his first role as an autonomous lighting designer, Prateek is working towards highlighting each scene to help shift between locations, and blur the lines between fiction and reality. 
Sound: Sophomore, Juliet Roll. Juliet is taking an exciting approach to the sound design of the show and is working towards making any sounds made in the space during a show live. This means that she is working with the band and sound-specific objects to highlight the chaos in Boomer's world.
Props: Sophomore, Nick Tiffany. There is no way to create the Wild West without GUNS. Every prop in this play is chosen to represent the rugged landscape and live that the characters live. 
Costumes: Sophomore, Lindsay Ewell. Lindsay is working to create different outfits and looks to help distinguish between multiple characters played by a few actors. By choosing a base look, she is looking towards looks that can be detailed and redefined to show the shift of time and characters through the story.
Music: Sophomore, Nina Jayashankar. An exciting development in our production is the use of a live folk band. Nina is working with the musicians to transport the audience into the Wild West through classic folk tunes.

The Cast

Adam Orme Rope/Flask/Cactus Boy/Accordion
Anna Basile Clementine/Fish-Stick
Garrett Hanson Boomer
Grace Elizabeth Hamilton-Vargo Spider/Gunman/Lackey
Lukas Arnold Westerner 1/Bear/Gavel
Marcellus Burt Western 3/Mr. Bullet/Blues Singer
Peter Vilim Westerner 2/Donald
Tess Musky-Goldwyn
Noah Goldstein		 Delia/Clarke/Cactus/Fan
Musician

Production and Team

Devyn Johnson Producer
Lucy Farnsworth Assistant Producer
Kenzie Smith Set Designer
Jessica Baldinger Assistant Set Designer
Juliet Roll Sound Designer
Nick Tiffany Props Designer
Claire Glubiak Assistant Props Designer
Tristan Chiruvolu Graphics Designer
Prateek Singh Lighting Designer
Lindsay Ewell Costume Designer
Liz Kang Fundraising Director
Will Altabef
Dawn Rafel		 Publicity Director
Publicity Director

Rehearsal Team

Shaina Wagner Director
Gabby Sant'Anna Assistant Director
Gabriela Leal Stage Manager
Grant Lewis Assistant Stage Manager
Nina Jayashankar Music Director

Showtimes

Thursday, October 29th at 8 pm

Friday, October 30th at 8 & 11 pm

Saturday, October 31st at 2 and 8 pm


Location:

Boomer's Story will be performed in the historic Shanley Pavilion located at 2031 Sheridan Road, Evanston, IL


Tickets:

Tickets are available at the door. $5 for Northwestern Students and $10 for General Public.


If you are unable to contribute monetarily, you can also help us out by sharing this link! We appreciate all of your support!

story:
In Summer of 2018, Woodzick was cast in Nirvamlet, produced by Band of Toughs. They played Laertes in this Nirvana/Hamlet mash-up, and wrote an original song for Laertes to sing over Opehlia's grave before the big ol' fight with Hamlet. 

When they thought about what they wanted to do for their final project for their Shakespeare in Community class at CU Boulder, they decided it might be cool to write the rest of Laertes' album and imagine a world in which Ophelia goes on tour with Laertes and doesn't fricking die. As they began writing the show, they decided instead of playing Laertes, they wanted to play a dragged up Ophelia and make the character a queer performance artist and filmmaker.

To make sure everything sounded super awesome, they collaborated with powerhouse singer/songwriter Jules Murtha. 

In this rock and roll re-telling of the Hamlet narrative, Ophelia is inspired by the aesthetic of Amy Winehouse. We hope to premiere this show at the inaugural Denver Fringe Festival. Even if we're not selected in that lottery, we know in our heart of creative hearts that this show has legs and are committed to producing it locally within the year. 

Your contributions will help us to produce the album and the world-premiere production. Any money above and beyond the first $2,000 will help us put our original music on Spotify for all to hear and help us tour the show to fringe festivals around the country. 

Album art by Max Cole-Takanikos. https://www.maxcoletakanikos.com/

story:
The Mascher Space Cooperative seeks to raise $3,000.00 for our Fresh Juice 2021 Artists-In-Residence Showcase. This money will be used to cover overhead costs such as rental fees for the park, sound system, event insurance, and equipment fees, as well as direct compensation for all artists involved. Use of the park has already been approved and our artists are hard at work finalizing the pieces they plan to present. The event is free to the public with a "Pay What You Can" donation model. 

Mascher Space Cooperative is a home for new dance in Philadelphia. Artist imagined, artist founded, artist shared and run, Mascher is a nonprofit that provides affordable and versatile space. We are a community of support that cultivates deep problem solving and artistic inquiry in continuing our practices. Bound not by aesthetics, but a common commitment to working cooperatively and sharing tasks and resources, Mascher nurtures the development of all its members at various stages in their careers, lines of research, and explorations.

​2020 was a difficult year for arts organizations in the Philadelphia region. Many organizations, including Mascher, saw funding disappear and many have struggled to continue operations. In the Fall of 2020 the Mascher Space Cooperative made the difficult decision to leave our home on Germantown Avenue in the hopes of meeting the moment head on. Due in-part to the financial difficulties brought on by the COVID-19 pandemic Mascher entered into a partnership with Headlong Studios and Ninth Planet during the fall of 2020, and now shares space and resources at 1170 S Broad St in South Philadelphia.

Heading into the summer of 2021, the Mascher Space Cooperative has regrouped and is in the midst of preparing our 2021 Fresh Juice Artist-in-Residence Showcase! For the last 13 years Mascher has hosted Fresh Juice as a way to highlight and support the evolving work of our artists-in-residence, and this year is no different! On June 26th @ 12:00pm in Hawthorne Park, our 2020-2021 class of Artists-in-Residence will be presenting new and in-progress work that they have been developing over the last year. We are so excited to share the many dimensions of performance that our wonderful artists bring to the table. 

Now we need your help! Any amount of support that you are willing to provide is a TAX DEDUCTIBLE gift and we are immensely thankful for your support. We so appreciate your willingness to engage with our work, and we look forward to sharing these unbelievable performances with you! Check out the line-up of pieces below for a sneak peek at what to expect on June 26th:

 

Waterfall

Choreographer: Rachel DeForrest Repinz

Performer: Catherine Westerduin

Group: Poeético Dance Collective

Original score: Tom Anthony

A solo dance work designed for film and recently transcribed to stage. It will debut at Fresh Juice. The piece was conceived during lockdown as an exploration of “going with the flow.” 

 

Free Fleet

By Free Fleet

 

Born on the 4th of July

Written and performed by Jay Kimberley

What does it mean to be a statistic? Life as a Ward of the State. 

 

Mi Shebeirach

Choreographer: Olivia Jenna Brown

Dancers: Olivia Jenna Brown, Sarah Owens, Kate Pellegrini, Heather Robinson, Catherine Westerduin

Group: Poético Dance Collective

Music: "Mi Shebeirach," performed on piano by David Syme of the Center for Performing Arts Medicine.

Costumes: Olivia Jenna Brown in collaboration with the dancers

The Mi Shebeirach is the Jewish prayer for healing: healing of mind, body, and soul. As some places in the world begin to emerge from the depths of the Covid-19 pandemic, while others continue to suffer its devastation, the Mi Shebeirach prayer feels timely and necessary. Just as the Jewish prayer invokes hope for wholeness amidst illness and loss, this piece expresses hope for a global refuah shlema—a complete recovery, or complete renewal. May we all be inspired to live courageously in the face of suffering, and to consider how, despite loss, we might “make our lives a blessing.”

 

Mountain of 1

Choreographer/Director: Katarina Poljak

Performer: Katarina Poljak

Music: “O’ My daughter, O’ my Sorrow “ by William Basinski 

Additional Sound Design: Katarina Poljak

Brains engineered for gore.  Reality traded for a chance to be adored from a curatorial distance. A pseudo realism, where everything is a high definition performance catering to the highest common denominator of coded personalities. A culture of efficiency. A culture of disposability. ...But I still loved you.

 

THIS SMOKE

Choreographer/Performer: Paule Turner, Duchess

Music: Johann Sebastian Bach -- "Preludio Partita No. 3 for Violin in E major, BWV 1006.1

Costume: Paule Turner, Duchess

As some places in the world begin to emerge from the depths of the Covid-19 pandemic, while others continue to suffer its devastation, the Mi Shebeirach prayer feels timely and necessary. Just as the Jewish prayer invokes hope for wholeness amidst illness and loss, this piece expresses hope for a global refuah shlema—a complete recovery, or complete renewal. May we all be inspired to live courageously in the face of suffering, and to consider how, despite loss, we might “make our lives a blessing.” Mountain of 1Choreographer/Director: Katarina PoljakPerformer: Katarina PoljakMusic: “O’ My daughter, O’ my Sorrow “ by William Basinski Additional Sound Design: Katarina PoljakBrains engineered for gore.  Reality traded for a chance to be adored from a curatorial distance. A pseudo realism, where everything is a high definition performance catering to the highest common denominator of coded personalities. A culture of efficiency. A culture of disposability. ...But I still loved you. THIS SMOKEChoreographer/Performer: Paule Turner, DuchessMusic: Johann Sebastian Bach -- "Preludio Partita No. 3 for Violin in E major, BWV 1006.1Costume: Paule Turner, Duchess

story:
SUPPORT WORSE THAN TIGERS' NYC PREMIERE

***Thanks to direct donations not reflected in this page's total we are currently at our goal! However, we still have a small deficit off $500 to cover. Can you help us?****

THE PLAY

Olivia and Humphry have a safe, comfortable, enviable life. Their condo is well-adorned with fancy knick-knacks, their social media presence is meticulously groomed, and they never fight. Or laugh. Or kiss. Or talk very much.

Unexpectedly, Olivia’s lover-- id-driven Officer Kirk Patrick --shows up, trailing a man-eating tiger which takes up residence right outside, threatening to devour anyone who opens the door. Tigers may be dangerous, but there might be something worse inside.

The Mill makes its debut at the legendary New Ohio with the NYC premiere of Mark Chrisler's play. 

THE STORY

Five years ago, at the urging of our mutual friends, I reached out to Mark Chrisler to find out more about his work. I've known Mark since our undergraduate days at NIU and as a peer in the Chicago theater community. I wasn't' familiar with his plays but had heard from many different folks that they were extraordinary. He sent me Worse Than Tigers and I was completely blown away. Doing a delicate dance between Realism and Absurdism the play was as hilarious as it was heartbreaking and I was determined to get it on stage.

Then my life took a strange turn. I was offered a job in TV/FILM production and I couldn't say no. The job offer was completely unexpected, and I felt it was an amazing opportunity if only I could stop weeping over the thought of leaving the theatre! Fast forward three years, an Emmy and a Peabody nomination later, I couldn't stop missing the theatre. The stars aligned and my dream of assisting Tony award-winning director, and my mentor, Anna Shapiro came true! Then, the kind and generous Robert Lyons, my boss at the New Ohio, offered me a slot there and again, more of my dreams were coming true. After a three year break, I would be back in the saddle, directing again. I couldn't be more thrilled to be producing and directing the NYC premiere of this play.

In order to accomplish this, I've assembled three of my all-time favorite actors (Shannon Marie Sullivan, Braeson Herold, and Zach Wegner) as well as a brilliant team of designers and technicians (Matt Carlin, Kate Ducey, Kristy Hall, Caspin Jones, Nat Di Marco, AJ Surasky).

...but making theatre in NYC (like doing anything in NYC) isn't cheap.

I need your help to raise $6500 to make the show possible

The overall budget for this show is $11,500. 

The Mill has $2000 in the bank and we expect $2500 in ticket revenue. Leaving a $6500 gap.

Most of the shows budget, $7000, goes towards paying the folks who are making it happen, the actors, designers, and technicians -- who all deserve much more than the modest stipends we can afford but are so committed to the project, they are willing to donate much of their time and energy.

The other $3500 covers the cost of the set, props, and costumes.

Leaving just a $500 deficit.

The Impact of your contribution

I truly can't make this play happen without your help. The only way that new plays exist is through the support and contributions of private donors and foundations. Without a significant producing history in NY state, receiving grant money for The Mill is almost impossible. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Come see the show! Buy tix here.

Like The Mill's Facebook and Instagram. 

LET OTHERS KNOW ABOUT THIS CAMPAIGN.

Contributions to this project are fully tax deductible because of The Mill Theatre's 501C3 Status.  If you know anyone who likes supporting the arts, or who needs another charitable deduction for their tax return, send them our way!

We want people to come and see this show, so if you can talk up Worse Than Tigers or create buzz by mentioning us on Facebook or Twitter we would greatly appreciate it!

The Creative Team

Mark Chrisler (Playwright) is a playwright, monologist and podcaster whose work includes Worse Than Tigers, Teatime at Golgotha, The Art of Painting and Phonies Frauds and Fakes: A Play That is Absolutely Not About My Ex-Girlfriend. His plays have been developed and produced at ACT, The Milwaukee Repertory Theatre, The Stella Adler Studio, Ilkhom Theatre, the side project, A Red Orchid and many more. He's published by Broadway Play Publishing and Smith and Krauss and holds an MFA in playwriting from Ohio University. He also writes, produces and hosts The Constant: A History of Getting Things Wrong, a non-fiction podcast about exactly what it says it is.

Jaclyn Biskup (Director) is a director and producer working in theatre, television, and film. She is the recipient of an Emmy and Peabody nomination for her work on the digital series, THE SECRET LIFE OF MUSLIMS and currently works as an associate producer at New Ohio Theatre. She is the assistant to Tony Award-winning director Anna Shapiro on the Broadway debut of STRAIGHT WHITE MEN (Young Jean Lee) for Second Stage at the Helen Hayes.  Her work in the theatre spans nearly two decades. As the founding artistic director of The Mill, she has directed and produced over 20 productions including the Chicago premieres of VENUS (Suzan-Lori Parks) and THE PRIVATE OF LIVES OF ESKIMOS (OR 16 WORDS FOR SNOW) (Ken Urban.) In NYC, work directed includes NICHOLAS, MAEVE, MARIANNE (Matthew Stephen Smith) one of Indie Theatre Now's 20 Best of NYC Fringe, HOT STEAMS (Zach Wegner), and IT’S JUST WEIRD NOW (Halley Feiffer). Her work has been seen at MCC, Rattlestick, Dixon Place, and the NYC International Fringe. She has assisted on productions at Steppenwolf, The Public, and The American Musical Theatre Workshop.  She has worked on digital projects for PBS NOVA, Delta Air Lines, Caltech, and Harvard. BA in Theater from Northern Illinois University, MFA in Directing and Theatrical Production from Northwestern University.

The Mill was founded in 2002 by artistic director, Jaclyn Biskup, as Experimental Theatre Chicago.  After the company evolved and broadened its scope, the name was changed to represent its new mission: to produce plays progressive in form and content.  Biskup’s father worked at US Steel -- unaffectionately dubbed ‘The Mill,’ for over thirty years and the name is an homage to him and her family’s south side of Chicago working class roots. The Mill is known for its stylish energetic stagings and bold theatricality including the Chicago premieres of VENUS (Suzan-Lori Parks) and THE PRIVATE OF LIVES OF ESKIMOS (OR 16 WORDS FOR SNOW) (Ken Urban) and in NYC, NICHOLAS, MAEVE, MARIANNE (Matthew Stephen Smith) one of Indie Theatre Now's 20 Best of NYC Fringe.

New Ohio Theatre is a two-time OBIE Award-winning performance venue that serves the vast independent theatre community of New York and the adventurous audiences who love them. As a small, downtown, artist-run organization with a twenty-plus year history as a beacon for bold and inventive work, we know the challenges and rewards of producing and presenting alternative, groundbreaking theatre. In any given year, there are over 500 independent theatre companies working for opportunities to develop and present new work. We believe the best of this community operates at the core of the contemporary theatre conversation (about both content and form) and acts collectively to expand the boundaries of the public imagination. With our move to Christopher Street, we aim to establish a professional, high-profile platform for the independent theatre community, reestablishing the West Village as a destination for mature, ridiculous, engaged, irreverent, gut-wrenching, frivolous, sophisticated, foolish, and profound theatrical endeavors.

story:
the company

Established in 2005, Purple Crayon Players is an award-winning student theatre company at Northwestern University committed to producing theatre for young audiences. PCP seeks to create thought-provoking smart and entertaining theatre for young audiences, which we believe is theatre for all audiences!

the show

What if you could escape the chaos of a busy, scheduled life to the quiet of Nothing?

After his teacher mentions the universe is growing, the constantly busy Simon Ives becomes obsessed with the idea of discovering this Edge - the place between nothing and everything, where he can just be. Simon dreams of going to a place where no one needs him to do anything.

Meanwhile, at the Edge of Everything is a boy who longs for someone to need him to do something. He seems to have done everything, and even redoes everything, but longs for company.

When Simon is rocketed into space (through an unlikely series of events involving “lots and lots of fireworks”), their worlds collide and neither will ever be the same.

the donation

Your donation would be instrumental in helping us make this show happen, and we couldn't achieve this without your help. Although we are affiliated with Northwestern University and Purple Crayon Players, this production is entirely student run, which means that we are responsible for raising the funds to build our set, rent our lights, buy costumes and props, and more.

Here are some of the ways your donation would help us: 

Buying lumber, furniture, paint, and more to build the set that will serve as the world of the play

Making and buying period-specific costumes for our cast to wear

Obtaining props from thrift stores, rental markets, supermarkets, or wherever else

Renting lighting and sound equipment as well as projection equipment

Helping us advertise the show so our message can reach as many people as possible

…and more!

the cast 

Tom DeFrancisco the Boy at the Edge; Martin Downs Simon; David Brown Louie/Artie; John MacGaffey Dad/Michael; Emily Wills Mom/Chloe/Ms Chester

purple crayon players

Lucy Ahlborn executive director; Khari Shelton artistic director; Sally Lindel production manager; Drew Guerra business manager; Emilly Wills outreach coordinator; Maddie Napel marketing director; Nick Raef technical director; Lisa Wiznitzer literary manager; Alex Goodman stage management chair; Rachel Leshin special events chair; Rebecca Elowe special events chair; Delaney Burlingame tour manager; Allie Hagen tour manager; Nikki Rosengren team education; Katherine Scott team education; Daphna Weinstock team education; Izzy Garcia the crayon

the team

Brandon Nadig producer; Myrna Conn assistant producer; Elsa Gay director; Eloia Petrson stage manager; Dylan Reyno set designer; Tatyana Aravena set designer; Jane Dickerson scenic painter;  Melissa McSweeney associate scenic painter; Austin Appel technical director; Matthew Kresch lighting designer; Izzy Porte assistant lighting designer; Mari Uchida assistant lighting designer; Geoff Ko master electrician; Lizzy Wigley costume designer; Emily Baldwin props/puppets/universe designer; Delaney Burlingame props/puppets/universe designer; Alex Dayton assistant props/puppets/universe designer; Rachel Stamler Jonas assistant props/puppets/universe designer; Ari Shapiro sound designer; Thomas Molash assistant sound designer; Jack Eidson off-campus marketing director; Kate Leggett on-campus marketing director; Mahek Tulsiani fundraising director; Ellen Ehrsam outreach director; Sophia Carbonell assistant outreach; Collin Quinn Rice graphic designer

come see the show!

The Boy at the Edge of Everything goes up at McCormick Auditorium, which is located in Norris University Center, from October 23rd to October 25th. We'd love to see you at the show! Tickets are only $5 for Northwestern students, $10 for the general public, and free for everyone under 18!

story:
Who Are We?

We are a group of eight sixteen and seventeen year-olds, who are all passionate about great theatre, through Aberdeen Performing Arts we were given the opportunity to work as part of an exchange with The American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco. While in the states we worked with playwright Timothy Mason, on a new play (The Life To Come) which was commissioned by APA and ACT for the group. APA has set us the fundraising goal of £7000, half of which we’ve already raised we’ve already held events such as our Blind Date with a Book night and our coffee morning.

What We Need and What You Get?

We still have to raise £3,500, this will help cover the cost of the flights and other expenses from the trip. as well as helping us put on "The Life To Come" on the 14th 15th and 16th of January. We hope to update our perks regularly and add more as the campaign progresses, we’ll also be doing more fundraising events in the coming months.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t donate to the campaign, or even if you can, please share our events on social media, such as Facebook and Twitter, you can do this easily by using the Indiegogo share tools, and keep talking about us using our hashtag ‘‪#‎lifetocome‬’.

 

Exchange Exhibition

We're hosting an Exhibition at 17 Belmont Street, Aberdeen selling art from local, national, international artists. see our 'Perk' for more details.
