story:
Who We Are?

We are a growing group of artists in our second year of production, passionate about asking life's big questions and engaging in meaningful dialogue with the community.  Last year, our production of Freud's Last Session won the 2016 Hawaii State Theatre Council Po‘okela Awards for Outstanding Overall Production, Outstanding Director, and Outstanding Guest Artist.  This year, we are excited  to bring you The Last Days of Judas Iscariot.

What's the Story?

Hailed by Time magazine and Entertainment Weekly as among the best plays of the year, Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Stephen Adly Guirgis unleashes his incendiary language and style upon Judas Iscariot, the Bible’s most notorious sinner.  Presented as a riveting and riotous courtroom drama in the depths of purgatory, The Last Days of Judas Iscariot is an irresistible examination of human free will and divine mercy.  Judas features a wild cast of characters – Mother Teresa, Pontius Pilate, Sigmund Freud, even Satan himself – to ask the question, “What happened to Judas Iscariot?”  This fiercely ambitious work explores the consequences of faith, guilt and despair, alongside the boundaries of forgiveness and grace.  Contains strong adult language.

What We Need? 

First things first...THANK YOU!

Thank you for your incredible generosity!

During our initial campaign we received over $2,500.  Counting these funds, we have now raised over $15,000 toward our overall funding goal of $25,000.  While the May 1st deadline for our first Indiegogo campaign has passed, we believe that should move forward in planning for the launch of this production.

Our hope is to raise $5,000 in the next 60 days toward fully funding this production.  In order to do that, we’ve set a small funding goal of only $500, trusting that this will double or triple or multiply more than ten times. 

We so appreciate your generosity and will continue to offer some great perks, including: free beverages at concessions, a book about the original Off-Broadway production, complimentary tickets, a sneak peak of a dress rehearsal, and even an invitation to our gala celebration.  And we’ve included a “Secret Perk” for those contributing $25 or more.  So drop a few dollars into our “piggybank,” grab yourself a perk and we’ll see you at the show!

Risks & Challenges?

This is a step of faith.  We have secured the royalty rights to the show.  We have cast some of the best actors available to appear in it.  We are preparing contracts for actors and designers.  We have set the dates for our three weekends of performance.  But, in essence, our “piggybank” to fund the production is still needing a big boost.

The show is ON!  Will you join us in this step of faith?

Other Ways You Can Help?

We are always looking for people who might be able to volunteer their time to assist in the production process itself.  We will need ushers at each performance and others to help at our concessions area.  We will need extra hands to install the set and just as many hands to tear it down at the end of our production.  Please email theatrefound@yahoo.com if you’d like to join us!

for people who might be able to volunteer their time to assist in the production process itself.  We will need ushers at each performance and others to help at our concessions area.  We will need extra hands to install the set and just as many hands to tear it down at the end of our production.  Please email theatrefound@yahoo.com if you’d like to join us!

story:
Scherzo Theatre Company is officially bringing YARN to the 2018 Hollywood Fringe Festival this June!  As with any creative venture, putting a show up requires time, energy, effort, and money.  Luckily, we have the first three covered.  Unluckily, we don't have the fourth covered.  But... we have you!  

What we ask is simple: If you have a couple hundred bucks lying around, or maybe just a fifty, or even just a few bills, or - who knows? - 3 coins, please consider passing them along to us.  In exchange, you can receive some pretty cool & unique rewards!  And, at the end of the day, you can go to bed knowing you helped foster some art.  

Why should you donate, you ask?  Simple - because we, as a theatre company, believe that not all theatre should be living-room dramas.  Not to say there's anything wrong with those.  But we believe that audience members deserve to have a choice when going to see theatre.  And, if you want to continue seeing people stuffed in trunks, talking balloons, and suspicious tea parties, well, you know what to do.  

Just to be completely transparent of where your donations will go, here are the costs we have to tackle: 
1. Theatre Rental Fees 
2. Stage Management Fees 
3. Set Design Fees (Yes - we are creating a new set for this iteration!) 
4. Prop Fees (Someone keeps eating all the dum-dums...)  
5. Fringe Registration Fees

If we end up with any money left over, those proceeds will go to start up costs for creating a new show.    

We understand that not everyone is able to donate.  If that's the case, that's okay - just come see the show in June!  If you saw the first showing of it at the Electric Lodge, come back!  The show will not be the same show you saw in November.  If you didn't see the first showing, it's your lucky day - you have the chance to see it!  

If you've made it this far through reading this, we have one thing left to say:
Thank you.  

Scherzo Theatre Company
Adam Dlugolecki 
Jakob Berger 
Kent Jenkins 
Katie McDowell

story:
The play:

Peter Sisk is a Protestant minister turned real estate lawyer. His wife Catherine is a social worker who wants grandchildren. Their daughter Marian is a Protestant minister who has gotten pregnant after having affair with a parishioner. She decides to have an abortion against the opposition of her mother.  As a result, Catherine decides to adopt the baby of one of her clients, a single teen age girl. Peter opposes this. He has his own "child." He wants to limit his work in real estate law and buy land, then develop housing for the homeless.

 

Why crowdfund?

Producing theatre in New York is not easy. It is very expensive. A small Equity Showcase production can cost up to $30,000. It if person has deep pockets, he or she can fund the production without outside help. Our pockets are not that deep. We are crowdfunding because we truly believe in this play. It deals with many pressing issues of our time such as abortion, gay marriage, interracial relationships, and faith, both religious and personal. We believe this play makes a statement about these issues, looking at them in a revisionist way that is not often seen in New York theatre. With your help, we will be able to bring this timely work to a larger audience.

 

Where will the money go?

  • Theatre rent (3-4 weeks) and insurance- $10,000
  • Rehearsal space-$5,000
  • Salaries-$5,000
  • Sets/Props-$2,000
  • Costumes-$2,000
  • Lights-$2,000
  • Advertising/Public Relations-$2,500
  • Miscellaneous -$1,500

The production will cost $30,000. We are working towards raising $20,000 of this amount online, through Indiegogo. If you would like to support the production through a tax deductible donation sent by mail, please see instructions at the bottom of this page. 

 

Who are we?

We are John Attanas, Lisa Tracy, and Jonathan Fluck. We met through Interborough Repertory Theatre (IRT), which Jonathan co-founded and ran from 1986 to 2006. Through IRT, Jonathan produced, directed, and acted in over fifty shows, from Equity showcases to traveling shows for children, including directing four of John’s plays on Theatre Row. Lisa joined IRT in 1992 and appeared in numerous IRT Productions on Theatre Row. John came to IRT through Lisa, joined the company in 1993, and had six of his plays produced between 1993-2000.

 

Are gifts tax deductible?

Donations made online are not tax deductible. If you would like a tax deduction, please make your donations by check. Make the check out to IRT, and send it to IRT, c/o John Attanas, 68-49 Loubet Street, Forest Hills, NY 11375. IRT is a not-for-profit organization. All contributions are tax deductible to the full extent of the law.

story:
Your favorite RTW gals are at it again!

For those of you who don't know us and for those of you who do and need a little reminder, we are Renaissance Theaterworks, Milwaukee's ONLY professional, nonprofit theater company dedicated to PROMOTING THE WORK OF WOMEN onstage and off. We are also the nation's second oldest theater company with the unique mission to promote gender parity.

OUR MISSION: Dedicated to promoting the work of women onstage and off, Renaissance Theaterworks creates moving theater that connects with our shares sense of being human.

 

So why are we here on Indiegogo? Well friends, we have some EXCITING NEWS! For the second time in less than 5 years, Renaissance Theaterworks will participate in the Samuel French Off Off Broadway Short Play Festival (OOB) in New York City. 

Our 2018 Br!NK New Play Festival included a production of the haunting and heartbreaking short play ALL OF THE EVERYTHING. Written by Minnesota native, Alayna Jacqueline, ALL OF THE EVERYTHING begins with a young African American couple out for a drive, where the woman begins to manipulate time in order to experience their entire future before they reach the destination that changes their lives forever.

(Photo from the 2018 Br!NK New Play Festival performance of ALL OF THE EVERYTHING)

After its successful premiere at Br!NK, RTW encouraged Alayna to submit ALL OF THE EVERYTHING to the OOB Festival. From over 900 initial submissions, Alayna has earned a place as a semi-finalist in the top 30. As a direct result of her experience with Br!NK, Alayna has asked RTW to produce and direct her short play this coming August in NYC. We are honored she has asked us to participate and thrilled to accept this amazing opportunity!

ALL OF THE EVERYTHING will perform on Friday, August 23rd, 2019 at 7:00 PM at the Vineyard Dimson 15th Street Theatre, NYC. Following the performances of the top 30 semi-finalists, 12 finalists will be selected to perform again on Saturday, August 24th, 2019. Of those 12, the six festival winners will be announced on Saturday evening. These winners will have their short play published in the Off Off Broadway Short Play Festival series, which is licensed and published by Samuel French, Inc. This will be RTW’s second trip to OOB. In 2015, RTW produced LUCKY NUMBERS by Gwendolyn Rice and made it to the final 12.This time we aim to win!

The National Stage

For Playwright, Alayna Jacqueline, this opportunity is life changing! The Samuel French Off Off Broadway Short Play Festival offers a prize of publication and licensing for six short plays in the notable OFF OFF BROADWAY FESTIVAL PLAYS series. This year, from over 900 initial submissions, 30 semifinalist plays were chosen and will be performed over a week at the Vineyard’s Dimson Theatre. At the end of the OOB Festival, the six finalists will be named.

(Playwright Alayna Jacqueline)

For Renaissance, producing at the OOB Festival is the opportunity of a lifetime. Participation will give us valuable industry insight, increase our national profile, and add distinction to our reputation. The OOB Festival features work from some of the freshest playwrights in the country. It’s a chance to bring our work to a larger stage and show off the quality theater we produce in Milwaukee.

In addition, there are many networking opportunities to promote Br!NK, Renaissance Theaterworks’ New Play Development Series. Aspiring playwrights, artistic directors, and other industry professionals come from across the country to attend. We can promote the 2020 Br!NK New Play Festival by encouraging playwrights to submit their work. We will reach a much larger group of artists than is currently possible, and expose ourselves to new ideas and practices.

Guess What? We need YOUR help to make this happen!

This is an incredible opportunity to showcase our world-class productions and promote the work of an emerging playwright on a national stage. We have created a lean budget for this project. We need to transport and house ten people in NYC (4 actors, director, stage manager, 2 producers, carpenter, and playwright). We provide our artists with a small stipend for this two week commitment.

Total Cost = $12,500

  • $6,500 =  A VRBO condo that can accommodate up to 10 people.
  • $3,000 = Air fare for 10
  • $1,000 = Production costs. Costumes, sound design, rehearsal space rental, and props.
  •  $1,000 = A $500 stipend for the director and stage manager
  •  $1,000 = A $250 stipend for each actor, 4 actors total 

What your producing dollars do:

  • $250 covers the stipend for one actor
  • $500 pays for all of our props & costumes
  • $1,000 covers the stipend for all 4 actors
  • $3,000 covers the airfare MKE – NYC
  • $6,500 underwrites the condo (which includes a kitchen!)
  • $12,500 covers the whole shebang!

(RTW's Trip to NYC in 2015 with Gwendolyn Rice's short play LUCKY NUMBERS)

Your Dollar’s Impact

As our Producer for ALL OF THE EVERYTHING your support will:

Provide national recognition for the work of a woman playwright, including the chance for publication through Samuel French.

Help us expand opportunities for Midwestern women playwrights by building connections with other artists.

Grow the Br!NK New Play Festival by increasing our profile and visibility on a national scale.

All contributions, of any size, help further our mission and advance the work of women theater artists. Your donation is tax deductible.

The Perks

All supporters at the $25 level or higher will receive an invitation to attend a special performance of ALL OF THE EVERYTHING in Milwaukee, at a date and time yet to be determined, and be listed in our Footlights playbills for one year.

  • $25 Gift: Receive our eternal gratitude for getting ALL OF THE EVERYTHING to NYC and a thank you email.
  • $100 Gift: All of the above, plus get your name added to the PLAYMAKER Board, to be displayed throughout next season.
  • $500 Gift: All of the above plus a reserved seat for the ALL OF THE EVERYTHING performance in Milwaukee, after we take Manhattan. Date/Time TBD but you’ll know first!
  • $1,000 Gift: Be listed as a PRODUCER on the PLAYMAKER Board! Get all of the above plus a special thank you postcard sent to you from NYC.
  • $5,000+ Gift: You know you get all of the above. You get all of our love, too and a private reception with the actors and playwright before the Milwaukee performance.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can give, or maybe you want to help us out in other ways as well as donating! Here's what you can do:

Spread the word about OOB by using the Indiegogo share tools.

Follow us on social media to stay up-to-date on our progress. @renaissance.theaterworks #RTWTakesManhattan

Join us for this year’s Br!NK New Play Festival, September 7-8, 2019 at NŌ Studios.

story:
Details

Reveries will premiere at The Tank on February 1st, 2018 with six performances through February 4th, 2018. With a team of 18 artists and growing, we strive to bring you a show that is in adherence to our artistic ambitions and expectations. But to bring this dream to reality, we need you!

Your generous support will not only allow us to afford the production costs but will also inspire us to continue our creative endeavors.

What We Need & What You Get

Here is a breakdown of what your support will help us cover:

  • Rehearsal Space
  • Costumes, Props, and Set
  • Posters and Programs
  • The Remaining Funds Will Provide a Nominal Stipend for the Artists Involved

Here is a list of perks you can receive by making a contribution:

  • Title of Producer
  • Title of Associate Producer
  • Complimentary Tickets
  • A Prop from the Show
  • A Signed Poster
  • A Signed Program
  • A Personalized "Thank You" Email
  • Program Credit

Who We Are & What Is Our Piece About

Ali Jamali is a New York-based artist with an interest in developing new works and devising immersive and site-specific pieces. He started working as a director and scenic designer at Wesleyan University, where he double-majored in Theater and Mathematics. Ali has worked on numerous productions with companies such as Second Stage Theatre and Manhattan Theatre Club. He is currently a producing resident at Musical Theatre Factory. Selected directing credits include: The AV Crew (MITF); Mnemonic, A Little Epic, Before the Sun Sets (Wesleyan University).  alidirecting.com

Calley Luman recently had her first publication of a short fiction piece titled Invisibility in Centum Press’s One Hundred Voices Anthology. She is also currently in the editing process of her first novella-length, young adult fiction manuscript. Previous credits include: Shakespeare Theatre Company of DC: Romeo and Juliet (Juliet U/S); Oklahoma Shakespeare in the Park: Twelfth Night (Fabian), Pericles (Marina.) Training: BFA, the University of Oklahoma.  calleyluman.com

Chris Goodrich is a native of Nashville, Tennessee and is an actor/director living in Brooklyn. He graduated in 2015 from the University of Miami with a BFA in musical theatre. Acting credits include various readings and productions of new plays with Rhapsody Collective, Rising Sun Performance Company, The Playwriting Collective, Exquisite Corpse Company, and the Venus/Adonis Festival. In 2016, he directed “The Illusory Adventures of a Dreamer” by Michael Bradley at the New York  International Fringe Festival. His first foray into playwriting since moving to New York was “A Glass of Tea” at the Tank in March 2017. Now, he’s looking forward to combining the challenges of writing and directing by working on devised projects.

Elvin McRae is a New York-based actor-musician and former member of the Blue Man Group. He has studied acting at American Conservatory Theater, the University of Evansville, Williamstown Theatre Festival, and the Moscow Art Theater School. As a drummer, he's performed across the city at Highline Ballroom, The Bitter End, and DROM. He is currently the Creative Director of Brooklyn Sound Lab.

Orlando Rodriguez is a graduate of the University of Texas at El Paso with a BA in Theater Tech and Design. After graduating he decided to pursue a career in acting and directing. He recently moved to New York from his hometown of El Paso and is excited about the new adventures the city will bring for him. Writing: Dolores (2017).  Directing: The Fall of Wallace Winter (2015), Johnny Tenorio (2009). Acting: Gretta in Bent (2017), Devlin in Ashes to Ashes (2013).

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't contribute at this time, there are many ways you can support us:

    • Share our campaign on social media
    • Spread the word out by mentioning us to your family, friends, and colleagues
    • Attend a performance

Share our campaign on social media

Attend a performance

story:
Our Story

On May 4, 2007, the small town of Greensburg, Kansas was almost completely destroyed by a massive tornado. Following the tornado, the people of Greensburg determined to rebuild their town as a model sustainable community. Their journey to transform a catastrophe into an exemplary achievement to the world is the stuff of legend.

The William Inge Center for the Arts has joined forces with Cornerstone Theater of Los Angeles and the 5.4.7 Arts Center of Greenesburg, Kansas, to help the people of Greensburg tell their incredible story. We ask for your help in creating this story that must be told.


The Impact

The production will help Greensburg continue to heal while bringing their remarkable story to the world in an an exciting and unique way.


What We Need & What You Get

The money will be used for set materials, costumes, lighting and sound equipment. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please tell your friends.  This is one of the most remarkable stories of our time.  We can also use all the materials and services listed at the end of the video.
story_txt:
Our Story

On May 4, 2007, the small town of Greensburg, Kansas was almost completely destroyed by a massive tornado. Following the tornado, the people of Greensburg determined to rebuild their town as a model sustainable community. Their journey to transform a catastrophe into an exemplary achievement to the world is the stuff of legend.
The William Inge Center for the Arts has joined forces with Cornerstone Theater of Los Angeles and the 5.4.7 Arts Center of Greenesburg, Kansas, to help the people of Greensburg tell their incredible story. We ask for your help in creating this story that must be told.



The Impact
The production will help Greensburg continue to heal while bringing their remarkable story to the world in an an exciting and unique way.


What We Need & What You Get
The money will be used for set materials, costumes, lighting and sound equipment. 

Other Ways You Can Help
Please tell your friends.  This is one of the most remarkable stories of our time.  We can also use all the materials and services listed at the end of the video.

story:
*Update: the performance will now be Friday May 31st- Sunday June 2nd! We have pushed back the date in order to improve the quality of the experience for everyone.*

We are creating a mixed-media performance art and theatre piece that will explore the intersections between race, class, gender and sexuality as we have experience it as mixed mamas.We need $5000 to make Mixed Mama's remixed volume 1 a reality.

Your contribution goes to directly to paying for the venue, director, musicians, tech, designer, printing, recording the show, studio time, production and postage. We're both over committed and tired of putting our art to the side. This is our chance to merge, create and grow, but we need your help. After years of being poor starving artist/activists we are asking our community of friends family and colleagues to help support our dreams.

Our campaign perks range from a facebook shout out to customized postcards, CDs, chapbooks, tickets to our show to voice recorded messages and official thank yous on our program. Every little bit helps!

We hope that the final live performance will reach 200 people over the cource of the weekend. Through the release of both a CD and chapbook we will reach additional 300 people. Large scale at least 500 people will be exposed to our work in through some medium and hopefully we inspired to tell their own stories and create their own artwork. We see this work as cyclical, renewing and as a form of resistance. Art is healing, healing is resistance.

This project is about liveness and humanity. It's about being open with stories that we've held on to for too long and sharing them with our community with laughter and sadness, beauty and pain. We are opening ourselves up and sharing our stories with the accompaniment of a live band. This piece is not only about creating a dynamic show that can push us as artists it's also to create a collective healing space.

We also understand that not everyone can help us through financial contributions. We do need help SPREADING THE WORD around--putting up flyers and postcards in cafes, schools, community centers, music and poetry venues around Chicago, videorecording our show, writing reviews, publicizing online, doing text message campaigns, donating food for our musicians, volunteering at the show to handle the door, stage managing, donating studio and rehearsal space for recording the CD and practicing our show. Please hit us up if you can volunteer your time.

Who we are:

Stacy and Sage met in Chicago. One sings, one writes poetry together they flow like chocolate covered fried matzoh.

Sage Xaxua Morgan-Hubbard is a multidisciplinary artist, poet, activist, and educator. She is currently the Academic Partnership Coordinator of the Dance department at Columbia College Chicago. She was the Cipher Organizer for Words, Beats & Life's inaugural Midwest Hip Hop Teach-In "Remixing the Art of Social Change" at Columbia in 2011. Most recently she served as the Outreach Director of Young Chicago Authors and as a teaching artist throughout the Chicagoland area instructing kindergarten through college-level students in jail and beyond. She earned her MA in Performance Studies at Northwestern University and is a graduate of Brown University where she studied "Performance Studies: Socially Conscious Art of the Everyday" and Ethnic Studies. She is a member of Real Talk Live Chicago poetry collective, the founder of WORD! spoken word artists and activists in Providence, RI, a former Washington, D.C youth poetry slam coach, and one of the original members of Spoken Resistance, DC Writers Corps and the performance group Sol y Soul. She was born a child radical fist first. She found poetry at the tender age of 14 and has been in love ever since. She performed her way through sanity. Sage has always spoken her truth, opened her heart and brain to knowlege, made mistakes: smiled, laughed, resisted & renewed. She is a Larry Neal award winner, a Gwendolyn Brooks Open Mic award winner, a Hurston-Wright writer, a Poets& Writers educator, DC young Artist award grantee, hip-hop theater head, funktafied grown up kid who used spoken word & music as medicine for survival. Sage believes in praxis, peace, & the arts as tools for social change and transformation. Sage is delighted to take her one-woman show Mixed Mamas (originally written & performed in May 2012 in celebration of her various mamas) to the next level in this incredible Remix with Stacy!

Stacy Rene Erenberg is a community organizer, activist healer and socially conscious songstress hailing from the north side of Chicago. She is emerging as a noted young vocalist who’s sound is sultry, with a tint of honey and much soul. Since her Chicago Debut in 2006, she has performed at legendary Chicago venues such as The Jazz Showcase, The Metro and The Park West. She is the front woman for prolific local groups  Vertikal, The Damaste Jazz Project, and My damn Butterfly. Her style and delivery is as diverse as her cultural background. She is influenced by jazz, soul, r and b, pop, hip-hop and most importantly folk music, which fuels her passion for telling the peoples history through her music. Stacy can’t remember a time when she wasn’t singing. She grew up in a musical family that was involved with a Buddhist organization that was constantly putting on musical productions. At the age of four she was singing in front of large crowds and composing melodies. Since childhood she has continued to grow and thrive as a vocalist. In 2008, Chicago-Sun Times music critic Jim Derogotis stated that Vertikal, which Stacy is lead vocalist for, is, ” Dedicated to bridging the gap between hip-hop and jazz but also incorporating elements of funk, neo-soul, Latin, rock and blues, the mixed-gender, multi-ethnic band nonetheless churns out some surprisingly seamless and very accomplished grooves.” She is also the 2011 recipient of the Illinois Arts Council Professional Development Grant. She also enjoys hanging with friends and family, decompressing with her partner by watching bad T.V, laughing out loud and dancing it out on a regular basis.

story:
Our Story

NYU Renegade Theatre is putting up a production of Andrew Lippa's THE WILD PARTY December 1-3 in Palladium. We are raising money to procure the rights and orchestral scores for the production. NYU Renegade theatre is a student-run theatre group based in Steinhardt at NYU focused on performing controversial and experimental material with participation from within every school at the university.


The Impact

The rights are expensive, with no student discounts, and we have to budget for set, costumes, and design as well; with the limited school funding, this is impossible without outside assistance.


What We Need & What You Get

Here are the fees for the rights:

ROYALTY A) $ 150.00 For Each Regular,Benefit or Other Performance
  PROVISIONS: Seating Limited to 120 per Performance
SECURITY FEE : $400.00 to be refunded following the timely return of the rented materials to us handling/shipping/missing materials/brokerage fees, late charges and/or any outstanding account obligations.
BASIC RENTAL : $ 450.00 for a standard set of materials or any part thereof.
  PROVISIONS: Please Add 8.875 Sales Tax to All Rental Items


We need your help! Check out the perks!


Other Ways You Can Help

Tell all your friends!!!

story:
Our Point of Contention

 

A little contention is exactly our point!  The work PoC strives to produce speaks to a need for open discussion with our fellow artists and devoted patrons on subjects large and small that shape our current culture.

 

"This is what Chicago’s theater scene is all about: around a corner, in a little space one could easily pass by, a small theater company is doing great things." - Chicago Theater Blog (The Wonder, 2009)

                                                                                                     

Your Impact

 

By donating to this PoC IndieGOGO campaign you are not only helping fund innovative collaborative art but you are helping to create and foster a communicative environment for both Chicago performers and patrons. Specifically, Point of Contention looks to achieve a number of goals with any money raised from this campaign, most important of which are:  gaining our 501(c)3 status, instituting our new educational & professional development outreach programs, and producing 1 full length play and our 7th Annual ChAos New Plays Festival.

 

What We Need & What’s In It For You

 

Point of Contention Theatre needs $5,000 to make our 7th Season a reality. This amount, combined with our ongoing fundraising efforts including our 6th Annual ChAos New Plays Festival, will go towards the rental of a theatre space for our full length production and towards our 501(c)3 dues. 

 

By donating to PoC you will not only get some awesome perks:

·       personal missives of bubbling thanks and appreciation from PoC’s doting company members,

·       soundtracks from shows guaranteed to tap your toes,

·       access for you and a guest to PoC events and much more!

 

You will also be helping a young theatre company ground itself in the artistic dialogue of Chicago's thriving theatre scene! We’re here to stay. What can we create together?

 

Help PoC and Spread the Word

 

Word of mouth is still one of the most powerful means of sharing information.  Help PoC by spreading the word to your family and friends about this campaign!

 

Keep track of the company at http://www.pointofcontention.org/

“Like” us on facebook at http://www.facebook.com/#!/pointofcontention?sk=wall

Follow us on Twitter @ThtrwithaPoint

story:
Stephen Belber, Playwright (Tape, Match, The Laramie Project, Dusk Rings A Bell, etc...):

(on why he wanted to work with Neil Holland and Don DiPaolo on their revival of Tape)

 

"There are two types of actors: There are those that go to LA and try to luck into something big, and then there are those who stay in NY and work on their craft and hustle. And these guys (Neil Holland and Don DiPaolo) are above and beyond that. I mean, they are the epitome of wanting to put their money where their mouth is, and more, their hard work where their mouth is."


What We Need & What You Get

We have already raised $10,000, and as in politics, early money is critical.  We now need to raise an additional $30,000 toward our final goal of $40,000.

These funds are needed to cover production costs including:
  • Theatre Rental
  • Artist and crew fees
  • A publicist and publicity
  • Marketing
  • Sets/Costumes/Lighting
  • Insurance
  • And much more...
We are offering a wide array of perks including:
  • Tickets to the show
  • Invitations to an exclusive opening night reception
  • Invitations to a working rehearsal
  • Posters autographed by the cast, director and playwright
  • Producer credits
Additionally, your donations are tax deductible to the extent permitted by law!  

But here's the bottom line:  This project is exceptional, and one you will be proud to be part of.  We have a proven track record of success, and there is no doubt that with the same team back in place, and an original play developed specifically for us by a Drama Desk nominated playwright, that we will once again put our money where our mouth is and make every single one of you proud.  

Our Story

Last fall was amazing:  Knife Edge Productions produced an award-winning play on a New York stage.   We performed to a packed house night after night and audience members included actors Cynthia Nixon and Bobby Cannavale as well as Tony nominated playwright Stephen Adly Guirgis.  

This could not have been possible without the enormous support of the over 150 backers who believed in us and donated close to $40,000.  And we are very proud to say that we did in fact put our money where our mouth is:  Our production of Tape was extremely successful and played to wide acclaim. In fact, Sandra Mardenfeld of “Show Showdown” just named Tape favorite play of 2011!

“Stephen Belber’s Tape moved me like no other show in 2011. This Off-Broadway production showed the after effect of high school through sharp observation and gun-fire paced dialogue.” -- Sandra Mardenfeld of “Show Showdown”

Of all the reviews we got, the comments we heard most often -- and took the most seriously -- were about the strength of our onstage dynamic. Based on that, we've taken the step of commissioning a play written specifically to our strengths and chemistry as actors.  We believe that an original work by an established playwright will attract significant attention, and also opens the door to the possibility that another theatre company could license our production. And yes, there is even the chance (however slim) that we could option film rights.

We are very excited to tell you that we have found our man: Drama Desk-nominated playwright Julian Sheppard. Julian's plays include Buicks, which was originally produced by the Underwood Theater in New York. The production received 2 Drama Desk nominations, including one for Outstanding Play.  Buicks has subsequently been produced regionally in the U.S., was developed for TV by Joe Roth, Paramount and CBS.  Buicks is currently being developed for film with producer Fred Roos and director Jessica Landaw. You can read Julian’s complete bio by clicking here.   

But wait, it get’s better and better: We have had discussions with Obie Award and Drama Desk Award-winning actor Reed Birney to join us in this production.  In the last year alone, Reed received a Special Drama Desk Award honoring his thirty six years of work as an actor, Actor’s Equity awarded him the Richard Seff Award and Charles Isherwood of the New York Times christened him the “hardest-working actor”.   Julian is writing a role with Reed specifically in mind.

All this, combined with the fact that Sam Helfrich is back at the helm as director, gives us great confidence that we will repeat and even go beyond the enormous success we had with Tape.

About The Play

Julian began work on this brand-new play in January, inspired by our work as actors and with us specifically in mind.  The play centers on a young man who has moved to New York City for a mysterious new job.  He strikes up a friendship with his building’s super, whom he encounters in his apartment when he first arrives. His job remains a mystery even after he begins work; his sole duty is to sit in a glass booth for eight hours and transcribe an endless flow of numbers on a wall of computer screens.  His suspicions about what the job and the numbers truly mean coincide with an growing suspicion that the super is more than what he seems to be, and the woman who meets in a bar isn’t just a random stranger.  Are the numbers part of a larger pattern? Is everything?   This dark comedy about the complications of friendship, the desire for meaning and the impossible choices we make everyday will be developed with us and director Sam Helfrich in the coming months towards our goal of a production – a goal we need you to reach.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please make some noise about this production and our fundraising campaign.

Take advantage of the sharing tools found right on our Indie Go Go page to help us spread the word. 

  • Facebook
  • Twitter
  • Google+
  • You can even click that little heart icon under our video right here on our Indie Go Go page to “favorite” us.
  • Reach out to friends, family members, colleagues, acquaintances, and anyone else you can think of.  All you have to do is click the “Email” button located with right here on our Indie Go Go page. 

The more we spread the word, the greater chance we have of success.  Our goal is to raise the remaining funds by May 2012 so that we may move forward and mount this production in the fall of 2012. 

With your support and enthusiasm we can make this a reality, and we thank you for it!

-- Neil Holland, Don DiPaolo, Sam Helfrich, and Julian Sheppard

Other Ways You Can Help


Please make some noise about this production and our fundraising campaign.
Take advantage of the sharing tools found right on our Indie Go Go page to help us spread the word. 

Facebook
Twitter
Google+
You can even click that little heart icon under our video right here on our Indie Go Go page to “favorite” us.
Reach out to friends, family members, colleagues, acquaintances, and anyone else you can think of.  All you have to do is click the “Email” button located with right here on our Indie Go Go page. 

The more we spread the word, the greater chance we have of success.  Our goal is to raise the remaining funds by May 2012 so that we may move forward and mount this production in the fall of 2012. 
With your support and enthusiasm we can make this a reality, and we thank you for it!
-- Neil Holland, Don DiPaolo, Sam Helfrich, and Julian Sheppard

story:
This July 1st marks a date that I have been looking forward to for a very long time, my 18th birthday. For as long as I can remember, I have been looking forward to this date because it marks the day when I can move to New York City and pursue my life long dream of becoming an actor. While living in Orlando, Florida, I have participated in local theatre and starred in commercials and educational videos for Sea World Adventure Parks and Universal Orlando. I have been lucky enough to have been trained by some of the best and brightest in my industry in the Orlando area. I have taken full advantage of all the opportunities that Orlando has had to offer and I know that my time has finally come to make the move to the Big Apple.

Acting, to some, is about status, fame, or fortune. That however, is not how I define the term. To me, acting is the chance to deliver the character of a story to someone who may relate to that character. By sharing a story through stage, film, or television you can not only entertain an audience but you can move them to tears, inspire them to reach their goals, and console them when they are faced with grief. Talented actors such as Johnny Depp, Denzel Washington, and Heath Ledger are completely dedicated to their craft to the point that they make us laugh at their humor, rejoice at their victories, and weep for their sorrows.

I believe an actor has a responsibility to the character they are playing, the actors and directors whom they are working with, and the audience that is receiving the message. As an actor, I do not take this responsibility lightly. This is why I believe it would be in my best interest to work along side the best of the best in the industry. The move and adjustment will not be easy. I will be working two jobs, auditioning at every chance I get, and practicing my craft during my down time. I will be moving far away from my family, friends, and local support group. However, I know that one day, I can inspire others to continue reaching upwards to better themselves and our society.
story_txt:
This July 1st marks a date that I have been looking forward to for a very long time, my 18th birthday. For as long as I can remember, I have been looking forward to this date because it marks the day when I can move to New York City and pursue my life long dream of becoming an actor. While living in Orlando, Florida, I have participated in local theatre and starred in commercials and educational videos for Sea World Adventure Parks and Universal Orlando. I have been lucky enough to have been trained by some of the best and brightest in my industry in the Orlando area. I have taken full advantage of all the opportunities that Orlando has had to offer and I know that my time has finally come to make the move to the Big Apple.
Acting, to some, is about status, fame, or fortune. That however, is not how I define the term. To me, acting is the chance to deliver the character of a story to someone who may relate to that character. By sharing a story through stage, film, or television you can not only entertain an audience but you can move them to tears, inspire them to reach their goals, and console them when they are faced with grief. Talented actors such as Johnny Depp, Denzel Washington, and Heath Ledger are completely dedicated to their craft to the point that they make us laugh at their humor, rejoice at their victories, and weep for their sorrows.
I believe an actor has a responsibility to the character they are playing, the actors and directors whom they are working with, and the audience that is receiving the message. As an actor, I do not take this responsibility lightly. This is why I believe it would be in my best interest to work along side the best of the best in the industry. The move and adjustment will not be easy. I will be working two jobs, auditioning at every chance I get, and practicing my craft during my down time. I will be moving far away from my family, friends, and local support group. However, I know that one day, I can inspire others to continue reaching upwards to better themselves and our society.

story:
The Company

cold.dead.fish is an independent theatre company that focuses on new works and emerging artists. We're interested in creating visually stimulating, emotionally challenging, intellectually engaging theatre. Pushed and Release, two new plays by Jessica Peverett, will be presented at the 2012 Edmonton Fringe Festival. We're so excited to share these projects with you. 

Here's a little bit about the shows!

Pushed (featuring Mary Hulbert & Jessica Peverett): After meeting in Lamaze class, two women bond over the highs and lows of being pregnant. What follows is a contemplation of possession and what it means to be a mother. 5 Stars - Vue Weekly, 2011 "Pushed is a dark gem"

Release (featuring Mari Chartier & Cody Porter): Tabitha didn't go to work today. Instead she did something (really) bad. There are old people wandering the parking lot, a father who doesn't want to understand and a lot of boxes that remind her of what she's lost. How can you let go when you can't move on?

Why is the Edmonton Fringe Festival so amazing?

The Edmonton Fringe is the second largest Fringe festival in the world where 41 venues house over 1500 performances. Last year over 192,000 tickets were sold and they estimate that nearly half a million people came out to visit the Fringe site. This is the perfect place for artists to present their work to a diverse audience. It's a chance to take risks and to rely on themselves to produce shows. 

The Edmonton Fringe is also unique because it runs on a lottery system and allows companies to book their own venues (BYOV - bring your own venue). We were lucky enough to snag a spot in one of those 41 lottery venues AND find our own venue. With two shows on the go, we've been very busy! 

How can you help cold.dead.fish?

The Edmonton Fringe is a fabulous tool for independent artists to get out and produce new works. Of course, with great opportunities come some financial snags. We're responsible for paying all the bills. This includes application fees, venue rental fees, insurance fees and that's just to house us! From there, we have to pay for our set, our costumes, our props, our rehearsal space and the rest of our marketing materials (posters, handbills, etc). All this has to be paid off before we can even think about paying our actors a fair wage. 

It's really important to us that we be able to compensate the people who throw themselves into these projects and there are no guarantees at Fringe!

So here's what we're trying to subsidize before we get to the festival:

1. The $635.00 application fee for our lottery venue
2. $215.00 to pay our technician in the BYOV


Other Ways You Can Help

If you're in the Edmonton area during the Fringe (August 16-26) come check out the shows! 

TICKETS can be purchased through the Fringe Box Office or at the door.

PUSHED - Venue 10: Acacia Hall, 10433 83 avenue: Saturday August 18 @ 4pm, Monday August 20 @ 12:15pm, Tuesday August 21 @ 10:30pm, August 23 @ 2:15, Saturday August 25 @ 8pm, Sunday August 26 @ 6pm

RELEASE - BYOV Venue 30: Phabrik Art & Design Centre, 10055 80 Avenue: Friday August 17 @ 4:15pm, Saturday August 18 @ 8pm, Sunday August 19 @ 5pm, Monday August 20 @ 10:30pm, Tuesday August 21 @ 5pm, Wednesday August 22 @ 10:15pm, Thursday August 23 @ 8:30pm, Friday August 24 @ 6:45pm, Saturday August 25 @ 11:59pm, Sunday August 26 @ 6:30pm


CHECK OUT OUR FACEBOOK PAGE (https://www.facebook.com/cdftheatre) FOR COOL TIDBITS! LIKE where did you get the idea for the show? can I watch a rehearsal? when and where does the play happen? where's the best place to get a beer at fringe? what's with that weird clown guy near second cup who won't leave me alone?

story:
“For years after leaving home I carried an old family picture; tucked it directly behind my driver’s license. Where the latter went the former followed—sometimes whispering, sometimes shouting: “I am not the Black Man you think I am.”

The Project:

BrownBox African American Theatre is thrilled to present the April 2013 World Premiere of Chad Goller-Sojourner’s sophomore solo performance: Riding in Cars with Black People & Other Newly Dangerous Acts: A Memoir in Vanishing Whiteness. ---Riding in Cars with Black People is the groundbreaking and crushingly honest story of what happens when a black boy, raised by white parents, “ages out” of honorary white and suburban privilege and into a world where folklore, statistics, and conjecture deem him dangerous until proven otherwise.

Of course this show is about a lot more than what happens when white parents ship their black kids off to college in ill-fitted automobiles. At times funny, biting, and somber, Riding in Cars with Black People unpacks race, privilege, and identity like only a transracial adoptee can.

Why This Project Matters: 

Google “conversation on race” and you’ll get about 201,000,000 results—seems everyone has an opinion. But for a “conversation on race” to be fruitful it must be made up of more than opinions. It must be made up of critical and unique voices. Riding in Cars with Black People is one of those voices; ultimately demonstrating how even the most painful of experiences can be reclaimed, transformed, and accepted for what they are: the building blocks of our unique identities.

“While I did not know it at the time, one of the benefits of my honorary white and suburban privilege was the ability to gather, congregate, and move aimlessly through public spaces without attention or purpose.”

 How We’ll Use Your Contributions:

Contrary to its name, there’s nothing solo (or cheap) about mounting a solo performance, especially a multimedia solo performance.Your contributions of $9,800 will be used to cover Artistic & Creative Fees including: Dramaturge, Director, Performer, and Choreographer, as well as Multimedia, Sound, Lighting, and Set Designers. Then there’s the production side, which includes Venue & Rehearsal Space Rental, Insurance, Tech Crew, House Manager, Marketing/PR, Videographer, and Equipment Rental.Told you there was a lot.

Now the good news: we’ve done this before and are pretty good about spending money wisely and getting the best return for our buck. In fact our first solo performance, Sitting in Circles with Rich White Girls: Memoirs of a Bulimic Black Boy which premiered in July 2008, went on to a successful three year college tour and a 2010 revival. See www.sitting-in-circles.com. Speaking of tours and revivals, any monies raised beyond $9,800 will go towards mounting the Riding in Cars with Black People & Other Newly Dangerous Acts World Domination Tour!

How You Can Contribute:

1) By making a financial contribution via PayPal* or Credit Card. Any amount helps. In fact, if 300 people donate $33 dollars, we will meet our fundraising goal.

2) Spread the word: tell your friends, family, coworkers, listserv, everybody. It’s as easy as posting the Indiegogo Campaign link on your Facebook, Twitter, Blog, or wherever you think interested people will see it. Finally, “Like” and promote our Riding in Cars with Black People & Other Newly Dangerous Acts Facebook page.

"Goller-Sojourner is both a heartbreaking and hilarious storyteller." Seattle Weekly

 “Chad Goller-Sojourner is the most honestly breathtaking voice to grace the stage in a long while: One of his gifts is playfulness in the midst of grief and it is a beautiful thing to behold.” Tara Hard, Founder Bent Writing Institute

The Performer:

Chad Goller-Sojourner is a Seattle-based writer, solo-performer, and recipient of a distinguished Artist Trust/Washington State Arts Commission Performing Arts Fellowship. His work has been funded by the National Endowment for the Arts (NEA) and featured on NPR. Most recently he was awarded a 2011 Artist Trust/Centrum Creative Artist Residency. In 2008, he launched a three year national college tour of his award winning and highly acclaimed inaugural solo show, Sitting in Circles with Rich White Girls: Memoirs of a Bulimic Black Boy.

Additional works include an evening-length play entitled The Bus Stop, which culminated in a July 2010 staged reading, and the publishing of a chapbook entitled Born One Thousand Years Too Early: Fat, Dark-Skinned, Gay and Adopted by White Folks A Fragmentary Journey Towards Alignment, which has been described as poignant, chilling, and prophetic.

 

http://www.sitting-in-circles.com/

http://www.sitting-in-circles.com/images/News_Tribune_Preview.pdf

http://realchangenews.org/index.php/site/printer-friendly/2280

http://seattletimes.com/html/jerrylarge/2003950447_jdl15.html

http://www.sitting-in-circles.com/images/Seattlest_Preview.pdf

 

* Want to contribute to via PayPal, but don’t not have a PayPal account? Follow the steps below. 

  1. When you get to the PayPal screen, you'll see up top "Choose a Way to Pay"
  2. Select the second option: "Pay with a debit or credit card"
  3. Complete the form - PayPal accepts Visa, MasterCard, Discover, and American Express
  4. Deselect the checkbox that says: "Save this information with a PayPal account"
  5. Click "Review and Continue" to continue with a payment using a credit card
  6. Click on the "Continue Without Logging In" link

story:
Short Summary

I started my aerial journey about 2 years ago and I have fallen in love!  I enjoy doing aerial dance so much that I decided to focus on my improvement so I could perform and teach it in order to share my passion with others.  While St. Louis offers aerial classes, it's not enough.  I've been taking classes, but I need to experience some new teachers, new theories for learning, etc. in order to be the best performer and teacher that I can be.

I have been awarded a work-study scholarship to teach Zumba at an 8-day aerial retreat intensive in the Dominican Republic, but I need your help to  pay the remainder of my tuition and to get there.

I am attending a training called Aerial Acro Play hosted by Sweet Retreats. It will include 8 days of training on a variety of aerial apparatus including lyra, silks, acro yoga, handstand training, flexibility, flying trapeze, and more.  http://www.sweetretreatsdr.com/

This training will enable me to accomplish some of my immediate and long term goals in my performance career, as well as coming back with plenty of new material to teach others in my classes and workshops!

Here is a video of my first aerial performance.  http://youtu.be/FVzVo_gGL1I

Check out more videos by clicking on the Gallery tab located above my picture.


What I Need & What You Get

I need $1500 to help cover my flight to the Dominican Republic and the remainder of what I owe for the retreat after my work-study scholarship.

Any amount you can donate will be greatly appreciated!  I have some perks to offer in exchange!  Check them out!


The Impact

Aerial training is an extremely difficult craft!  It requires much physical and mental strength.  It offers much in return, though.  I have personally gained so much more than just physical strength!  I have become more confident and believe in myself more now, at the age of 33,  than I ever have.  

The self-confidence that comes from aerial training is part of the reason I seek to teach it.  I try to help people find their inner and outer strength through my lessons.  I don't want it to take others 33 years like it did for me to find that one can truly do anything you set your mind to.

Having attended this retreat last year, I know the value of the instruction that I will receive and how inspiring it is!  It was a life-changing intensive for me!  It helped me find my inner peace and convinced me that I am most certainly called to teach others and share my passion with them!

Here is a short video of me at the retreat last year.  I'm doing a trick I learned while I was there called the double star.  http://youtu.be/duhDNY3MtpQ

Please help me inspire others through aerial training the way it has inspired me!  Donate to my cause today!

Other Ways You Can Help

It's OK if you can't contribute today! What you CAN do is help spread the word! Please share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, or whatever social media site that you use! Word of mouth is always the best way to share!

story:
Hey, we're putting on a play and we would love your support!
 

We aim to raise $1000 to put on an quirky play for you all, called ‘Love is a Time of Day’ written by John Patrick, adapted and Directed by Felicity Tchorlian. 

It is a site specific theatre performance. As the play is set in an apartment room, we will be performing it in a gorgeous terrace in Glebe in the living room with an audience of 15 people. It's nice and cosy!

The play is a tragic-comedy about two university students who desperately seek each others help for money, love, comfort, food and sex! But they struggle to achieve this due their conflicting beliefs, their social status and their emotional capabilities.

Grace Rouvray will be playing Mac, Ryan Madden will be playing Skip plus a furry actor, Lilo...YEP there's a little dog in the play!

Why $1000?!

To pay for:

Rights to the play -$450

Rehearsal space -$200

Props- $150

Costumes -$50

Technical equipment $150

Catering $100

***So if you have a spare couple of bucks please don't hesitate to donate!***

YES! There IS something in it for you all!

-For anyone who donates $50 will get themselves a tasty Greek inspired dinner.

-Donate $100 and score yourself a free photo shoot with Felicity Tchorlian Photography. Check out www.felicitytchorlian.com


All you have to do is press 'Contribute Now'!!!

Show goes up on 2nd October - 4th October 2014

Looking forward to seeing you at the show :)

Thanks

Felicity, Grace, Ryan and Lilo

story:
Short Summary

Hi, I'm Samantha Hull and I run WFL (World Foam League). We introduce a new concept in sports Called "Precision Point combat". Although WFL has had our official first show at Ultracon Of South Florida we plan on traveling the nation and entertaining many. But before that can happen...promotion is essential. 


What We Need & What You Get

WFL has been in the works of locking WCW Tag Team Champion Brian Knobbs of "the Nasty Boys" as our spokesman. Having the likes of Mr. Knobbs spreading the word about our league would catapult us into endless opportunities. In the coming months we will be launching a micro funding campaign to get all our ducks in a row but first we need to give Mr. Knobbs a down payment to get the ball rolling. 

  • $2,500 is needed to get Brian Knobbs signature on a year long promotional contract. 
  • $500 is needed to travel to Mr. Knobbs with all the fighters to start immediate filming of promotional videos.

The Impact

We have confidence that this new entertainment sport will get many people as excited as we are. Nothing like this has ever been done. The rule set has been revised to reflect the skill of the fighters. Not only will the audience get a taste of REAL one on one combat but the eccentric theatrics will keep them coming back for more. With characters like an insane clown who's calm demeanor will only be shook by his violent attack to the viking like God who is loved by all. The hilarity of the characters like the hobo who can't put the bottle down long enough to remember who was paid to take a fall will only tie together the victory and defeat of them all. 

Risks & Challenges

The obstacle of getting people to understand this is neither "LARP" nor is it wrestling is in the forefront. Getting the promotional videos out and the people to the fights is the only way to see the difference. I as well as the others involved in getting this done have worked hard for over a year to set in stone what exactly we are and what we do. We want a lot for this and it can be great with only a little push from you.  

Other Ways You Can Help

For those who can't help financially, sharing this campaign is a huge help... probably more help then actually funding.
story_txt: Short Summary Hi, I'm Samantha Hull and I run WFL (World Foam League). We introduce a new concept in sports Called "Precision Point combat". Although WFL has had our official first show at Ultracon Of South Florida we plan on traveling the nation and entertaining many. But before that can happen...promotion is essential.     What We Need & What You Get WFL has been in the works of locking WCW Tag Team Champion Brian Knobbs of "the Nasty Boys" as our spokesman. Having the likes of Mr. Knobbs spreading the word about our league would catapult us into endless opportunities. In the coming months we will be launching a micro funding campaign to get all our ducks in a row but first we need to give Mr. Knobbs a down payment to get the ball rolling.   $2,500 is needed to get Brian Knobbs signature on a year long promotional contract.  $500 is needed to travel to Mr. Knobbs with all the fighters to start immediate filming of promotional videos.    The Impact We have confidence that this new entertainment sport will get many people as excited as we are. Nothing like this has ever been done. The rule set has been revised to reflect the skill of the fighters. Not only will the audience get a taste of REAL one on one combat but the eccentric theatrics will keep them coming back for more. With characters like an insane clown who's calm demeanor will only be shook by his violent attack to the viking like God who is loved by all. The hilarity of the characters like the hobo who can't put the bottle down long enough to remember who was paid to take a fall will only tie together the victory and defeat of them all.    Risks & Challenges The obstacle of getting people to understand this is neither "LARP" nor is it wrestling is in the forefront. Getting the promotional videos out and the people to the fights is the only way to see the difference. I as well as the others involved in getting this done have worked hard for over a year to set in stone what exactly we are and what we do. We want a lot for this and it can be great with only a little push from you.     Other Ways You Can Help For those who can't help financially, sharing this campaign is a huge help... probably more help then actually funding.

story:
Dearest Friends and Supporters,
Hello! I'm Benjamin Landsberg, a Toronto based contemporary dancer and independant choreographer. Last year I was the lucky recipient of the DanceOntario Creative Partnership Commission for 2012, which I used to create my first full-length work, Chemical Messengers. During that creation process in Montreal, it was my honor to have the wonderful Ms. Dena Davida of Tangente notice my work and appreciate it as a part of what she calls "a resurgence of movement invention".

Ms. Davida has since been offered a carte blanche evening at The Festival Transatlantique Montreal, in which she has decided to bring together three fresh male choreographic voices that she believes are a part of this movement. In this specially curated evening, I will be presented alongside two other extremely talented young male choreographers from Les Grands Ballets Canadiens. I have recognized this opportunity as a deep honor and an exciting opportunity for my work and for my dancers, but I need your help.

Where You Come In
The money for this festival is scarce, and my participation in it is not supported financially by grants or organizations. I am working through fundraising (this campaign included) and networking to raise enough money to pay my dancers modestly, and to cover the costs of production and travel to Montreal. We will create the work in an intensive 2.5 week process leading right up to the show, in September. Any donation in any amount is a huge help to me and my dancers, and is so appreciated. I believe that this festival is an invaluable step in my very new choreographic career. 

THANK YOU for reading, THANK YOU for caring, and most of all THANK YOU for giving. For more information about myself, my work, and the festival, read on.

Love,

B

...............................................................

 

The Bystander Ritual

Originally one of only two annual Creative Partnership commissions from DanceOntario, Chemical Messengers chronicles and abstracts the loss of mankind’s biochemical link to the unseen mind of the planet, and the resulting descent into a patriarchal, dominator style society. The Bystander Ritual is a sister piece, adapted choreographically into a trio specially for Festival Transatlantique Montreal. By re-examining in detail certain relationships from Chemical Messengers, The Bystander Ritual explores power dynamics between victims, aggressors, and most importantly, bystanders. It is inspired by the unseen forces that bind people and minds, the synaptic gravity of guilt, doubt, and fear.


About Me

Benjamin Landsberg is a Toronto-born contemporary dancer and independent choreographer.  Since his completion of Ryerson University’s Performance Dance BFA Program, he has performed and collaborated with Typecast Dance Company, MOVE: the company, inDance, Kaeja d’Dance, Ezdanza, Compagnie Flak, and Pro Arte Danza, and toured through Canada, Asia, and the United States. He has danced works by Darryl Tracy, D. A. Hoskins, Robert Glumbek, Roberto Campagnella, Emily Molnar, Joshua Beamish, Hari Krishnan, Edgar Zendejas, Laurence Lemieux, and Jose Navas. In January 2013, Landsberg premiered his most recent full length work Chemical Messengers, as one of only two Creative Partnership Commissions from DanceOntario.

 Benjamin Landsberg’s dance background is mainly contemporary ballet, but his fascination with popular culture, music, film, and the internet has colored his approach. Influences of hip-hop, jazz-funk, and burlesque are palpable. As a choreographer, Benjamin believes that a dance work’s highest priority is to engage both the performers and new audiences in an interactive and generation-specific manner. Contemporary and modern dance doesn’t have to exist in the artistic vacuum that it does today. The aesthetic he explores with movement vocabulary, music, and lighting has a current tone, and he strives to create a performance language that truly speaks to the human beings involved.

story:
Become a production-supporter of

A HAND FULL HOME

a new dancetheatre solo piece - produced by stormproof productions!

Welcome on our indiegogo site. You are invited to participate in creating new work. About Home. And a myth. Featuring dance and original music...

But first let´s introduce ourselves.

What is STORMPROOF?

STORMPROOF productions (that is Mia Shen from China and Sina Heiss from Austria) are proud to work once again with Lia Bonfilio (dancer/New York) and Manuel Mitterhuber (musician/composer/Austria).
After having produced Caryl Churchill´s Far Away this spring with these two amazing artists in our team we still wanted to see and hear more of their work! The invitation by DIVA Monodramafestival in Austria to devise a piece around the topic of home offered us the chance to realize this wish.
And with the writer-brain of Toby Knops (New York) the team is ready to start telling their stories...

What we do...

STORMPROOF productions stands for creating art under difficult circumstances and helps international artists to meet and create theatre, which is informed by their interdiciplinary multicultural approaches.
We believe that art gives impulses to new thinking in society and unites wonderful, smart thinkers. We therefore believe that artists from different countries should be able to connect. To overcome the boundaries of distance we need to raise some travel costs. Last but not least we want to honor the artistic work done for us and rehearsal time invested with food, drinks and little presents - artists should not have to work for nothing! And we love to make them happy with a little gesture of thankfulness.

 

If you can identify with our ideas and if you want to get connected with us and our work we invite you to become a producer in donating a fraction of our budget-goal. Every dollar counts and will be used for supporting high-quality witty artistic work!

Sounds good?

Read about our piece...

 

a hand full home - Athena travels to Ithaca

A dance theatre piece adapted from Homer's First Book of the Odyssee

 

The Odyssey sounds familiar of course...But the First book?
Ready for a refresher? 

For years the Gods have been preventing Odysseys from escaping the island of Ogygia, where the beautiful sea witch, Calypso keeps him captive. Athena, the goddess with gleaming eyes, pleads with them to aid in his escape. Deciding to take action, she travels to Ithaca, where she convinces Odysseus' son, Telemachus to go on a journey to find news of his father. Seeing the chaos in Ithaca, she realizes the palace and the royal family will drown from a flood of suitors. Unless she can help get Odysseus back.

Lia´s performance unites reality and mythology:

A dancer – alone and far away from home – courageously tells her story and explores the feeling of home inside herself.
And a goddess – a stranger – grips her listeners with an adventurous personal story, a quest.

And what will this all look like on stage? 

Lia will present a colorful experiment of contemporary dance, object and movement theatre and of course a bit of humor. We like that.

The piece reflects the universal desire for coming home – wherever that may be – an emotion every one of us carries inside.

Who is involved so far?

Well, you. Which is awesome.
As well as

  • Performance: Lia Bonflio Lia studied dance in Chicago and lives/works as a dancer in New York. Her performance highlights have been with artists like Susan Rethorst, Joe Goode, Julia Rhoads and Peter Carpenter in San Francisco, Chicago and New York.

  • Direction&Concept: Sina Heiss Sina is an Austrian theatre director, performer and singer. She is pursuing her MA in Directing for theatre at Columbia University New York. Additionally she tours original work in Europe.

    A hand full home is Lia´s and Sina´s third project together. (former projects were: Ping – A dance installation adapted from Samuel Beckett; Far Away by Caryl Churchill)

  • Music/Sound: Manuel Mitterhuber Manuel is an Austrian musician and composer. He is the founder of ZACHrecords in Linz, Austria and his original music has toured with various ensembles (such as NI, Drumski) all over Europe.

  • Text Adaptation English: Toby Knops Toby is an Artistic Director, performer and writer in New York City. His plays have been performed in NYC, Vermont and Kentucky, and has produced major events such as the NYC Sketch Festival, the NYC Improv Festival and the upcoming SOLOCOM NYC.
  • Creative Producing: Mia Shen Mia Shen is from China. She has produced three full-length productions with Sina Heiss between 2012 and 2013. 

 


EVERYBODY will be rewarded through this campaign!

What we will get and what you will get:

OUR CAMPAIGN GOAL IS 2800 USD.
Most of it will be used as travel costs. Manuel is visiting us from Europe and his flight is not yet covered. We don´t want him to pay all that by himself.
The reamaining amount will be used to reward the artistic work and effort put into this project by FEEDING the artists with healthy stuff and not forcing them to buy yet another 1 Dollar Menu at Mac Donalds, COVERING EVERYDAY COSTS like subway rides (which sums up enormously for artists travelling around in New York City), PAYING for REHEARSAL SPACE and BUYING PROPS.

WE HAVE SOME UNIQUE REWARDS FOR YOU!

Your donation will be rewarded with a gift, that is inspired by a hand full home or that directly results from our artistic process!
It will be a reminder for you that you were part of our production team and supported us in creating this piece!

Last but not least:
A successful start of our Europe Tour will help us get connected easier with theatres in the US. With your support we can afford to make this piece look BETTER! We are currently planning to tour it in New York as well and make it a stormproof repertoire piece! 

We guarantuee you that all the money raised for this project will be used to support our artists!

If you cannot support this production financially but would still like to contribute something we would be thrilled if you spread the word about it, tell your friends, family and artists you think would like to get connceted!
We love to get to know new collaborators who have a desire to work with an international team and welcome new audiences.

Thank you for loving the Arts...The Arts love you back!

story:
I'm Halley Daigle, a MFA candidate for performing arts at Savannah College of Art and Design.  

I am currently working on my Graduate Thesis Dance Show:  A satyrical representation of daily issues women face in modern America.  Specifically referring to misrepresentation and  over-sexualization women go through often caused by marketing and advertisement.


    The show is extremely stylized, zoning in on the Vaudeville and Burlesque based choreography.  All the dances work through general topics women face, playing with humor as they do it.


    When preparing these pieces, I took personal stories from a range of women I interviewed.  These interviews are currently being pieced together and will play in between the dances, grounding the piece. 

    The Show is being preformed at :

    Muse Warehouse

     Friday Oct 31 (7:30, 8:30), Saturday (8)



    My biggest challenge is my budget, and keeping the quality of the piece with what props/set/costumes I have.  I have designers hard at work, but the more budget, the more freedom they can have

    Everything is out of pocket for this, that being said I need any support I can get.

    From rental of the space, to posters, to the head bands--any contribution helps me.

story:
The Show

In its inaugural year, Funny Face Productions will be producing  a musical featuring a cast of twenty-three young actors and actresses from the Sheridan area. The show, called 13, will be performed in the brand new Mars Black Box Theater, part of the recently-renovated WYO Performing Arts and Education Center. 

One of the most frequently produced new musicals of the last decade, 13 is a rollicking musical comedy featuring a cast exclusively comprised of tweens and teens. It’s a grown-up story about growing up! With an unforgettable rock score from Tony award-winning composer Jason Robert Brown, 13 is about discovering that cool is where you find it, and sometimes where you least expect it.

We Need Your Help!

Producing a musical is financially burdensome. Licensing, technical costs, rental fees, costumes, sets, and advertising are just a few of the many expenses for which we will be responsible. This experience will be worth every penny, but we will not be able to do it alone.

While some youth theater companies require cast members to pay a steep fee for participation, we at Funny Face Productions believe that the performing arts should be accessible to all and thus will never require our players to pay out of pocket.

Who We Are

My name is Emma Hall, and I’m a rising Junior at Brown University, majoring in Education Studies, and I will be directing 13. Growing up in Sheridan, taking part in local productions was a hugely formative part of my life. Theater helped me evolve from a shy, self-conscious individual to a confident, outspoken one. I’m so excited to be back in my hometown to help bring the joys of learning through the performing arts to almost two dozen young people, ages twelve to sixteen.

With the invaluable support of my parents, I am establishing Funny Face Productions in order to provide theatrical opportunities for middle adolescents in northeastern Wyoming. Funny Face Productions will be a collaborative community of young people who share a passion for the performing arts.

    The Impact

    The performing arts are a natural catalyst for community building, as demonstrated by the unexpected oasis of the arts Sheridan has become over the past few decades. Every year, Sheridan’s artists, musicians, and performers continue to grace our community with their gifts. Participating in 13 will be a valuable opportunity for the cast members to hone and develop their skills, while also enriching their community with a full weekend of performances, July 30 through August 2.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you are unable to contribute financially but still wish to help, please share this page with your friends and family, and spread the word about 13!
